Â I wish my current employer offered a Kaiser plan; I'd gladly pay extra for it.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical used to be 5 stars. It's not anymore. All the old friendly staff is gone and so is several doctors I've visited. They have huge staff turn over which is frustrating as a patient to have to re-explain medical issues to a new doctor every year. For my specific situation I'm taking a medication that has been well tolerated for several years that requires blood work every 3 months. They're now requiring me to have an appointment every 3 months to discuss said medicine even though at the actual appointments everything is fine. My old doctor there only required an annual followup and even said that my blood work was so good that he'd feel fine if I did it every six months. This just feels like a money grab to bill my insurance provider unneeded office visits.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Many problems with the doctors here. They can't or won't diagnose one of my problems. I have wasted probably 20 hours trying to get treatment and ending up with nothing more than lousy referrals, lost faxes, endless hours on hold, wasted trips, extra copays, just for that problem. (Thanks, Natalie :-( ). That problem is easily treatable if treated promptly, but require a physician to treat Â  (individuals who are not physicians are not allowed to purchase certain medications). I am also suffering from an injury. Bodhi Anderson, PA-C onemedical.com/la/physicâ¦ "The only thing that can cause loss of lordosis is a pulled muscle [long explanation of pulled muscle]". I attempted to quickly factcheck Bodhi and asked him to please be patient. Bodhi did not wait one second before he said in a raised voice that he had been doing this for 20 years and that I could go elsewhere for treatment, and then hung up. Not only was he incredibly rude, what he said was not true:-- Other causes of flatback syndrome include the entities listed below:Degenerative Disc Disease: [...]Vertebral Compression Fractures: [...]Ankylosing Spondylitis: [...]Post-Laminectomy Syndrome:[...]Apparently several causes of this condition but I could not find where pulled muscle was one such cause. The reason for my call was not to get into a fight. I called because I had been to Veronica Jow that morning to ask for assessment of my condition and a strategy to transition back to my normal active life. I didn't get that this morning. Veronica said that I could ask another provider about it. But I wasn't asking for her permission to go elsewhere! I was asking her what was wrong with me and what to do about it. I had to press her many times for this and each time she did not answer. Then, she said that the time was up so I had to leave the office. Also, I didn't get her doctor's report after the visit. I didn't get any suggested follow-up, either. I called in to One Medical, to ask about that morning's failed appointment with Veronica and how I still needed a plan for recovery. I was told that I'd get a call back from them within two hours. I waited patiently, but didn't get the call within two hours and so I called back and then the receptionist told me it wasn't two hours yet, and then slipped that it had been over 2 hours. Why she wanted to fight about 2 hours with me when I'm simply calling in to get treatment and following up on a call I was expecting, I do not know. Then she told me to wait a minute. I waited several minutes before being transferred to Bodhi. This is just one example of the sorts of problems I've had here. They seem nice, but when the doctors can't treat me they should not get frustrated with me about it!On the plus side: 1) the office is really nice, 2) the receptionists are usually very nice and clear-speaking when I call or visit, 3) Appointments are on-time. They seem to be seriously trying to have a better referral process, but it is still awful. The doctors are also mostly stupid. Sorry, but it is true. Â reason.com/blog/2007/01/â¦I am leaving this as 2 star in hopes that they have a doctor who is committed to health (rather than simply doing their job and billing the insurance companies for a yet unresolved condition). As for the lost 20+ hours of my life in wasted time, I won't get that back :-(.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: What to know: 1. When you receive your pricey bill (around $330) , call them! They'll bring it down to $175. BOMB2. use their virtual services - I've called in for UTI's, bc, and general derm issues. They're super fast and get your the meds you need. So much better/friendlier than other doctors in the United Healthcare Network!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I have been a member of One Medical since October 2015. I had a great experience with them until I scheduled a visit with Dr. Andrea Powlen and had to deal with One Medical's billing department. I was billed $419 for a less than 1 minute visit with Dr. Powlen that wasn't even necessary in the first place. She asked me to come once every 3 or 4 days for follow up visits and I am so glad I never went back. At $419 per visit, it would have been thousands of dollars without having the slightest clue that I was being billed for the unnecessary visits. I have read many reviews on yelp and it seems like I am not the only one to have faced this problem. On a side note, I have a very good insurance plan.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My employer pays for One Medical, otherwise I'd definitely not spend the money. I've had some really good providers and some really bad ones through One Medical. My primary complaint, though, is their operations. Everyone is super nice, but things just constantly fall through the cracks, and the supposed benefits and efficiencies actually end up costing me more time and frustration. I find a lot of my providers have ended up getting frustrated with One Medical and leaving for elsewhere. If you have a choice, I'd definitely avoid it.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical is a third-rate middleman with nice waiting rooms. They do not have any in-house medical expertise. They do not have any relationships with actual medical providers. Anything beyond a flu shot is going to require a referral. The admin staff will send you a message with Â some random service provider's contact info, who maybe won't call you for a week, and if you call them, they tell you they have to double-check the insurance authorization and they'll call you. Then they'll say the earliest available appointment is more than a month out. So you'll contact One Medical again, and they'll send you the next referral on their list within a day or two. Sometimes you'll finally get an appointment, get to the office, and be told the provider you have the appointment for doesn't accept your insurance, only a few doctors in the practice do and this isn't one of them but One Medical didn't bother to check that. And they don't have any available appointments for (wait for it, literally) more than a month anyway. Lather, rinse, repeat. When you do get care, it'll be some place that only has appointments available because no one wants to go there, e.g. a physical therapist's tech/assistant who conducted the assessment on the wrong hip and then gave me 30 days of exercise which they said, this won't help the problem, but you have to do it to get the insurance to allow you to seek other treatment. If you have a concussion and vertigo, it's still going to be all on you to navigate this process. They will never follow-up to check on your condition. The nurse practitioners you'll see who will trigger the referrals will all be super nice, and the techs that do the blood draws are skilled at painless needle insertion, but you will not actually get any treatment for any medical problem.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Elite 2021
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've been a patient for about 18 months and have seen a steady decline in care with a steady increase in costs. It is a shame because the premise is good, but the practice is terrible. All my favorite MDs have left for greener pastures in private care, as One Medical has promised so much to them, yet failed to deliver.{The company has great branding but fails to live up to its brand promises...}While the 45 minute appointments can be great as I do feel "heard", the productivity that comes from these meetings have been limited to "prescribing" supplements or very expensive compounded products - neither of which are covered by my insurance. Â Too much time is spent documenting my symptoms (CYA?), so much so that my MD apologizes every time I see her. Such is the current state of our medical system who fails to recognize that MDs need time to SEE their patients instead of staring into a computer screen.Anyway, most of my successes have come from consulting with a L.Ac outside of their system (and not covered by my insurance), then getting blood tests to verify the diagnosis and follow up tests to determine progress. (Oh, and One Medical just started charging a fee for blood draws, the nickle and diming is getting to be a bit much.)I'm currently looking for a new East Bay PCP Â and won't be renewing my "membership" with One Medical. Sad to say, as I tried so hard to like them.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My daughter would not post her visit to One medical but as a concerned dad I did. Â She was suffering from what I thought were just migraine headaches. Â A young male physician ( name withheld) Â scared her into going to UCSF to see a neurologist. Â There was nothing in her medical history to suggest anything out of the ordinary as discussed in our family of health care providers. After paying a huge copay and waiting 2 hours the neurologist did an exam and told her to take Excedrin for migraines for " migraine headaches". Â There are times to use specialists but a newbie doctor could not differentiate serious from simple.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Overall, I had a pretty mixed experience with One Medical. Some good, some bad. In the end, I decided I'd be fine without the service.Pro's*Online booking*Positive experiences with the doctors I interacted withCon's*Buggy/confusing software*Difficult to get a primary care doctor (spent over a year on a waitlist and never got one)*No refunds if you decide to cancelThe No Refunds policy is in particular strange since when I called to cancel, I was told they don't offer refunds, which is completely opposite of their advertised One Medical Promise policy.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: These people are thieves. I went for 1 checkup when I had just quit smoking. They sent me a bill for $487. Totally disproportionate because I was in there for 15 minutes, no tests were taken and I was told all the complaints I had were normal side effects. The lady listened to my lungs and that was the end of it.Don't fall into this trap.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: LOL! SMH! The Millennial mentality is frightening. These idiots are thoroughly convinced that their convoluted system is streamlined, efficient, time saving....BUT IT'S THE EXACT OPPOSITE! Â It's a blaring case of The Emperor's New Clothes. Therefore, I say that the Emperor is a naked fool, and good ridance!! Don't waste your prescious time trying to manuver their nonsensical maze! Â Turn & run.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This review is about the One Medical business, which came highly recommended. I called in ahead of my first appointment with questions about my insurance and billing. When I showed up for an appointment to get a repeat prescription I was told that I could go through insurance and pay $300 (!) or pay a reduced $175 up front. Under pressure I chose the $175 option. I then called my insurance, and got the full story. Insurance companies have contracted rates for different visits. It doesn't matter if the doctor bills $300 or $10,000 as the contracted rate is what's paid by insurance and then relayed to the patient. Feeling ripped off under pressure is not a nice feeling from an industry that one must rely on in very uncertain times of bad health.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Long story short. After a knee injury from falling riding a snowboard, I was told by one medical doctor's assistant over video call that I should rest five days before seeing a doctor. My knees felt better each day so I waited longer. Three weeks later some symptoms persisted so I went to a doctor and was diagnosed with a complete PCL tear. Basically missed a critically first few weeks of treatment. Well done one medical.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Just had my first appointment with One Medical.Before my visit with One Medical, my idea of a doctor's visit was this: 1) arrive 10 minutes before appointment 2) sit in the waiting room for 35-40 minutes 3) go to the patient room 4) sit for another 10 minutes 5) nurse comes in and takes vitals 6) sit for another 15-20 minutes 7) finally doctor comes in and spends maybe 5 minutes with me.At One Medical, this is what I experienced this morning: 1) arrive 10 minutes before appointment 2) doctor picks me up from the waiting room, exactly at the appointment time 3) spend 15 minutes with the doctor 4) I'm outAlso, I was able to get a next-day appointment booked easily thru the website (could have been same day if I went to a different branch).It's a game changer.Also it's pretty nice that the office is well furnished with some soothing (and choice) music piping through the Sonos speakers. Â A little bit of a spa-like experience.Also, Dr. Burns is great. Â Patient but really efficient, with a very calming demeanor.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I love One Medical's app as well as the ability to schedule same-day appointments. I also like that they have many convenient locations. However, my most recent experience with One Medical was a very expensive one-- and I've since cancelled my membership.Though One Medical "accepts" my insurance, they are not in network. That I knew. Â  What is worse, However, in making referrals to outside specialists they did not even try to find an in network specialists. What should have been a very routine colonoscopy turned out cost several thousand dollars out of pocket--even after my insurance paid their share.Buyer beware. Â  One can argue that this is solely the patient's responsibility, however, if they are going to refer a patient to a single clinic for a procedure their billing and insurance department should due some due diligence.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've been going to one medical for 6 years and love them. I'm able to get same day appointments almost anywhere in the city. I get frequent UTIs, by using the treat me now app feature I'm sometimes able to get antibiotics sent to the pharmacy without even needing an appointment. When I had a nasty cold that was lingering, I used their video chat feature to get advice from their medical team. Some of their doctors I've liked more than others, but there are many options for doctors and to find one I click with. There is a yearly membership fee. Like with anything medical you do, make sure they're covered by your insurance before you go. They're in network for me and I found their billing to be a breeze. I just pay my small copay at the front desk after my appointment, simple. Labs get paid by mail, but are detailed so I know what I'm being charged for. No mystery bills.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Update: One Medical is still sending me emails, including an email with a hyperlink to reactivate my membership that I keep trying to cancel, even though I asked them to remove my personal information from their files last year. This is not how a company that handles medical information should conduct itself.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I can in yesterday for my visit with dr Mary Lowen. She was so sweet & helpful with me and definitely an amazing practitioner. My appointment was quick, I was super in and out and I had no wait time. Additionally, this location has a really attentive staff & a very clean office. :)
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Elite 2021
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I switched to One Medical because the primary care physician I was seeing moved over to them. She was stellar. Now I pay a yearly fee, besides my insurance, and for that additional fee I expect just a little bit more, instead, I have received a whole lot less. A buzzer goes off while I'm being examined after 15 minutes. The Doctor types the notes while I'm there as though it is a part of the 15 minute window. It is a model I am not fond of. They push you to conduct business online, which I detest. You cannot reach the specific office where your physician is, but are routed to a central office. No continuity, and no knowledge of who you are dealing with. Healthcare is a business, I understand that, but the human aspect of it is paramount. I am waiting for a referral that thus far has taken 3 phone calls, all to different assistants, and one call to my insurance, which informed me no one has contacted them in regards to a referral. It should not take 8 days to obtain a referral! I will not be renewing with them.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: If you want to be billed $400+ for a less than 10 mins visit with nothing useful, One Medical is your answer.This is like the most outrageous kind of ripoff gimmick. The doctor looks at you for 5 seconds and whoa! You are billed $150 for the visit that is not even supposed to help you. If you decline to pay and have them bill your insurance.. they will quadruple this amount which if your insurance doesn't support you will again have to pay out of pocket.I really don't get the point of having to go through "medical groups" for a simple doctor's appointment.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical is nothing special. They require a fee of $150 fee a year to be a patient which supposedly covers "exceptional doctor's office experience" and technology... All doctors should be integrating technology these days... for heavens sake, it's 2017! In the past they waived this fee but I have been advised that they have tightened up on this policy. While the doctors are just mediocre, I don't think they are worth an additional $150/year on top of copay's and insurance. If you're going to ask me for additional fees, i'd expect more than a monthly email subscription. If you're looking for a swanky office with sub par doctors, this is your place!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I went in for a visit with a cough - it took 15 mins and they gave me a nasal spray which gave me nose bleeds and in no way helped. Then I got a $400 bill after I left with them saying my insurance has been "accepted" and my copay should be far less. Â Now I have a huge bill AND still have a problem with the cough- as if I would return for additional help with that bill. I will certainly be cancelling my membership and fighting that bill
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This place is amazing! This is the first time I've been to the doctor in the state of California and the people in here were so welcoming! They just happened to be one of the few places that accepted my insurance which was a life saver! Everyone there from the receptionists to my doctor, Bethany, were amazing, kind and receptive! They were so nice and awesome that it makes me want to come back even if I'm not sick LOL!! I've also never used an app before with the doctor's office so that was pretty cool! I made an appointment so quickly and easily, it blew my mind honestly! Once I got there, the wait was about 5 minutes and then the rest is history! I totally recommend this place, you won't regret coming here!!! :-)
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This review is just for the lab work, but this morning I told my boss I was going out for coffee and stopped in to get some blood drawn in preparation for my annual physical. Without an appointment, I spent less than two minutes in the waiting room before I was whisked away by a lovely phlebotomist who expertly drained my veins, and congratulated me on... well, I don't know what I was being congratulated for, but she told me I did a good job... good job bleeding I guess. Then she sent me off to pee in a cup and I was back on the street with enough time still to pick up coffee without raising suspicion back at the office. I think the whole thing was less than ten minutes. Remarkable! Front desk staff was great too, and the building is lovely.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Abysmal experience! If you have a medical provider that works, don't switch. I've had all sorts of issues with OneMedical over the last year and even getting managers involved doesn't smooth them out.My wife on the other hand has had a 5 Star experience, but I'll let her write her own review. I've joined her for some of her appointments and it's a night and day difference.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I am fairly new to the Bay Area so I thought it will be a good idea to join so I can get appointment when I need one. I went in for an office visit, got two immunizations, and a referral for mammogram. I was told my insurance may not cover for one of the immunization and was given the option of paying it out of pocket instead of going through my insurance. So I paid out of pocket for that (typhoid). When I get the letter from my insurance company, it shows I was covered for both of the immunizations!! So Â I was told to pay out of pocket and my insurance got billed. I contacted the office and is still waiting to hear from Medical One. Will update the review when I hear back from the office as to whether I would be refunded.** Update. I was not able to get the refund. In the process of contacting my insurance company. BTW, you may be able to get an appointment on the same day, but you don't get to see a doctor. You get to meet a nurse but your insurance bill will show that a doctor has provided the service and your insurance will be billed at over $400. The office is nice but it is hardly worth the "membership" fee you are charged.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I have no complaints about the doctors, though it does take a significant amount of time (up to 6 weeks or so) to see some specialists. My problem is instead with their billing model and the annual membership fee. I pay for my insurance as well as my copays and to be hit with an annual fee for what amounts to common sense (booking online, emailing doctors, and the like). I got this at Keiser Permanente with no additional fees. Recently my doctor messaged me about a new prescription wanting to make sure I wasn't having issues, but without the fee paid there was no way to message my doctor back to discuss some side effects. That's a pretty scary customer experience.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: No real doctors, no labs, slow follow-up.Yes, I got to see someone right away, very nice. Not a doctor. Could not make a real diagnostics. Sent me for an X-ray at UCSF. Still waiting for the results. Emailed. Called. I moved down here from Seattle and I am not used to this level of health care. My doc back home would send me downstairs for imaging and would have the results right away.Ah yeah, and they charge you a "membership fee" for this privilege.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I will say, to be fair, the access to more timely appointments seems to have improved since I wrote my first review.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This place is horrible. I paid off a bill months ago and received the same bill in the mail. They are useless and idiotic, go to a real company for medical care!!! One medical is a bunch of half witted hipster idiots here in San Francisco. Save yourself the trouble and go elsewhere
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This review is for the experience that I had at One Medical Group's 110 Sutter Location: I tried out One Medical Group at a time when I was new to SF, quite ill, & in desperate need of Medical Care. I had insurance through BCBS but did not have a Provider/PCP & was not sure where to go so I looked them up on Yelp, saw some good ratings & reviews and decided to give them a try. This was my experience.It was a horrible choice & a regretful terrible route to have taken. A sorely poor choice I made to give in to OneMedical. It was almost like jumping through unnecessary hoops or taking a pointless detour to access medical care. They were very quick to sell me the Membership & did everything they possibly could to convince me to join, & sell me their services. They wanted that money - $150 for a Membership. They were advertised perks such as on time appointments, a stylish waiting room, & they seemed very keen to have me. From the moment I rang them, I felt as though I was being sold something, it was like ringing up an exclusive health spa or Gym. They were fabulous on the phone & sounded so exclusive & glamourous. It was JUST like being sold a Gym Membership, or calling in after seeing an exclusive Advert on QVC with the Agent waiting right next to the phone prepared with a script. Walking in to their office was like visiting an exclusive health Spa, or Real Estate Office.. It felt fake, like it lacked authenticity, it absolutely did not feel like a doctors office.After visiting reception & paying the Â£150, I was sat down at a computer where I would pick out my PCP just by looking at faces, a brief summary about them & their qualifications, a guide with their location of office/clibnic based on neighbourhood preference & convenience. Then there was the Membership Fee, OF COURSE, which they insisted I pay before they would provide service. A Lovely Membership Fee - only Â£$150 to join & become an 'exclusive member'. Just as if I was joining a Gym indeed! I observed a few things right off the bat. First the staff at reception were not dressed appropriately at all, certainly not for the Medical Field. They looked like they were working at a H&M, Forever 21, or some Health Spa/Gym sort place - they had pearcings, crazy hair, and looked casual, cool, though quite informal. They ought to have been wearing scrubs, a uniform, name tags, and something a bit more presentable, which is what I would have expected that being they are a Medical Office. But it seemed ok because of course One Medical is not your typical Doctor indeed. I selected a female PCP cos I felt that I'd work better with a woman. She looked lovely on the computer screen but even after I chose my PCP when I went in to see my selected PCP she wasn't even the person I had selected! It turned out the PCP I selected was on Maternity Leave, & I wasn't even notified at the time I signed up! A Nurse Practitioner saw ne instead (Nurse Tatum I believe) - I didn't even recognize & her appearance made me feel very uncomfortable. She was dressed more like a Bank Teller or Real Estate Agent, she had no name tag, and wasn't even wearing a white coat or Medical Attire. It made me feel uncomfortable, like I was in the wrong place, and was not what I had expected. As for the medical component, I was incredibly ill with a cold when I went in I knew exactly what kind of Medications that I needed cos I had empty bottles from Meds I had previously taken that I was prescribed. I had a sinus infection & needed refills on a few medications I had previously been taking which was the reason for my visit. I was unwilling at the time to compromise, I just wanted to feel better, so out of desperation I went forward with paying the $Â£150, despite all of these observations that had indeed turned me off. I accepted the fill in Nurse Practitioner that had called my name instead of the Doctor that I had chosen on the computer. The medications she prescribed me were not what I was seeking or had wanted. I only got 3 out of the 5 that I had requested & for my Sinus infection instead of prescribing me antibiotics she told me to go buy some nasal saline pot from Walgreens! Absolutely absurd & ridiculous! i should have just gone to the Emergency Room or Urgent Care. I was so horrified that I never followed up with her or did anything. I was so displeased that I never even went back, but of course I got lots of bills in the mail! I feel like One Medical Group is geared towards a specific type of cliental, & turn their back on others needing more specialized care. They are definitely exclusive & not open to just everyone, which is one of the reasons they sell themselves with a Membership. I have since moved on to UCSF & I'd recommend going with CPMC, Kaiser, St Francis/Marys or even SF General instead. I would not recommend One Medical Group to any of my colleagues.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Elite 2021
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This place is a total scam. I signed up in February 2016 to go for a simple doctors checkup (total 20 mins long) and found out weeks later that i was billed $400+ for the visit and my healthcare somehow doesn't cover the type of visit. They had not let me know about the price of the first visit so I went a second time making my bill a total of $800!!!!!Not to mention when I tried calling to work through all this with the team they were extremely unfriendly and unhelpful. They offered me a "50%" discount (making the total bill $400) which is ludicrous and begs the question why the visits are so expensive in the first place if they can mark it down that much. I highly DO NOT RECOMMEND One Medical and have been extremely frustrated with their service.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I am sitting in the office of One Medical offices on Sutter street having a truly awful experience. I just spent fifteen minutes with a PA who who asked me what medications I take, probed my jaw with her fingers, and looked into my ears with a lighted scope. She then confirmed that yes, I do have TMJ and there's nothing to be done about it except keep taking Ibuprofin. When I went out to pay my co-pay, I was told that it would be $100 usually, but since I was a new patient, that would be $150. I balked, because a couple years ago I paid $140 for an uninsured appointment with CarePractice that was twice as long, included tests, and sent me home with medication. The receptionist told me sweetly that of course they could try putting it through the insurance, but there was no way of knowing how much it would cost then, except that it would most likely be considerably more. Probably $300 to $500. Or I could pay $150 now. "Let me make sure I understand you: I have to give you $150 now or you are going to charge me an unknown fee, probably somewhere between $300 and $500? For fifteen minutes?" "Yes, that is what I mean.""That's crazy.""We don't know what the insurance will say.""Can you call the insurance?"She goes to call the insurance company. I get on the phone too, but my hands are shaking, so I'm still winding my way through their automated system when the receptionist comes over and shows me a figure. It's $789 She explains this is the highest the insurance company pays for that code, and it could be as much as that. In other words, I can give her $150 now, or find myself with a bill for $789 later. Take it or leave it.The insurance rep, when I finally get through, gives me a guestimate of $78.68. This sounds a lot more reasonable - I realize medical care is not cheap, but a $300-$800 range for chatting with someone for 15 minutes is pretty crazy. There is no way I would have come in if I'd known it was going to cost that much. Apparently, I'm not the only one facing this problem. There have been several disagreements during the half hour I've sat here with patients telling the receptionist that their insurance companies have told them that they shouldn't have to be forking over these large sums in the office, that One Medical should be billing the insurance companies. The receptionist always sweetly insists that they pay.Eventually, I call my wife who comes over and bails me out by telling them we'll just put it through the insurance company and work it out with them if the charges turn out to be outrageous. But I still leave the office in tears. There's really no reason, IMO, why I should have to choose between forking over $150 (for a $78 procedure) immediately or face a bill of several hundred dollars. I gather the reason why I was pressured into making a decision on the spot, without access to information or time to think it over, is that it's easier for One Medical to get money that way. I can't stop comparing my experience here with the one at CarePractice, where I was handed a binder upon arrival that very clearly spelled out all the procedures available and how much they cost. In fact, they put their fees right up on the web, for everyone to see: carepractice.com/feesThey also don't charge a $150 "annual fee". I didn't mind paying the fee when I signed up yesterday. But I thought I was buying protection against an experience like this.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: SO incredibly frustrating. I've had three different experiences with One Medical and they've all been headaches, from doctors blowing me off to randomly cancelling my appointments with no prior notice. None of the staff seems to communicate with one another. It's a shame, I love the theory of OM but it's being carried out in a terrible manner. I keep trying to give them chances but at this point I'll be headed elsewhere when my membership expires.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I had a 15 minute appointment with Dr Elizabeth Maier from ONE MEDICAL.I arrived and she told me "I only have 15 minutes, I hope you know that".I had an order from my cardiologist for an ultrasound (liver, upper abdomen) I wanted her advice on where I should have it done. She told me that she couldn't give me an order for an ultrasound. I told her that I had one, gave it to her. She looked at it. She said she couldn't give me an order. I said I didn't want one, I just needed to know where to go. She asked me why my Doc didn't tell me where to go, I said I didn't know. She asked me what I wanted from her. I said advice on where to go, that I thought ONE MEDICAL was a concierge service to help me. She said she could look up a place (we are 5 mins into the 15 min meeting at this point). She pulls up Health Diagnostics and I call them (from her office), she tells me after 2 mins "can you do that outside, I am busy." Now, I still had 8 mins left by my count. I left. She was a completely unprofessional from the time I walked in to the time I left. I was concerned with the fact my Doc asked for a liver ultrasound, she showed no care/patient concern at all - concerned with her issues, her situation.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I am new to One Medical, was very excited about their concept on Medical Care. Â Part of what I found exciting was that I could communicate via email with my doctor and possibly avoid taking time from work to go to the doctor. Â I was wrong. Â I've seen a lot of posts that people had problems getting a Primary. Â I did get one, in my network my first appointment. Â That was about as good as it gets. Â After my first visit I was sent to Physical Therapy. Â I sent the doctor an email asking a question, no response. Â I called One Medical, asked if I am allowed to email or if I needed to get approval or something. Â The Receptionist said the Dr's are busy and will get back to you when they can. Â I got a response 4 weeks later. Â After a few months of Physical Therapy, the therapist told me to go back to the Primary as there is an issue she cannot resolve and wants me to see another specialist. Â I went to see the Primary, she sent me in for blood work. Â Got the results via email, Primary was copied. Â Sent 5 messages asking what my next steps should be .. come back to the office, more test etc. Â That was 3 months ago, no response. Â I sent an inquiry to the general mailbox for One Medical, no response. Â I also thought it strange that the Primary spent the whole appointment sitting behind a computer. Â I got a lot of "oh, that sounds terrible"; "wow, you must be uncomfortable" ... I do not want soothing words, I want medical assistance!! Â The worst news is I was going to go back to my previous doctor (even though I do not like him, at least he follows-up) and I just got a voicemail from his office telling me he joined One Medical --- UGH!!!!! I am posting here because in my desperation to find a solution I found these reviews. Â While I am pleased that I am not the only one struggling with One Medical, I am equally as disturbed that so many people have had similar issues. Â I noticed "Cookie L. of One Medical Group " responds to most posts, maybe I'll finally get some help from One Medical. Â Probably not.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Something to know about One Medical. Their billing systems are from 1989 if not earlier. As you will note from many people below, they don't or are really bad at billing your insurance companies. I have gotten 3 bills from them saying my insurance did not cover the doctors visit. When I call the insurance companies they don't have any claim from One Medical. So I call One Medical about this, they say they will research it and get back to me. Â No one gets back, you get the same bill again in the mail. Not renewing my membership since they have no clue on how to send an invoice to your insurance company. Just got a recent bill, sent admin[at]onemedical an email and got no response.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: They ignored a recommendation from a referral that ultimately resulted in a 6-months-delayed cancer diagnosis.Be careful with this place.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: For quality medical care, look elsewhere!I have been a member of One Medical for years and have just ended my toxic relationship with them. Â Things they have done in the past include:1) Taking the wrong amount of blood so they were unable to test me for certain diseases2) Charging substantial amounts for what seemed like routine tests with absolutely no notice that they cost extra3) More misdiagnoses than I can countIf you end up actually being able to get an appointment with a M.D. or a D.O., you've hit the lottery. Â Even if you do, expect the doctor to be rushing you and giving you all sorts of crazy advice. Â I once had a skin problem and after a number of visits, I was finally able to see a doctor. Â He told me the solution was "to grow a beard." Â (Note: When I went to a doctor outside One Medical Group, a doctor was able to instantly tell me what was wrong and the condition, which I had for months, quickly went away and never returned). Â Really, this isn't a service to see doctors, it's to see nurse practitioners who have very little bedside manner and are, at times, downright rude. Â Writing that, I don't know why I stuck with them for so long. Â Today was the kicker, when I had an important appointment, and I received notice a few hours before that the nurse I was going to see actually would not be able to write a prescription I needed. Â This is after confirming on the phone when I made the appointment (since it, as always, would be with a nurse practitioner) that the nurse would be able to help me. Â Perhaps just as bad, the nurse I was speaking to, Mara, kept pointing out how long we were on the phone every few minutes as I desperately tried to find a solution to being misinformed about my appointment.If you want to pay $149/year to be treated badly, get misdiagnosed, and have your appointment changed hours before you're going in, this is the place for you.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Elite 2021
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I really have no axe to grind here. Â I am a real person, you can see all my positive reviews. Â So this is real. I have been a member for years and seldom use it, so it's been fine -- until I did use it and they then sent me an INCORRECT bill and then hassled ME to call MY insurance to figure out "what it was for". Â I said, "you don't know what you're billing me for, and you're asking ME to figure it out?"Then finally they "apologized" for billing me incorrectly, but I really wonder if they would have caught that if I just paid (which I likely would have done because I'm busy.) Â I bet they would have kept my money. Â What a fraud.Then to be treated so rudely just because I am calling about THEIR mistake was beyond the pale. Â Finally, when I asked to speak to someone about it via email, and leaving phone messages, I got ZERO return calls or emails.The whole point of this is to have real people who care about getting it right and to save you time. Â I got neither. Â  Tom Lee if you're reading this, please give me a call! :)++Follow up -- it was a very unpleasant and time-wasting ordeal, BUT Tom Lee himself did give me a call, and straightened it out, and he copped to their mistake. Â Also their office manager followed up. Â Refreshing!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: What a brilliant concept! Affordable, friendly, humane and dare I say...inspiring health care. I walked out of here with a spring in my step, I was so utterly thrilled with the whole experience.My coworker had told me about One Medical Group's system - you pay a yearly membership fee ($149), and then can utilize any of their SF clinics. Sounded unusually easy. See, like most 20-something year-olds, I don't go to the doctor to check on my health...I go to the doctor when I'm on the edge of death, desperate for drugs and educated answers. And as we lax youngins know, doctors don't like last-minute appointments. In fact, I have always ended up in Urgent Care because it's easier than begging my doctor to squeeze me in.But with One Medical Group's snazzy, patient-oriented set-up, the minute you have symptoms (or a week after you've been suffering from some unknown infection) you can just hop online to check available appointments, book it, and you're good to go. I booked an appointment the very next day! They have multiple clinics in SF, and the office atmosphere feels so clean, modern, and stylish - totally unlike those gross, sterile, lifeless doctors offices we're used to. They've got sleek furniture, stacks of cool mags, and...get this...fabulous music (they were playing Lykke Li, Beirut, and The Knife during my visit - where the hell am I? This is too good to be true!)Ok, but I haven't even gotten to the good part yet. The doctors! I picked my doctor, Amber, online, based on nothing except the fact that she looked nice. And boy, was my intuition correct. Amber has such a calm presence, and really listened when we were chatting about my medical history, concerns, etc. I felt immediately at ease, knowing I could be totally honest and that she was actually paying attention to what I was saying. So un-doctor-like. In fact, everyone here from the receptionists to the lab techs to the nurses are super cool, and they seem like they actually enjoy their jobs. That's the key difference.I got my lab tests emailed to me within 4 days. Everything was so streamlined, efficient, and high-tech that I'm almost excited to have an excuse to go back (almost). This is what health care would be like in a perfect world. See for yourself!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I may not sign up next year and this is why: - A lot of (mostly?) non-MDs- Not a lot of specialization: * There is one sports injury doc and it takes 6 weeks to get an appointment. Not generally helpful for an injury. (Although he is good.)* I need a throat/nose/ear doc right now and can't find one in their network.- Immediate appointments are a great idea but not really a reality here unless you are willing to leave San Francisco or happen to get lucky. (I've been lucky before.)- The web site does not offer searchability for doctors' specialties. So you need to go one by one to see what they do. This is tedious.Why you Might Like it:- Basic prescriptions can be filled via their app. If you get tons of UTIs or something, you will want this service.- Online everything, instead of needing to call. Thank god.- Doc offices are prettier than normal.- Individual practitioners are good. Never had a bad experience.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: USELESS Unfortunate and completely horrible story: We were attacked by a deranged homeless transsexual male while walking down the street in the Finacial District. Â (Yes, really.) She actually scratched our faces, necks & bit through my boyfriends shirt badly. (Think bloody dog bite.) Â We had no idea where to go to get treatment. It was clearly a "tetanus shot" or 'worse' kind of immediate situation. We googled & found this place 5blocks say so we rushed over. I had used them before in Beverly Hills and thought it would be great. I was SOOO WRONG. Even though I was 'in their system' they did NOTHING. Did not set an urgent appointment to see us, open the door to see a nurse. Actually they stared at us & would not even touch us. They told us we should, "go to a facility that could help," set alcohol wipes on the desk with a piece of gauze. To their credit they did: try to cover their 'corporate arse' by conveniently offering to 'get us a ride & apologizing profusely. God help you, Â if you actually needed medical care and totally don't die in their office, you'll clearly never be revived!DISGUSTING and USELESS EXCUSE FOR MEDICAL CARE. I will be cancelling my 'membership'.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I would avoid this place unless you like paying extra money for subpar service. I signed up over the phone and they failed to mention that the primary care provider they were assigning to me was not a doctor, but a PA. Contrary to all the promises, my first appointment did not start on time and I waited around in the waiting room wondering why I was paying a premium for "timely" appointments. I still haven't received the test results for the tests that my PA conducted 1.5 months ago, which I was reminded of when I just received the bill. ALSO, the bill seems pretty high for routine labwork considering that I have great health insurance. Totally unimpressed. I'm cancelling my membership.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've been a member of One Medical for two years now. I haven't had any serious medical issues, so I really haven't had a strong opinion of the services it provides, until now. This changed today when I got a message from my primary care physician that she is leaving her practice at One Medical. She recommended that I change my primary care to a nurse practitioner in the One Medical Office, which I found strange. Why would a Medical Doctor recommend Â a nurse practitioner to replace her? I called Blue Shield, my medical insurance provider, and I was told that Blue Shield does not allow nurse practitioners or physicians assistants to be chosen as primary care physicians, so even if I followed the recommendation of my PCP to go with this nurse practitioner, Blue Shield wouldn't allow it. Anyway, I would rather have a medical doctor Â as my PCP. So I went on the One Medical website to chose a new medical doctor that Blue Shield has in its network. I was surprised that all of the One Medical physicians in San Francisco are waitlisted, so the only providers available are nurse practitioners and an extremely limited number of physician assistants. I called One Medical and asked the representative how I was going to chose a Primary Care Physician when none are available. The rep said that I would have to be waitlisted and it could take anywhere from six months to as much as two years to get a medical doctor as my primary care physician. He said that until that time, if I should require medical attention, I can make an appointment with one of the nurse practitioners. Â Although I like the idea of One Medical's services of providing same day office visits, I find it strange that One Medical has an extremely limited amount of actual physicians. At the time I joined One Medical I didn't mind paying the annual fee because my Primary Care Physician was an actual medical doctor that was board certified and accepted by Blue Shield insurance. I really liked my doctor and it is unfortunate that she is leaving One Medical. Now I find myself at a crossroad wondering if One Medical Services are worth it if no medical doctors are available anymore. There definitely appears to be a decline in the level of their service if One Medical can't attract any physicians to meet the needs of their clients. As I stated, I like the concept of One Medical and I really hope that I can get a Primary Care Physician like the one I had before. The idea of waiting years and years for one to become available is not acceptable to me nor should it be to any of the other One Medical clients. One Medical might be a good option for someone who doesn't mind placing their care in the hands of a nurse rather than a medical doctor. I don't see this as being an issue for minor medical issues. But I sure would like a doctor around for more serious issues. Especially if I am paying premium for the service and the fees increase yearly.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Elite 2021
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This practice is the biggest rip off and they deserve negative 5 stars! They charged $460 for a 15 minute office visit when I had a bad cough/flu and did nothing for me. I can get "rest and lots of fluids" off any website. Â Total rip off!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I don't think I have ever changed my mind about my 1 star reviews. Â Cookie has been very helpful in address my concerns. Â She handled my anger with finesse and I will credit that in my desire to give this place another chance soon. Â My opinion of Scott stays. Â Period. Â I will update my second experience soon.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Horrible experience. Â I went to a nurse practitioner that was more interested in showing me what their version of WebMD said for treating my symptons than listening to me. Â She did not care that I have had those symptons repeatedly throughout my life and medicine "A" ALWAYS cured it. Â But her WebMD did not recommend medicine "A". Â She ended up prescribing me something different which did not work. Â The next time I went in, I saw a different nurse practitioner hoping to get someone that would actually listen to me, but instead she took the same stance as the first nurse practitioner and would only give me a referral to a specialist. Â I took the referral, saw the specialist (not at One Medical) who proceeded to give me the medicine that had always worked in the past and he told me not to waste my time seeing a doctor/nurse practitioner that won't listen to a patients past experience.I promptly canceled my membership with them and will never be going back.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I use to love One Medical until I realized they are only good at standard visits... If you have anything serious or have symptoms that might be serious, most of the providers I have seen will tell you it's nothing and will not test you... I have had two serious issues in the past year and I'm glad I pushed to be tested for both because I had symptoms for a reason! I have had better service at Golden Gate Urgent Care. They will actually test you for your symptoms without the hassle...
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: The entire idea of this service is flawed. They keep recruiting for new patients but they don't have enough doctors. I've been trying to get a primary Dr for months and everyone is wait listed! It's ridiculous. The one Dr. I did get to see has now left the practice. They only have PAs and NP and I'm sorry but I want a male Dr. It's not that much to ask. They can't hold onto the MDs they have so why are they aggressively recruiting for new patients?! If you have a good primary physician stay where you are. I guess this service would work if you don't care who you see and don't want to build a relationship with your doctor. The whole service seems to cater to fast-food medicine.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've worked in a doctor's office before - hectic and not an easy job. The staff at One Medical Group are so wonderful! Grace under pressure. So helpful and pleasant. Sam, is one name that comes to mind, who has helped me book an appointment - super professional and nice!Excellent docs here too. Dr. Rothman is smart, compassionate, and never rushed. I've really loved Dr. Alpert and Dr. Zeljko Milovanovic and Dr. Adrienne Kassis as well. I would recommend them in a heart beat. Kind and understanding and patient and explain everything very clearly. Â After a major accident I was in great hands with One Medical Group and have appreciated the team's expert care. Also the NPs are wonderful. I am so thrilled One Medical Group exists. They put the care back into health care.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: DO NOT TRUST THEM WITH YOUR HEALTH. Â  I've been a member of One Medical Group for at least 6 years. I used to say they were the best medical provider I've ever had. Not any more. Â  Most recently, I called to have a prescription refilled. I spoke with Wendy. Then I called and spoke with Melody because it wasn't sent as One promises. Then... I spoke with Corinne, who's job is customer quality assurance who apologized and acknowledged she didn't know why the ball got dropped and my prescriptions weren't filled. She said she'd personally take care of it. Â  Now, I just spoke with Amanda who said it STILL hadn't been filled and had no reason why. This is three weeks of totally unacceptable behavior for a medical provider. Â  Unfortunately I have no health insurance and must order from Canada... with a couple week's lead time. One Medical's incompetence is costing me hundreds of dollars and weeks of frustration and broken trust. Â  Don't trust them. They are not the company they used to be. Â So sad to write this. They really used to be an amazing health care provider.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I love One Medical and I don't understand the bad reviews. Â I have a doctor I adore, I can always get in to see here. Â I can blood work done at any One Medical office, and I feel that I get great care.Even when I needed to see a Cardiologist quickly and no one could see me for 3 or 4 weeks, my PCP got me an appointment in right away.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical couldn't be more easy. Online booking, email your doctor and a bunch of locations in and out of the city. If you are looking for a doctor, I recommend Erica. She is amazing. She brings ease to any conversation with a comfortable rapport, blending her knowledge of homeopathic and western medicine, for a holistic experience.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I just visited again (going on three years with One Medical) and realized I overlooked some things in my review. Here are more things I love:If I have a weird rash that I want to get looked at right away and my primary provider isn't available, I can peruse who is available and read their bios--thus letting me choose someone who has expertise in my area of concern and is available within 24 hours.I love that there are no intermediaries. If I booked an appointment, I only see the provider I booked it with--they take my height and weight and lead me to the room. It cuts out having to wait two times before seeing the doctor. I love that each patient room has a desk with two chairs. They are strategically placed so that I'm never sitting across the desk from the doctor but rather diagonal from them. I appreciate that I'm not expected to immediately sit up on the table and that the initial conversation always happens when I'm sitting in a normal chair. I know these are small things but they make a huge difference.For women's health exams: She had me step into the area with the exam table and closed the curtain that divided the room in half, so she never actually left the room while I changed, she just was on the other side of the curtain. I appreciate not having the awkward knock on the door with them peeking in to see if it's okay to come back in. Also, the gowns are roomy and made of a soft fabric with snaps every six inches to close it. The gown I was given was leopard print. And she covered the exam table in a similarly soft white cloth.Still loving it!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Aileen Kucsera is such a terrible disappointment to One Medical. If you must go here, make sure to request to not have her. She has been, without a doubt, the crudest professional I have ever had the displeasure of conversing with. I asked her about a medical problem that I have been suffering with for years and she told me my time was up and to reschedule another appointment. She proceeded to shove me out the door, as well. Aileen Kucsera is the worst, and if you are reading this, I hope you lose money and clients because of me. You are a pathetic excuse for a health-care provider. One star is too generous for you. One Medical, I hope you really rethink about the kids you choose to associate with and work for you.One Medical cares more for its image and being savvy and modern and cut edge and cool than actually about medicine or health care. Their arrangement of priorities is clear. It's about money and image; not health and people.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Elite 2021
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My coworkers warned me, but I couldn't pass up the online appointment service and bajillion locations right by my work. Even paid their annual membership fee which was over $100, thought it was worth the fact that they always have same day (sometimes same hour!) appointments and it's a 30 foot walk from my work, they also have fancy hip couches and decor in their waiting rooms where they play top 20 music (gag). Unfortunately that's about all the benefit. Here's what I've been told here, nearly word for word:- "Sorry for your 20 minute wait, we couldn't find the doctor!"- "Oh we can't handle that here, we'll have to refer you to a real doctor"- "Well billing (essentially the price) depends on if you're paying out of pocket or through insurance"And here are my experiences:- Never on time- Billed my insurance nearly $300 for the five minute referral appointment- Billed my insurance nearly $500 for a simple urine test, a ten minute appointment
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Had an issue with Brown and Toland and so called One Medical to switch to them as my PCP. Yvette answered the phone and was truly amazing. I'm not very savvy about primary care/hmos/ in vs. out of network but she made everything super clear. She stayed on the phone with me for 30 mins and told me exactly what I'd need to do to make sure I paid the minimal amount out of pocket. She also was able to get me an appointment the same day, for only a few hours after I called. It was really an awesome experience and I highly recommend the group!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This place is super convenient - Yes, there is a membership fee but the fact that I can see a doctor same day, and will only be out of work for about a half an hour makes it worth it. On top of that, my PA-C was really helpful (Sarah Maxwell) and lab work was so easy. The only reason they don't get 5 stars was the receptionist was really confusing about insurance. When I called to straighten things out the next day, it was too late - so a bit annoying with billing but I know better now.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Turned away for being 20 minutes late, feeling horrible, thanks for your cocearn One Medical.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Looking back on the last 12 years of not having a primary care doctor, and always having not a clue why every hospital visit doctor would ask me, "who's my primary / family doctor?" I now know. I use think... people still have these? I thought only existed in Northern Exposure. I suppose in major cities there are many offerings for primary doctors, but where do I go? The giant monoliths of UCSF & CPMC? When an acute attack of neck pain set on, my co workers suggested this place, and it was as streamlined, personal cared for, calm, professional, thorough & comfortable as they said it would be. I've been seeing them for about a month during this weird nervous system situation, and they've been readily available and attentive. For now, this is my initial diagnosis for this place. I'm sure I'll be back for more updates, but I am way down to have a primary doctor like this.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Relatively new member with One Medical...3 visits later I'm extremely satisfied with my overall experience. Professional, incredibly flexible/easy to schedule visits via their website or app and each office has modern decor, so many convenient locations in SF that I can easily walk to and the doctors are knowledgeable/professional/hip/up to date. In sum, this concept is incredible - kudos to founder Tom Lee and team for creating a game-changing healthcare experience! Who knew going to see the doctor can actually be fun?! Just fantastic.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Amazing.The best healthcare experience I've had, hands down. The online scheduling of appts, and quick access to your support staff via email has been fantastic over the last 3 years. It makes it easy to stop in for a quick visit on a short timeline if you have something to discuss, without waiting multiple weeks for an appointment like at other doctors. Also, access to a wide range of doctors and nurses for various specialties, and offices all over the city if you're often trying to fit in a visit between client visits in random neighborhoods.Can honestly say they have gone out of the way to make my life better over the last 3+ years. Give them a shot.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This review is for One Medical Group in general. Great for BASIC, GENERAL CARE. I think the focus on customer service & their use of technology (website, app) Â are what makes One Medical a true gem in the industry and an innovative company. They streamline the process if you need an appointment by giving you access to the calendar of all the doctors in the area, and you can even get a prescription written for you via e-mail (if it's minor). This allows for a myriad of possibilities, and the likelihood of getting an appointment when you need it (often day-of or the next day) is actually a possibility. Most other Medical Companies I have dealt with are extremely inefficient with this, and do not pay attention/care about the patient's needs. OM's e-mail support team is always on-point and punctual. Â I've had nothing but great experiences with One Medical. Like everyone has said, the yearly fee is worth every penny.The only downside is that the sheer amount of people on staff does make it a double-edged sword. One thing I would recommend is making a relationship with one particular doctor or smart PA if you can (they do not all know what they're doing, and some will judge you or make assumptions about you). The amount of doctors available is appealing but it can be hard to get someone to truly understand/ not judge you for what you're feeling.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Unfortunately the only @hole I've seen leave a 1 star rating here was named Chris G. Sounds like he is a premadonna.I on the other hand am not. The doctors at the Embarcadero facility saved my life. Literally. I fell down my stairs and they sent me to the right string of doctors due to my complaints that led to them finding a cancer that would have surely killed me if it had not been found when it was. I am alive today because of them.The ongoing care they gave me over the following two years was unparalleled in any doctors office I have ever been to.Sure UCSF/UCLA or some other massive facility would give you care if you can find an available doctor there. What you're paying for here is a guaranteed same day visit in a major metro area. It seems like a good deal to me......
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Bait and switch. Â After signing up online and paying their annual fee, I found out that no, there are no same day or even same week appointments available. Â The next available appointment is three weeks away. Â I feel awful, and will never get the hour of my life that it took to find this out, back.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Total joke. Same day appts are great, but urgent care offers the same thing... yet MUCH better provider care and knowledge level. This place is ALL fluff absolutely no substance. Unless I see someone competent, I would never go back and intend on getting my membership fee refunded. Horrible bedside manner-- and they actually have the nerve to tout differently. Ha! Marketing schtick at its most egregious.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Convenient locations, modern offices, friendly staff and doctors. I have been able to get same day appointments when needed - which is a huge plus. Â Lab / test results by email means less time waiting and much less chance of losing your records.Since I'm always on the go, this is the perfect place for me.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

The one good thing was the no wait but I was rushed out in 10 mins exact even though my appt was meant to be at least 20 mins because the doctor had somewhere else to be and on top of that the doctors there were googling answers to my medical questions - I was getting them answers by emailing other doctors I've seen in the past. Not thorough and more like the fast food of healthcare def not quality and certainly not knowledgable information - so disappointed I cancelled my membership

Reviews: I liked OMG when they were small and and 1/3 the price; however, their service has slipped and they now charge way too much for what you get. They are able to do this because they have saturated the market with their service, now it is almost impossible to find a doctor downtown unless its through OMG. I refuse to go here anymore just on principle.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Awesome. Appointment started on time, they wrote my referrals on the spot. A+
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical Group has a decent offering, but it's OVERSOLD. Real "concierge" medical practices often cost upwards of $500 a year for membership, and offers services like a doctor being on call after hours, responding to your emails, etc.One Medical claims to offer all of this for $149 (less if you have a coupon or are referred by a friend who has a coupon), with a snazzy office to boot. Surely, they're cutting corners somewhere, right?They are.Let's start with the promise of email access to my doctor. My doctor used to be a Dr. Singh at the 110 Sutter office. Over the course of my 1st year of membership, I emailed Dr. Singh 3 times. I received 1 response over that time, and it wasn't from Dr. Singh, it was from a physician assistant who works at One Medical. So strike one - you don't truly have email access to your doctor.Second - continuity of care? Dr. Singh left One Medical with exactly 1 week's notice. 1 week's notice! After being my primary care physician for 18 months, I got a mysterious email stating he was leaving One Medical at the end of the week to pursue an interest in "corporate health". Log in to the website and find another doctor... that was his advice.My prediction is that One Medical will eventually farm out everything to inexpensive PA's and nurse practitioners, and you won't be able to see a doctor. That's already pretty much the case. I since moved to a PA after Dr. Singh left, as it's hard to schedule a visit with an actual MD. Not that I don't think PA's are capable of most of what an MD does, but sometimes you want to see a doctor, and One Medical used to provide those...Nonetheless, I'm still giving them 4 stars (I'd love to give them 3.5 but that's not an option) because: a lot of other clinics in town will force you to see a PA rather than an MD (it's an industry-wide thing, you see, to save on costs), and being able to make appointments online AND request prescription renewals online is worth the $149 annual fee.Just don't buy into all the hype, because as with any other deal, if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Real concierge medicine isn't cheap, you pay for what you get.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I do love the One Medical concept and I really, really like my doctor so I am sticking with them and him, but I had a not so great experience with the billing department. Â First off, you should know that if you have a high-deductible plan and you haven't met your deductible, One Medical gives you the option to pay $100 for any standard office visit on the day of, rather than bill the insurance company, but that $100 does not count toward your deductible. Â I had a few appointments in 2013 and when I went to leave, I was not asked to pay the $100 and instead was told "okay, you're all set" so I figured they somehow changed their policy. Â Nope. Granted, I should have asked about it and admittedly I did not. Â One Medical ended up billing my insurance for 4 different office visits and a few months later I received a bill in the mail from OM for around $1,000. Â I called them to see what was up and what it boiled down to was that they sent claims to the insurance company and whatever the appointments were for weren't covered, so basically I am paying $600 ($1,000, minus the $400 for the visits) as a penalty for the inconvenience of sending claims to insurance that didn't get paid. Â I can understand charging some kind of administrative fee for the trouble, but it's pretty draconian to charge that much over the $100 pay-on-the-day option. Â  I called to complain that this cost was a little excessive so they agreed to knock down the bill a little, which was cool of them, and I agreed to pay some of it, which I did. Â At some point early in 2014, after payments had been made, I was told that the entire bill had either been waived or paid and that no further amounts were due. Â But at a recent office visit, the front desk person said I had an outstanding balance of $300 and change. Â When I told her I thought everything was settled, she said she'd check with billing. Â Billing called me today and said that the amount was due and when I said that the last conversation I had with billing ended with them saying that we were square, the response was "sorry, there's nothing we can do about it at this point but we can set up a payment plan if you'd like." Â Super annoying. Â The girl from billing was very nice about it, but I'm pretty pissed about having to fork over more money when I thought the bill was settled.So five stars for my doctor, five for the one medical experience and two stars for billing - nice people, but not so nice penalties for denied claims.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I love One Medical. I've been to two different offices in SF and both were great. I was able to make a last-minute appointment online. The office was very nice, comfortable, well designed, and they even had water and tea. :) Reception was friendly and efficient. I saw Heather, who was amazing and had me in and out in no time. One Medical makes going to the doctor a pleasant experience.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I had my first visit as a new client this past week. Â Honestly, I wasn't blown away by the service from the staff but it was prompt. Â What I liked?- It has a warn & cozy feel to it in terms of decor and style. Â You don't have a bunch of people running around in white coats/blue nurse uniforms in a cold white hospital feel. Â  Â - Sarah Maxwell was the PA-C I met with. Â She was easy to talk to and helpful. Â I hadn't gone in for checkup in over 5 years. Â  Â - They have an on-site lab (on the 2nd floor) which is convenient. Â I was able to get a blood test immediately after my appointment without a wait or appointment.Its still too early to say whether my $125/annual membership is worth it but so far I have no regrets.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've been a One Medical Group member for 2 years. Â It seems they like to keep putting me with this one P.A. whom claims to be a Woman's Specialist (didn't know a P.A. could actually have a specialty, but ok..). Â I have a PPO, and each time I've gone in to One Medical, I've walked out with this feeling like I needed a second opinion. Â It's turned out that every single time I've gotten a 2nd opinion, she's been completely wrong. Â Some redeeming qualities: Same day appointments. Superb administration and customer services. Â If you want a decent diagnosis, skip this group. Â The two redeeming qualities can't make up for a lack of ability to correctly diagnose someone.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: There are some great things about One Medical. Nice offices. Easy to get appointments. On time. Easy refills. Everyone is super friendly. Excellent practitioners of medicine? No.Their roster of MDs is super junior. Some bios don't mention board certification, which is insane. The level of turnover at the MD level is crazy high as well.Run of the mill stuff, they are mostly fine. Anything seriously wrong with you, and that is when you wished you had a relationship with a real physician practice. One of the weakest parts of One Medical is that the practitioners also seem to have terrible referral networks. I don't mean official insurance referrals; I mean a dr. knowing a roster of specialists locally who they know are good physicians and feel comfortable referring patients to. I am in a PPO, don't need referrals to see specialists, but used to ask One Medical simply because I thought they would know good doctors. I could not have been more wrong.And please don't be fooled by some of One Medical's responses here to complaints. On the issue of not having admitting privileges - that is a big deal, and being able to "work with any hospital" is NOT the same thing.As for the $150 fee, if they take your insurance, unless they have an insanely unusual agreement with a given insurance company, they actually are NOT allowed to charge the fee. They got into major trouble with Brown & Toland over it a few years ago. They are not even supposed to ask for it, and you most certainly do NOT have to pay it. The way they charge and justify the fee is super, super slimy. Lastly, I hated that practitioners would shake your hand when they greeted you in the reception area. In any other setting would be nice. In a doctors office full of sick people? Gross. Who knows what sick people that hand has touched.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: It was like a scene from a horror film. In the shower, blood splattered EVERYWHERE. Except instead of being stabbed to death, the source of all the blood was my nose. Yes, projectile bleeding at its best. It was getting EVERYWHERE [No exaggeration, but I have no pictures to prove this...], and I was trying to clean as I bled to my near-death, naked in the shower...I hadn't experienced anything CLOSE to this since '98 in Brussels when I had to stand over the hotel room sink while my nose ran like a leaky faucet. The bleeding only stopped after we ran down to the bar downstairs to ask for some ice. That, and I was probably low on blood by then!You want to scare the shit out me? Well, this would do it. Would I not live to see week two of 2008?! Would I collapse in a pool of blood with the shower running above and blood-splattered walls around me? Would CSI realize that I hadn't been murdered and that I had instead died from a very bad nosebleed? For a moment, I thought I should perhaps write "NOSE" on the wall - a final bloody clue to the mysterious death of moi. It was barely clotting when I was able to hop out of the shower, conditioner still in my hair, trying desperately to keep pressure on the nose. Scary. Luckily, the bleeding stopped after about two hours of applying pressure and just sitting there. Very carefully, I washed the conditioner out and grabbed some lunch too. To be on the safe side, I emailed MMG with a brief description of my "problem." I had signed up in October after reading Cherie's review of one of the doctors there and had not actually made an appointment yet. Within minutes of sending my email, I received a response. I could possibly be squeezed in for an appointment in the same afternoon! While I chose not to go in on the same day, imagine my relief when I got such a prompt response.
