Â I tried to pick another medical group other than Brown & Toland, but as I mentioned, Hill Group ALSO contracts to One Medical. Â I must dig deeper.If and when we ever get a universal or near universal care, where everyone gets equal care, less hassle, higher taxes, and fewer corporations with their hands in the cookie jar, it will be near utopian. Â Until then, it pays to find a simpler solution. Â And apparently it doesn't pay $150.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I had taken my boyfriend to Dr Clothier, and we were given no answers. Something was clearly wrong with him, and no referrals, no tests, no advice (except to say he had a sore throat). The same did not happen at One Medical. It was a superb experience from start to finish. We got a same day appointment with nurse practitioner, Pferdehirt and she was so helpful in giving a thorough examination and a referral for an x ray. I can't tell you how grateful I am that we discovered One Medical Group.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've been a patient off and on for a few years. Â When I first joined I loved the service, but a year later I had a misdiagnosis and ended up in the ER for several hours. Â I left the practice for a year and came back because of their location and decided I would use a different doctor. Â Recently another major mishap happened that also had me ending up in the ER. Â I'm in good shape and in my early 30's, so for this to happen is crazy. Â I currently have a complaint filed against them with the medical review board.My other major issues with One Medical are there lack of professional service. Â I think the front desk people are nice, but thats about it. Â I needed a same day appointment and had to wait 2 days. Â Never once were the normal check in tests (weight, blood pressure, etc.) performed. Â This company is really focused on getting as many people in and out during the day as possible. Â  No personalized attention or follow up.You would think after the issues that were caused by my last visit that someone from One Medical would call to check in, but not a call from anyone.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My daughter and her husband told us about this wonderful medical practice and encouraged us to check it out. I had been having a horrible time with my insurance company in trying to get them to approve a hip replacement for me. Â After the third time my surgery Â was "canceled" at the last minute because the insurance companies kept blaming each other for not approving the procedure...I had just about had it with all things medical. Â After inquiring about the practice and the insurance they took...we signed up. Â It has been nothing less than spectacular! Â Same day appointments...30 minutes minimum one - on -one time with the Doctor! Â They really have your interests in mind. Â My Physician's Assistant sat with me and patiently took down all my gripes and complaints and then referred me to an orthopedic practice that would take my insurance. Â They double-checked everything and I've now got an appointment that should not be canceled. The nominal yearly fee is so worth it...we come from the East Bay and it's a quick BART ride and a very short walk to the office. All in all..a great way to see the Doc!!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I was assigned to a doctor at one medical group as my primary care physician through my HMO. Â Turns out, the doctor is not taking any new patients so I had to see a different doctor a part of the medical group.Initially calling the office to schedule my first appointment, the women on the phone explained to me that there is an annual $150 membership fee. Â I thought this was outrageous but after telling me that she understands I have health insurance and I can opt out of paying for the fee based on a waiver form online. Which I went ahead and filled out right away.On my first appointment, I checked in with the receptionist. Â The first words to come out of her mouth was "It looks like you are due to pay our $150 annual membership" Â And I explained to her that it was my first appointment, which she totally disregarded. Â I also told her about the waiver form which she also acted like she had no idea what I was talking about. Â then I showed her my email "Your waiver request has been processed. Should your situation change and you opt to pay our membership fee, simply go to your account at onemedical.md/pt/otp/bilâ¦ and enter your payment information." Â After seeing that she says, well it's being processed and not necessarily approved. Â Then I was called into my doctors visit. Â I did not feel like doctor I saw paid any special attention to me at all. Â Leaving, she also forgot to prescribe me medication I asked for during the visit. Â I also explained to her about areas that had discomfort. Â Instead of actually looking at the area, she just ordered more labs. Â Yes, she got the most important thing that I needed to visit the doctor for done, but a thorough doctor and so they say they have "fresh new approach" that I also did not experience.After my doctors appointment, and checking out with the front desk. Â I spent another 5 minutes talking to the front desk again about the $150. Â She kept tryng to explain that the $150 helps maintain their facility and provide me with services that other offices do not, for ex, same day appointments, emails, online appointments, and online prescription renewals. Â And she said to me, just because I have health insurance does not mean I don't have to pay for it. Â Well, why would I have health insurance then??? And also, my last doctor who was amazing and I can no longer see, also, emailed me, provided me with same day appointments, and called the pharmacy for me to renew my prescription. I feel as though they should not state its an "optional" membership fee, because clearly it is not. Â In the end, the receptionist unhappily waived my fee but said, at any moment you can pay for it please do. Â And we will be asking you for the membership fee in one year.I felt forced to pay a membership fee I didn't feel like I needed to pay. Â I also feel as though I was not provided with the care that everyone else describes. Â Perhaps I need to visit a different doctor here. Overall, a stressful experience, and oh, that extra 5 min made me 5 min over the 1 hr parking, which bumped me up to $6 for parking at the sutter parking lot.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Update: a very helpful person from the back office called me after my insurance company contacted them and demanded immediate reimbursement for me. She refunded me the visit fee, which was due to me. She also refunded me the annual membership charge and offered to keep my membership open should I want to come back for another visit. I really do appreciate this effort on their part, but they should get their billing system under control. Hopefully I will return to the office for a great visit. I will post an update when I do.I joined One Medical late last year because I loved the idea of making appointments online and the convenience of multiple locations. I paid the membership fee of $149 and the fee for my initial visit, $150, which I found reasonable. They also did me the curtesy of billing my insurance. Now it appears that my insurance also paid them $172 for the visit. I just happened to notice this when reviewing my EOBs. I called the office to inquire if this an overpayment. The person who answered the phone said he would look into my inquiry, and contact the billing department and get back to me. Six days later, I call back to ask what is going on. The receptionist checks with the person who handled my original call and says that "he is on top of it" and that he hasn't heard from the billing department, but as soon as he does, he will call me back. I ask when I can expect a call back. She tells me that refunds can take up to two to three weeks. I say, "yes, I understand this, but when will he call me back to tell me how this has been resolved?" She says that it could take a couple of days, she's not really sure. I interrupt her to tell her that I want a date, so that if I don't hear back from him, I will call them again. I suggest a couple of days, and she picks the furthest one out. At the end of the conversation, she makes a grunt of some kind and hangs up the phone, without thanking me or saying goodbye. This kind of treatment, although quite insignificant in the grand scheme of things, just put me in a bad mood. I suppose I will call Blue Shield and work from that angle, as they are always very helpful. Oh, and while I'm bitching, the doctor I saw knew nothing about acupuncture. I had just assumed that the doctors would at least know when it was appropriate to refer a patient to an acupuncturist. So if you are looking for a practice that is integrated with western and eastern medicine, this is not the place.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: First impression is the most important... I set up an appointment one week in advance with Dr.Wu. at 3:30PM. I arrived at 3:00PM and I was asked by the front desk to register on-line.. 3:15 PM.. Registration was done... 3:30PM.. nothing 3:50 PM.. Dr. Wu comes and greets another patient... What about me????? The front desk forgot to check me in the computer. The dumb person claimed that there was a bug in the computer and wanted me to take another day off to see the doctor(I came from East bay). The manager claimed that the front desk forgot to checked me in because she was confused that I was not registered, so...So... The bug was in fact a problem between the keyboard and the chair..not the computer.. Dr. Wu refused to see me after the other patient...Claiming that the next appointment would be too late...Think she's going to try to make it up? No.. Just take another appointment!!! I guess that's fair to think that a patient.. that's just a piece of meat that will be ready to take a day off and pay for a pricey parking in SF to see her Majesty the Doctor...So.. Dealing with a bunch amateurs... No thank you. I'm stuck with this bunch of morxns for at least a month before I can switch.Oh BTW.. You pay a fee and think that you can see any doctor right away? Dream on... This is false advertising.. Unless if your you.. right now.. that means in 3 days... So.. if you're looking for an appointment for next week..Come back next year!!!!Dr. Wu : ZERO starsFront Desk : MINUS 500 STARS
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: A plus for online appointment scheduling. Â One Medical is ok if you have a cold or hangnail but that is about it. Â I wanted to see a doctor for a somewhat what I thought was a serious issue, I got a NP. Â If I have to pay $150.00 Â year just to be a 'member' and then my copays, I want a doctor not a medical school dropout. Â As my review states if you have a cold or hangnail this place is fine but don't let them manage a more serious issue. Â They don't have the resources.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: It's a blessing that I can come here with my insurance. The e-mail access to your doctor- how 21st century! Also, when I had an emergency late night, I called and it directly paged my doctor, and she called back within 5 minutes. I like the feeling of integrative medicine, but they definitely have the more clinical doctors if you want that.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Not only was my doctor so clearly disinterested and going through motions, their billing dept is a mess. One Medical sent me a bill for my first visit. So I called One Med and they claimed - this had nothing to do with them, not their job. Â So I called the billing office. They refereed me back to One Medical office. There a guy, Harley, sounded so bored and that I was really taking him away from his clock watching... Â but he said to me, the charge Â probably was some co-pay. I insisted it was a mistake. Well, sure enough... two days later I get a call. It WAS Â a mistake. Whoopsie. How many are billed and just pay it? It's not a huge sum, $22.35 - but if they do that to a few hundred folks that pay it... Â adds up. This took my time and energy. Â They just say - whoopsie. CHECK YOUR BILLS WITH THEM VERY CAREFULLY! I find their staff trying to MAKE you feel they care. But they are all very green - and I dont mean eco- friendly green.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Well, they just lost me as a customer. I tried to book a same day appointment and was given one time slot option. I explained that due to my busy schedule that time would not work but instead gave them a two hour window in the afternoon when I would be available. Their answer "Sorry, all of our providers are booked." What's the point in paying an extra $150/yr on top my copay if they can't accommodate same day appointments for folks with busy schedules . . . . especially when the first bullet point on their website is: - Same-day appointments to fit your busy scheduleRather, maybe it should read:- Same-day appointments to fit OUR busy schedule
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I am losing all patience with One Medical. Â My husband and I are their exact demographic - young professionals who are relatively healthy and just looking for convenience. Â But One Medical has gone utterly downhill of late, so much so that I plan on cancelling my membership after I finish my current slate of vaccinations. Â All we wanted to do was get our immunizations done - my husband so he can get complete his green card application - and me in anticipation of potentially changing employers/insurers and thinking ahead to the possibility of getting pregnant. Â Call after call, they just can't get it done. Â My husband is on the phone with Jennifer right now and she is telling him that he has to get a blood draw first, which makes no sense at all, since he needs a documented MMR so the civil surgeon can sign off on his I-693. Â I've been going back and forth with them on the vaccinations that I need, and they keep insisting that I've probably had immunizations as a child that I know that I haven't. Â You'd think this would be the easiest thing in the world to do - just put an order in and we'll drop by their lab - but they make this the most unproductive exercise imaginable. Â I'm basically done with them.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Finally! This model works! One Medical has beautiful offices, extremely peppy receptionists, and is very customer service oriented. When I needed lab services, I was able to have them done on-site, immediately after my appointment. I received my lab results via email as soon as they were ready. Online appointment scheduling is very convenient. I love having access to naturopaths and acupuncturists alongside my regular physician. PS. they all work together and have access to your records (online!) so everyone who sees you is on the same page. So happy I found this place. I would pay three times the membership fee if I had to.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: First, they told me that the $99 would be covered by my flex spending so at least it would really only be like $65 in real dollars in my life. Â Not the case. Flex dollars will not pay this.Second, they told me they were worth it because I would never have to wait. I figure ok, fine. I have a certain number of hours I have to bill. They translate into a certain number of dollars to me, so it is going to save me time, which = $, to not have to wait. And then I get there and I wait. Over ten minutes. Usually I would not in the least mind waiting ten minutes. But when you just persuaded me to pay you $100 because I wouldnt have to wait, don't make me wait. Really. At least THIS time since you promised me that YESTERDAY.Later in the year. Their docs are useless. I find a specialist on my own. He is amazing and saving my life, renewing my will to live. I ask them to at least try referring me to him. Â You know, in case my stupid insurance would cover it. They wouldn't even try. Now, I bet it would not have mattered. But, really, I just paid you $100 for the pleasure of your services and you couldn't do what I needed and now you won't even refer me to this impressively credentialed MD at USF? Thanks. Thanks. So, one day, I asked the doctor why she became a DO instead of an MD. She basically said because it was easier to get in to school. No passion for alternative health care. No belief that maybe drugs arent the best answer. Just easier to get that degree. Great!So then as my year of disappointment comes to an end they send me a message about renewing my membership- this time for $149. I write back and say, in sum, hell no, don't you dare charge my cc. They charge my cc. I work it out, but the time it takes certainly eats away at any claim that they could make that they offer such efficient service.So, if you've got $100 sitting around to blow on the same old piss poor healthcare you get anywhere, go for it. At least you don't have to leave the building.Addendum: as *soon* as I posted this, I was contacted by the owner wanting to make things better. That would have been nice 6 months ago when I was trying to deal with the crap service. I am glad Yelp provides a forum for our voices to be heard outside of whatever feedback channels a business provides us. But, I have read the reviews on here and I think he does this all the time. That is nice and all. But then people change their reviews. So, their overall score looks decent. But if you are considering using their services, you aren't getting an honest assessment of what you are going to encounter. What you are getting is an assessment of what you will get if you bitch and moan on Yelp. No thanks. I was wiling to pay for what you told me I would get. How do you make us feel like you are worth it? Follow through instead of tending to the squeaky wheel- after the squeaky wheel has abandoned the wagon for a new wagon.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I have been going here for a few months now and can really notice the difference. I enjoy that I see the doctor without having to wait for nurses and the doctor is with me from the time I start the visit until I leave. I really appreciate that. I can't even tell you how much I hate waiting for a nurse, talking to a nurse, talking to a dr, then the dr leaves and I don't know what happened. Â I really think it's worth the extra money per year.That being said....DO NOT ALLOW JENNIE COSSMAN TO EVEN SPEAK TO YOU. She won't pay attention to what you are telling her your symptoms are and will simply tell you how you feel. I went in crying because I was so upset about not feeling good that instead of even looking at me, she tells me I need a shrink. I tell her that is not my problem and she tells me I don't know what I feel. She even started yelling at me to tell me how depressed she thought I was. In the end, I was having a weird reaction to my birth control. I stopped taking it and the problem went away. Of course I wasn't depressed and I knew that. She was unhelpful, unprofessional and I will never allow her to see me again. Arnold Lee is the best! He is the nicest. So see him!!!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: 3.5 stars. Pros: Convenient to make appointments as it's easy to reach a real person (previously I went to Kaiser, which I reviewed). Another convenient feature: Being able to email your doctor is genius. I always procrastinate going to the doctor's office, and now with email access, perhaps one seldom has to go.  I really like my doctor -- she's kind and helpful and communicative. Even though my questions are sometimes more suitable for specialists, she's been great at giving me a second opinion. She's very good at noticing unexpected things: giving me a useful sheet for iron deficiency healthcastle.com/iron.shâ¦ and proactively testing me for ferritin and vitamin D. Plus she's so personable and nice that it makes the whole experience of having to go to the doctor's office very pleasant. Cons: Lack of preventing testing. Regular blood tests that I get at Kaiser, e.g. for cholesterol and blood sugar, are hard to get here. I had to argue to get these tests this year, and I don't know whether I can successfully get them next time. (My blood sugar is greater than 90 and LDL is greater than 95, which are not exactly low.) I'm happy to pay for these tests if my insurance doesn't, but it does, and that doesn't seem to be the issue. Judging from other reviews of people with similar complaints of their doctors not approving cholesterol tests, this is endemic to One Medical. Perhaps One Medical has lower standards for cholesterol? (My doctor said my LDL is excellent... My friend's cholesterol is 215, he has high blood pressure, and his doctor at One Medical is not worried.) This makes Kaiser look good in comparison -- Kaiser is very good at preventive care (took an excellent back care class there).Still it is convenient and I really like my doctor -- hopefully I'll remain healthy and don't need tests so I'm staying for now.Update 07.12.2010: Dr. Thomas Lee, the owner of One Medical Group, contacted me and said that getting preventive testing is not a problem. I appreciate his message and hopefully upon future visits can push the rating up to where it should be: 5 stars.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: i guess i joined a little late as i am getting charged $150/year membership fee instead of the $100, but i feel that over a course of 12 months, that's $12.50/month, which i think is perfectly acceptable for the service.i called in and i was about to schedule an appointment any time i wanted to -- not a month from today. Â not only, i really like the web based system they have. Â i submit all my information on line (which is neater and faster than filling out paperwork by hand) and the doctor sends in my prescription on line (fast and easy, right?). Â but wait -- the BEST part about this is that there is zero wait time! Â i went in here today and didn't have to wait to see my doctor. Â i went in for a general check-up/physical (as a first time patient here), and i was in and out in exactly 30 minutes. Â how great is that?
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Finally, what a relief to find such amazing doctors in this city! After living here for 3 years I have had some terrifying and terrible experiences with all kinds of General Hospital and doctors. Well, not here. Here they care, listen and actually want to find out what the problem is, they look at everything not just handing you a perscription after 5 seconds and hoping that will fix it. No, here the Dr's (Dr. Weiss) listen and look at everything. I will miss them and thank you for finally giving me a great Dr- patient experience.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I like that you can get a fast appointment here if need be, but the Dr. I'm seeing I didn't feel gave me the best care, especially since you have to pay $100 extra just to be a patient here. Â I'll also say I had blood drawn here and have never had a more painful experience. Â Not sure if the guy was new, but nonetheless, super painful. Â He blamed it on the rubbing alcohol, which has always been used any time I donated/gave blood, so I'm a little doubtful and which he would have just said sorry. Â May search for a new place to go.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Modifying my review as the business owner reached out to me directly to work on resolving the billing problem with Apollo Medical Group. Will update again once it is actually resolved.In the meantime, as originally stated, I've been very happy with the service provided by the doctors, the business model, and facilities. A noticeable difference (positive) from most doctor's offices and visits.Keep up the good work...
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I just paid $350 out of pocket for a 15 minute appointment to put ear drops in my ear! Â Could have bought them at Walgreens! Â I'm currently looking for a new doctor since I can't afford this one!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: First of all - GO HERE. Â These guys are great, they really, really care about you, and most of all, especially for busy, young professionals, they get it. Â The coolest doctors I've ever had. Â These guys would get a five, except that in the last year they increased their annual fee 50% (to $150), but at the same time, have not been able to give me a same day appointment (which is their big selling point) the last 3 times I tried. Â THAT SAID, when I complained about this they immediately responded with a personal e-mail and even offered to let me come in that day if I still needed care!!! Â AWESOME. Â Also, they are expanding and adding another office and more doctors, so they can hopefully reach equilibrium soon. Â I think part of the problem is that they have become so popular, so quickly it's just a supply and demand issue...and supply is supposedly on the rise.You can usually get an appointment within the next day or two (even if it is with an R.N. -- though their RNs are pretty darn good). Â And their appointments are LONG! Â So awesome. Â I have never ever felt rushed out of there. Â The full doctors are ridiculously smart and attentive. Â Dr. Miko is super cool, too. Â My only gripe with him is that he sent me to Financial District Foot and Ankle which is a total money-making racket that has the worst customer service ever.Also, the same day appointment thing really only works if you are flexible, too (i.e. don't demand a same day appointment if your foot hurts; save it for the flu and other acute pain and symptoms, so you don't squeeze others out). Â For instance, I had knee issues during the Swine Flu epidemic...I was okay with having to wait 2 days for an appointment.But all-in-all one of the nicest group of folks, very modern, very worth the $100 (damn...now $150 a year).
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I cannot say enough good things about this group. Â My co-worker convinced me to go 2 years ago when I was at work downtown, sick, and my doctor at UCSF could not see me for 2 weeks. Â I love the convenience of all the locations downtown and the same day appointments. Â But I also love that my doctor takes the time to get to know me Â - on my first visit, I went in and instinctively sat on the examination table. Â My doctor came in and immediately invited me to sit a the desk and have a conversation about my medical history, what I was in for today, etc. Â So much more humane and personal! Â I email my doctor on weekends when things come up and she gets back to me in a matter of hours. Â The $150 annual fee more than pays for itself in attention, care, and responsiveness.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Adding the star back...when I posted my comment about the fee, I was quickly contacted and the situation was remedied.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Dr. Margit Dijkstra was great - very attentive and friendly. Â Offered medical and non-medical suggestions to my various ailments. I felt satisfied that she gave me sufficient time for the visit, and asked if she had answered all my questions/concerns.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I just wanted to update this because One Medical Group wrote an e-mail to me when they saw my review. They told me to call the number again to inquire my money back. This time some one did pick up and I got my money (annual membership fee) back!! Unfortunately my favorite primary physician Carrie Bowler left One Medical. I hope my new physician from One Medical is as awesome as Carrie!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This is long overdue. One Medical has been incredible since my first visit last August. Dr. Singh takes his time, is patient, listens to what you're saying before even completing an examination, and is just a plain old nice guy. Plus, he has been responsive to email, getting back to me within 24 hours.A few months ago, I started a new position and had some kind of virus that left me immobile - 101 fever, headache, cold symptoms... I had to call out three days in my first week of work, which I was mortified by. I called One Medical and was put on the phone with someone to determine whether a visit was necessary. Since my symptoms sounded like a virus, they suggested I stay home and get some rest and offered to write me a letter stating that I consulted them and that since I've started seeing them, I've generally been in good health. It was nice to be able to go back to work with a note saying I'm not a dud!In the past, I've dreaded making doctor's appointments, and have taken half days at work knowing that I'd be in a waiting room for an extended period of time. I know that going to One Medical, I'll be in within a few minutes of my appt time and on my way (back to work, unfortunately!).
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This is by far the best doctor's office I have ever been to. Â I love having email access to all the doctors. Â And once they get to know you they will fill prescriptions based on an email exchange. Â The office is well designed, and you feel like you are a customer, not an object to be herded and poked at. Â  Â Well worth the $99 per year to join.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: They doctors are amazing and you can always get an appointment. As someone with asthma who is frequently sick, this is a great group. The $99 for the year is worth it to know you are getting a group of reliable, well trained, friendly doctors. Plus the practice location office is really nice and clean.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One medical is an amazing group. They always help me out and the e-mail access to my medical provider is invaluable. No more frustrating long phone calls, holding for the right nurse, and long waits for urgent appointments. I walk right over from work / before work for my appointments or lab work. I can call in and talk to someone about my medical needs and get a fast response and efficient follow up. I was impressed with my recent request for mail ordering my prescriptions. I recommend them to my friends. The fee is nominal for the great service I get. Great job guys, keep it up.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: -RIDICULOUSLY easy to get an appointment-friendly front desk-non judgmental practitioners (you know how some doctors can be passive aggressive, they are not!)-option to book short 10 minute appointments so you can pretty much squeeze yourself in practically whenever you want-online appointment booking-email access to doctor-online RX request ... actually almost everything being online-OB/GYN and general physician under the same roof? check!... you do have to pay that membership fee though, and i'm not sure it is worth it. i don't know, once i grew out of my pediatrician (which i am still cursing age for...) i wasn't able to/too lazy to find a good doctor who vibed with me. i'm sure if i looked harder i would have found someone, but i dont even go that often to the doctor so that would have taken YEARS.... they send your RX via computer to whichever pharmacy you designate, which kind of stresses me out cause i dont know when i'll be going by a certain walgreens. i miss old school paper RXs cause then i had the freedom to go to whichever walgreens i happened to walk by.overall, good experience every time i go, but the biggest most notable plus is the appointment availability all the time.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I had a horrible experience at OneMedical. For the most basic primary care that requires just a nurse, it is fine. If you any remotely complicated issue - from a persistent cold to a concussion to a gynecological appt - it is terrible. For one, you wait just as long to see as a doctor than at any other practice - sometimes longer because OneMedical doesn't have many MDs relative to patients. Even worse, they will always push you to see an RN even when the issue is more complicated and the doctor knows more. And their care model means you don't talk to one provider consistently. I would write them about issues and get an email back from a different nurse every time. I would have to re-explain everything to them each time, and would get different advice. They only gave a cursory look at my chart. Also, if you ask for a longer appt with a doctor, they wills till book you for half an hour and force you to make a separate appointment, wasting your time.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: The annual membership fee that my husband and I pay to belong to One Medical is the best investment we make every year. We both work full time and don't have the time or patience to deal with doctors who can't take us when we really need it or who make us wait forever when we come in for an appointment. The entire staff here is great. All friendly, competent and fast. I love that all of their records are kept electronically and that they email prescriptions directly to my pharmacy. (I'm the queen of dropping paper prescriptions in my purse only to find them a few days later crumpled at the bottom next to my old Muni transfers and receipts.) Plus, when I do have something weird going on and I'm not sure if I need to go in, I can email my doctor or NP to get their opinion for no additional cost.A+ all around.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: This is the best medical care I've received in a long time. Â The way the clinic functions fits my life-style: Â pre-register online; same-day appointments; e-mail me with test results; fax prescriptions to my local pharmacy. Â There is a $99 per year membership fee, but very worth it. Â The atmosphere is inviting (almost spa-like!), and the doctors and nurse practitioners are nice. Â I am definitely staying with them.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My first experience with this medical group couldn't have been more satisfactory. Almost everything at this office (the one exception being the lack of parking!) -- from the unusually pleasant office settings, cordial and knowledgable receptionist and, of course, my physician Dr. Alex Chan, couldn't have been more satisfactory. If this is what a $150 / year membership fee brings; I can't believe that more medical groups in this country are not offering similar health care support services for a society that is so sadly lacking such support. Whether or not you are already a member of another health care system, do yourself a favor and give this group a try. You won't regret it. - Peter L. Hoag, Ph.D.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Best western medicine focused doctors office I've ever been to. Â They also have naturopaths, bloodwork, and accupuncture on site and bill your HMO directly, plus you can email and call your doctor. Â Simply excellent.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Totally worth the annual fee for easy appointments, friendly staff, lots of time with doctors and email access.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I literally cannot say enough good things about O.M.G. I know it is $150 a year, but for hypochondriacs like me, that is nothing. Same day appointments, high tech communication amongst staff, and friendly doctors who know what they are talking about. Love it!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I just can't say enough good things about One Medical Group. Â Through word of mouth I heard about them at the beginning of this year. Â Historically I have always had very poor experiences with health care. Â Scheduling hassles, difficulties being "in sync" with the doctor/staff and building a credible relationship, etc.One Medical Group is amazing for numerous reasons:1. Online scheduling is a breeze. Â I can schedule a new appointment in a minute.2. Same day appointments. Â They run their practice so efficient that you can get same day appointments.3. Time efficient. Â They are always on time and respect your time. Â You feel guilty if you're a minute late.4. Genuine care. Â They doctors truly listen to you, solicit your feedback, ask for your input on the treatment plan, etc.5. Efficient uses of resources. Â While meeting with the doctor, they'll have a laptop out, do Google searches, access other info, show you the results, IM their assistants and other doctors to help accelerate things, etc. Â All while listening to you. Â It feels like a team effort.6. Email. Â You can have meaningful dialogue and follow-up with your doctor via email. Â They take the time to summarize things. Â They are extremely responsive. Â Incredible!I highly recommend One Medical Group.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Yes, there is the annual fee, which I hate paying when I am poor and also paying for an individual private plan... but with the state of the health care system in this country, I would rather be safe (and slightly poorer) than sorry (/bankrupt). The same-day appts are great, as is the email access. And I've felt like I was in good hands with the various physicians I have visited here. If they take your insurance plan and you are willing to pay the annual fee, definitely check this place out, much better than dealing with the bureaucrats.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Best medical practice I have ever been too. Â The entire staff is professional yet friendly. Â Have never had to wait more than 5 minutes past appointment time. Â And best of all they will communicate with you via email. Â Don't let the small annual fee scare you...they are more than worth every dollar in saved time and peace of mind.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I am so very thankful for One Medical Group! Â I have been sick for almost 3 weeks and my doctor decided to drop my insurance apparently as of Aug 1 (unbeknownst to me - yeah, would have been nice to have gotten a letter about that...) so when I had to get in to a doctor quickly - One Medical Group was there. Â And not only did I get a same day appointment, for the first time in my adult life I got true kindness when I went to see a medical doctor. Â I was heard, I wasn't kept waiting for 20 minutes to be seen, and today - she followed up with me to see how I was doing! Â Yes, it costs $149.00 a year to join, but this is such a nominal price for what you get including but not limited to the convenience of same day appointments, the many different locations they have available and the empathetic care you receive. Â Being treated like a human being, customer service, wow - I never thought I was the cynical type but I almost can't believe this place is for real. Â I am however eternally grateful it is.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: 2 stars only because I've had good experiences with Carrie Bowler and Angela Powlen at the Sutter St. location in the past. They seemed genuinely caring and competent. The rest of the experiences I've had there would receive 0 stars if I could.I've been with One Medical Group since it was Metropolitan Medical Group (3-4 years). I used to be really impressed with their service (Angela, Carrie), but it has become way too evident that the group has shifted their focus from same-day quality patient care to becoming a cash-generating operation looking out for the insurance companies' best interests. I am dropping them and filing a formal complaint.Without getting into a long description of all the ways they've jeopardized my health for their own financial gain in the past year, I'll just say that I've had several doctors in private practice tell me that this place can't be trusted for anything more than prescription refills and rash diagnoses...and I wouldn't even recommend them for the latter. I went in with what turned out to be just an allergic skin reaction to the metal rivets in my jean pockets (think of where your back pockets are) and had the nurse tell me I had herpes!!...I won't share my other two stories (the real reason I will never go back) since they're even more personal than that one, but when I went for second opinions in the other two instances, the new doctors I saw were appalled at what I had been told by the doctors at One Medical Group. One muttered "One Medical Group" while shaking her head and told me she knew they were just trying to make money off more appointments and that I had been flat-out lied to (her words). Another doctor said One Medical Group was more concerned about the insurance system and told me to get them to sign a form taking responsibility for my health outcome if they still wouldn't prescribe the necessary MRI they denied me. Anyway, if you feel like paying $150/yr to have a doctor do something they would already do for no extra charge (fill prescriptions and answer questions), then sign up with One Medical Group. If you need a real diagnosis that isn't dependent on whether or not they can bill it easily, or if it will hurt Â their standing with an insurance company, then come on Yelp and find a doctor who gives a s#!t.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Been a "privileged" member for 3+ years. Â I am always blown away by the "Doogie Howser" element of Dr's there. Â None of them have hospital rights or appear on my insurance as a PCP. Â Called my Doc last Sunday about 5 days of lower ab pain. Â He said "take a bowel break" if not better in am get in to see someone at any office. Â Monday I called and they squeezed me in at another office with a Dr. (looked 30). Â She examines me and presses on right side and I yelped. Â She says "well, you don't have a fever take a bowel rest for 2 days". Â Went to ER next morning, they did a scan and I had to have emergency appendix surgery right then as it was starting to burst. Â Most of the Dr's here are posers and dangerous. Â I'm outta here after I report them to my insurance company!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My one-star review was not an easy decision to make: It was a very easy decision to make.My caveat is that this review is not reflective of the quality of care provided by Metropolitan Medical Group; this review reflects my overall experience and the way in which the group is administered.That said, on to the review:First, let it be known that one star is for the ease of which you can get an appointment. You can call and more than likely someone will see you today. Wonderful! The downfall: I have been three times and have yet to see the same person. Of course, the above is dependent on being able to get through the phone lines. (I got the impression from the site that I would be able to schedule appointments electronically. Signing into my account affords no such options--at least that I can find.) While staff members are nice (plus one star), the group appears to be grossly understaffed (minus one star). The floor plan for the Sutter office (the remodeled one even) requires you to either wait in line right by the elevator or to take a seat and then try to sort of out who is next as there is only one person to take calls and admit people. I had a question about billing and was directed to someone outside the office. I left a message, but felt uncomfortable giving too much of my information as the answering machine to this random number appeared to be something run out of someone's home. While I am not concerned about the billing department's competency (OK, I'm a little concerned; I've been through three times and have yet to see any sort of bill or be asked for a copayment), it just all felt a little less than professional--or at least outside of my usual medical group experience.Last--but definitely not least as this one is the worst offender--is the lab. You will be asked to go off-site to go to the lab. OK, so this is not ideal. I'm used to being in the same building for both my clinician and lab services, but fine, I'm healthy and able-bodied (what do people who aren't do?) so I can walk the four blocks. But then you get to the lab and it's this strange set up where if no one is at the desk, it's not quite clear what you are supposed to do outside of writing your full name on a pad (which in itself seems odd as far as confidentiality--again maybe this is strange because I'm used to writing down, say, just my last name). In fact, I'm not sure privacy is a huge concern for them as any sort of urine test requires you to WALK DOWN THE HALL to use the building's floor bathroom. The walk to the bathroom, while strange, is not so bad as the walk back to the lab, during which time you have a huge sharps receptacle in one-hand (it's their keychain) and YOUR URINE in the other as you walk past the elevator bank and some other businesses and their patrons. OK, maybe the most offensive part isn't parading around with my own urine. Maybe it's the $75 you pay for the above privileges. I did it out of desperation (needed to have a prescription filled after changing plans and after two hours of calling I still couldn't find another group accepting new patients). Yeah, the $75 may be the worst part.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Not really following through with their promises of same day appointments. Â More like ten days out; a significantly longer delay than what I was accustomed to with my previous primary care practice; for which, by the way, I didn't have to pay $149/year. Â On the positive side, their telephone customer service is really fantastic, even if the agents aren't able to schedule appointments in a timely manner. Â Too bad, because I really like the concept of One Medical Group. Â Execution leaves something to be desired.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: BEST medical care I have ever received. Established my PCP (Dr. Kim) here a few weeks ago and can't stop raving about my experiences thus far. Firstly, you can fill out all of your medical history online before heading to the office. The staff is friendly and helpful. Very progressive doctors. My new doc is helping me take a supplemental approach to my health and has also suggested alternative remedies for the ailments one would normally "pop a pill" for. After my first visit I received a personal e-mail from my doctor outlining EVERYthing we discussed including some helpful attachments with info on general healthy eating habits for my age, stress relief tips and tricks (breathing exercises), etc. The best part is...same day appointments! And I love the ability to e-mail the doctor with any questions you might have. I've already had a question and received a reply directly from my doctor within 48 hours! AMAZING. I highly recommend joining One Medical. The annual fee is totally worth it.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I used to have a great Doctor who seemed to know everything about everything. Â Unfortunately my insurance switched and I came here thinking at least I can get same day appointments very easily. Â Yes that's abou thte only convenience about this place. Â Everytime I go I see a random Doctor which feels very odd. Â I get to reexplain all kinds of details. Â I also feel like a lot of the Doctors there seem a little phony, they seem like they are looking all answers for everything online. Â They also respond faster to email than phone which just seems a little cold to me. Â  After going here for about 2 years I think I'm going to start looking for someone who has they're own small practise who actually seems to care I'm really starting to feel like it's the Walmart/McDonalds of healthcare and i'm tired of being treated like I'm a 5 year old child everytime I go in. Â In addition to them not being able to even start me with samples of an antibiotic as I was too broke I was told to simply go to the ER if I feel worse cause they will just bill me later since I have no money now
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I joined here almost 1 year ago and am really impressed. Â The concept is awesome and is much better than traditional doctor offices. Â The fee is very reasonable and really simplifies things if you have a PPO plan like me. Â Instead of browsing through countless lists of doctors, I go to one centralized place (similar to an HMO facility) and get all the treatment I need. Â If you need something they cannot offer in-house, they will give you several quality referrals. Â They also offer holistic services that you wouldn't normally receive at a regular facility. Â The office is nice and the staff are very courteous and professional. Â The only reason they don't get 5 stars is that it may take longer to get an appointment with someone you want to see then what their website promises (but not by much). Â All in all, I love this model of doing business and I think they do it quite well. Â Make the switch now!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I was referred to the Metropolitan Medical group by a coworker and I like it. I have gone twice and they were able to get me in with the same PA. I scheduled the first one a week ahead and the other same day. Filling out the on-line form helped speed things along for my annual Physical and Pap exam. One drawback is that the lab is located at a different facility (450 Sutter), but my test results came back pretty fast. I happened to be in my PA's office 2 days after my visit to the lab for a followup appt and she was able to give me my results and then emailed them to me. I have been able to communicate via email with my PA and she is very good about following with me. I paid $99 for the annual fee in February; however, another coworker just joined in March and the fees have gone up to $150.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: They have become too big and the service is rushed. I never see an actual doctor, so you never really build a relationship with anyone. I asked for a refill of Vicodin (which they had prescribed to me) now in my entire life I have taken painkillers 3 times and I am Â 50 years old. They refused to refill unless I came in and they wanted me to see any doctor, this was just so they could profit. I know several co-workers that have left as well. About the membership fee, my insurance company told me it is illegal in the state of California to do this and in all fairness One Medical will waive it if you ask if you cannot afford. Â I know a friend she was on Methadone for PAIN not for Heroin addiction and they treated her like a junkie and she left after being a patient/member for over 7 years and they are the ones that sent/referrred her to the pain specialist that put her on the Methadone! Very sad as she will have this on her medical record the rest of her life.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical Group = OMG! Â I travel a lot for work, and I always end up sitting next to sick people or dirty little babies on planes. Â It makes me hate life and hate babies. Â I would probably hate life and babies even more if it wasn't for One Medical Group. Â The $150 membership fee is worth it because they are able to accomodate me for appointments right away. Â My old doctor who would make me wait a couple of weeks, and by then I would no longer be sick, or would have to cancel the appointment to go on a business trip. Â My old doctor place would recommend me to go to urgent care if I needed immediate help, but there are always super weird people at urgent care and the line is super long! Â So far, I haven't seen any weird people at One Medical Group. Â So, if you are one of those people who flys on planes while sick, or if you are the owner of a dirty little baby, you should probably give One Medical Group some props too.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I've been with One Medical Group for almost a year now. I don't have much to praise them about but I don't have any strong negative compliant. However for $150/year, the receptions are friendly, helpful, and you'll be able to get same day appointment, but the quality of care is comparable to any other services or doctors. Overall it's not worth the $150/year.The travel clinic is a complete waste of time. I went to Peru in the summer and worked with the nurse, Julie West, to determine which shots I needed. Â Firstly, the travel clinic is on a different billing system so they will not work with the insurance company but will require you to pay upfront and for you to sort it out with the insurance company. Â The nurse basically read what shots was needed for Peru on the CDC website and insisted that I get ALL the recommended shots. Â She improperly advise that I needed certain shots and rather than telling me in advance, she told me when I went in to the office for the shots (waste of time). Â Fortunately they didn't charge me for the co-pay. Â  Since some of the vaccines were not available at One Medical Group, I had to go to a different clinic and choose the travel clinic @ CPMC. Â The travel nurse was AMAZING, she knew exactly which shots were required in different areas of Peru (which was important as I didn't need ALL the shots for Peru) and was able to speak intelligently about the different vaccines. She was very practical in her advice and CPMC worked directly with my insurance company regarding billings, which was much appreciated as apparently, insurance companies are very picky about which travel vaccines are covered and sometimes, they way it is administer, determines whether or not it is covered. Â The physician I selected is Dr. Maricar Pacquing, DO. Â Similar to other review, she has absolutely no personality and does not offer much in terms of over and above care. You ask her a question, she'll answer, and then you ask her your next question, and she'll answer. Â Again, no praise but can't complain since she didn't do anything wrong. Â The service just isn't worth paying a fee each year.Since Dr. Maricar Pacquing is on mat leave, I recently saw Aliciea Wu. Â Since she was not able to assist me with my question and wasn't really offering any service that was worth paying an additional fee for, I just went ahead and asked that they waive my co-pay, which they did.If you see a doctor frequently or considered yourself high-maintenance, this place and the membership fee would be worthwhile. Â  Â I have decided to take the extra effort to research various groups/doctors that would provide better quality care which is more important to me than being able to schedule a same day appointment. Â I'm still in the middle of my research but have already found a knowledge doctor that has made my visits much more worthwhile than Dr. Pacquing & Dr. Wu. Â Unfortunately the location is not as convenient as One Medical Group.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I decided that the next time i needed to see a doctor, I was going to try Metropolitan, because of the great Yelp reviews and location to my office & BART. Â In the mean time, my wife developed a rather nasty infection but wasn't able to get an appointment with her physician. Â She tried Metropolitan and they took her in that day without requiring her pay the annual fee before hand. Â Her experience was phenomenal. Â  She raved about the amount of time and attention to detail that was shown to her and she quickly decided to switch to permanently switch Metropolitan. Â This week, I had my first visit and I was shocked at how courteous, professional, communicative and unrushed the medical and support staff were. Â I actually got angry for all the impersonal, rush-job, cattle call experiences I've been subjected to all these years, not knowing that a place like Metropolitan exists. Â They are truly fantastic.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: One Medical Group is a breath of fresh air! Â After many years of being frustrated with the quality of care (or lack there of) that I received from other general practitioners, I decided to bite the bullet on paying the membership fee and see what this was all about. Â The membership fee definitely seems nominal when you compare it to the exceptional service and treatment you receive. Â I was actually able to see a doctor when I was sick! Â That's priceless! Â The staff is friendly and don't rush you out the door. Â The doctors are attentive and seem genuinely concerned about improving your health. Â I highly recommend One Medical Group - don't let the fee deter you. Â It's worth it!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Superficially, great practice. That said, have anything more than a common cold and they send you to the emergency room. I was a very healthy patient for years then suffered from an odd nerve ailment in the backside. They tired to get me to take Chinese herbs, told me I had VD or prostate cancer, sent me to the hospital. The nurse practitioner I was pawned off on complained that I was interrupting her lunch break! Basically, they didn't want to deal with me. Went to a "real dr" on advice from ER doc then onto physical therapy and issue went away. just have to say, beware, med one docs are hacks, unprofessional, trained to pawn off more than colds to ER which cost $$. I have a new "real" dr who is thorough, professional, sends me to a specialist when needed, doesn't charge a stupid yearly fee so i can see a fish tank in the office. Avoid these guys, a real racket. btw - numerous people, including my girlfriend, have run into issues w/ med one and have since left the practice. I feel like a real smuck because I referred them to med one. avoid avoid avoid
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I have been through 2 different doctors Dr. Lee and Dr. Singh and was very happy with them. Â The front desk personnel are super helpful both on the phone and in person -Thank you Becky and Ethan for your responsiveness and profesionalism.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: yes. this place is a big yes. i had Â gotten dangerously close to exploding trying to find health care, for a few different reason, when i came across this place on yelp. They asked ME when I would like to come in. i told them, they made it so. it's a nice, comfortable place, easy to wait in (which i didn't even have to do) and my doctor was really sweet and helpful. w/o insurance, this is the one place i found since moving here that took care of me in the right way. thanks to the yelpers and thanks to the mmg.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Even though I don't see Dr. much (knock on wood), it doesn't take much Dr. interaction to make the yearly fee to One Medical worthwhile.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I love this place. My husband and I have been a member for two years and we love the service. The $149 price seems steep when you are already paying monthly insurance fees, but the same day appointments are priceless. It is also very nice to be able to email your doctor. And yes, it's true, the practitioners actually take the time to listen to you.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: I was so relieved to find One Medical Group after a friend told me about it. Â I am in between insurance coverage ( none currently) and thought that I could not see a doctor. Â That was until One Medical Group.. I called on Monday morning with my symptons and was given an appointment that same day! Â I couldn't beleive it, with my own experience in the past with trying to see a doctor , it would generally take weeks. Â When I got to my appointment with Dr. Jade Schechter, it was so great. She was so thourough and really took the time to get to know me and my symptoms. I was sicker than I thought and thank goodness she was there. Â She diagnosed me with a case of walking phneomia and got me on the antibiocs and the breathing disk that has made me feel so much better! Â She was so thoughtful and sincere in my interview and my examinination. I am so grateful to this fantastic service and the professionalism of the staff as well. Â I would tell everyone to seek One Medical Group and cannot say enough about how wonderful they were to me and what a piece of mind they gave me. Â Thank You all so much for taking such great care of me!Janet RossSan Rafael
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My real review is 2.5 stars, but Yelp doesn't allow that, so I'm going with 3.The pluses: the doctors themselves are pretty good; the offices are downtown (a big plus for someone who struggles to find an open window of free time for an appointment); they usually run on time (again, a great thing for those of us whose days are packed); having email access (during business hours) to the doctors/care team is convenient; and having a general practitioner can be a positive thing (haven't had one of those since I was a kid--usually have just relied on my OB-GYN). Unfortunately, there have been some problems which justify a star deduction. Â I had to wait for several weeks to get an OB-GYN appointment for follow up testing. Â Then, the doctor's assistant cancelled the appointment at 6 p.m. the day before the appointment (after the phones had already been turned off for the day so that when I called back 2 minutes later no one answered). Â The reason? Â They apparently accidentally scheduled my appointment for a day the doctor had jury duty (something which they presumably knew about months ago but had not told me when I was scheduling the appointment). Â At a different appointment, I had to speak up and demand specific tests which the doctor didn't think I needed given my age and general good health (alas, the test results proved otherwise). Â On a separate visit, I also had an assistant try to give me a vaccine that I had received on a prior visit (apparently my chart indicated that I needed the shot but my chart had not been updated to show that I had received the shot--good thing I was paying attention and spoke up in time to stop her). Â And, on one occasion, the front desk made me pay in full and then had me personally follow up with my insurance company for reimbursement, something none of my other doctor's offices have made me do (like I said, it is hard enough to find the time to make the appointments--I don't have time to follow up on paperwork).In the end, I think the general practice medical care is competent but for specialized care you'll need to go elsewhere. Â They also need to work some on the support side of the business in order for One Medical to live up to its promises of being an efficient medical group for busy professionals.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Everyone should be able to experience health care like this; doctors who take the time and initiative to help you become as as healthy as possible!
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: My experience with this medical group has been pretty mixed. I appreciate the same-day appointment scheduling, which I've utilized many times, and a couple of the practitioners I've seen here have been very helpful. Â However, for the last seven months or so I've been struggling with chronic insomnia Â (sleeping 2-5 hours a night most nights of the week) for which, after several visits, I've never received any useful recommendations, effective treatment, or a referral to someone who might be better able to give me that help. The primary care physician to whom I've been assigned (after my last doctor left) does not ask many questions, listen to my observations or concerns, or appear to care about my condition. Every time I've brought it up, she has jumped to prescribing me sleeping pills, as if my own experience and the scientific evidence hasn't found sleeping pills ineffective. Â Last time I saw her, at my urging, she finally got off the sleeping pill band-aid and instead gave me the recommendation to try geting off caffeine for five weeks to see if my condition might improve. I suppose that's a reasonable next step but there was something about the recommendation -- maybe the fact that it came after months of what seemed like "go away and leave me alone" type care, or the fact that I consume very little caffeine anyways, or the fact that my insomnia has never, in my experience, been linked with caffeine consumption, which I told her, or the fact that insomnia can have literally thousands of different triggers-- just made me feel like I was being sent away with a shot-in-the-dark type solution to my suffering. If she'd suggested I keep a sleep log-- so I could simultaneously track the impact of many different factors on my sleep -- or if she'd indicated she'd like me to try a program of systematically cutting out different common culprits, starting with coffee -- or if she'd given me a referral to a sleep specialist-- I would have been much more satisfied with the recommendation. As it was, it felt really unlikely to lead to any improvements, which, as a matter of fact, it didn't. Â The other MD at One Medical I saw about this condition also put me on sleeping pills and in addition spent most of my session proselytizing about the health benefits of strict veganism --I was a vegatarian already at the time, which most experts agree is as healthy as or more healthy than strict veganism-- so it's hard to see how this was useful medical advice to me. Sorry, but I'm looking for care elsewhere.
Practice: Family Practice, Internal Medicine, Concierge Medicine

Reviews: Do NOT send your family here. The hospital physicians in this hospital are terribly trained. St. Francis outsources their physicians to a corporate physician group, which is not unusual nor necessarily a problem except that their training and clinical reasoning are subpar at best. My family member died prematurely as a result of their repeated lapses in clinical judgment, failure to discharge the patient with appropriate guideline-directed therapies, unwillingness to consult specialists (standard practice in most General Hospital), and failure to listen to patient family's request even when family is medically trained. For instance, despite repeated re-admissions for heart failure, they refused to discharge with the next-level of guideline-directed therapies set forth by the American Heart Association. In the final admission, they finally listened and consulted a cardiology "specialist", who promptly (I am not kidding) decided against the heart failure drug due to the fact that the patient had heart failure. Read that again. For the sake of other patients, I truly hope this was a one-time lapse in judgement. They refused to consult their own radiologists to parse out the patient's pulmonary diagnosis. They refused indicated radiographic studies that would have significantly altered our understanding of the seriousness of the patient's condition as well as what treatments were necessary. From the beginning, the doctors were most interested in simply stabilizing the patient and rushing them home rather than spending the time to come up with an adequate treatment plan. Unfortunately, this speaks to the growing trend of medical corporatization and overwork of medical providers across the country. This should scare you - this entire hospital has ONE doctor for non-ICU patients overnight. Again, this is NOT unusual in the industry! However, there are definitely General Hospital nearby that are better than the average - St. Francis is just not one of them. Why does this hospital get 2 stars? Because there are some things that it does do well. They have an excellent rehab unit. They are the very best at treating burns. The gender institute is renown. The private practice surgeons (eg orthopedics) that do their surgeries at this hospital are overall very competent from what I hear. Outside of these reasons, STAY AWAY FROM THIS HOSPITAL.

I chose to have my surgery here in Saint Francis Memorial back in September Â I really like all my nurses and the way they took care of me I think I had all female nurses. They were kind and caring and motherly to me and I never once felt neglected or scared to be there. One nurse that really made an impression for me and made the difference in how I felt while being there was a nurse by the name of Ernesto! Ernesto really made me feel as if I was staying at a private mansion with my own private nurse. He has such a kind and caring demeanor about him he is very gentle and compassionate. He put my insecurities at ease and took my shame of being there away. You are very vulnerable while being in a hospital and he made all the difference for me. He payed attention to me, treated me with that special care that lacks in General Hospital ( my entire family works in General Hospital and I have been in many top General Hospital ) . On discharge day he helped me get dressed and treated me as a friend, with respect and kindness! I will always remember Ernesto and he is the reason I am actually considering becoming a nurse myself! Any hospital that has the honor of having Ernesto to be present with their patients is truly a lucky place. Like I said I didn't even feel like I was in a hospital but more like I was staying in a historic mansion in San Francisco with why own private nurse. I will definitely choose St Francis for any future surgeries I may need to have.

Terrible staff and good luck with your payment. They will make you pay day of more than what you owe and when it's time for them to give you a refund after your insurance pays they, they will argue they were owed more and that they should keep your excess payment. I wouldn't come here. Go to Sutter Health, their General Hospital are great and they take their billing department seriously. Here after millions of phone calls I was told that there's no one I can speak to since their "back office" manages things and you can't talk to them, and they will tell you that they can't help you.

Went to the walk in ER. They were all very nice and gave me a diagnosis. Then gave me %100 incorrect information as to whom i should contact next. Literally outdated phone numbers and the verbal command "the surgeons will know what to do next. Go ahead and call those numbers." Â The insurance guy also came to visit me while I was only wearing a smock and asked for my ID. The lady at the desk gave me a medical bracelet that didn't belong to me. All in all i wish i would have gone else where. Â But I didn't have to pay for the humilation that was a bonus.
Top of the line full service hospital spevializing in sports medicine, the burn unit transgender health, CancerCOPD, Senior care etc

Thank you so much for the difference you make in my life! Divya and Zandra of Pulmonary Rehab's kindness, sincere caring, and concern make everything better and are a great encouragement! Thank you so very much for taking care of me and being so skilled at what they do. Every day of my life will be better because of Zandra and Divya of Pulmonary Rehabilitation! Being in rehab helps me prevent from going to the hospital because of COPD flare-ups, or "exacerbations." I always feel better at the end of my exercises

Got a $1.9K bill for less than 10 minutes ER visit. Wow!!! I am so upset I had to share with everyone. Why I got two different bills? Not sure yet. I have no words but what type of fraud is this? Called them and they said they don't like to disclose the cost upfront. Because it could be $3K.

Yeah I agree with other reviews. Something definitely changed with this hospital, I've been to the emergency room before in 2015, and 2016 and even admitted to the hospital and my copay was always 150$. It is one reason I didn't hesitate to go to the ER at Saint Francis, because I knew my insurance would cover everything. A month later I received the bill, it was around 5k for the ER, my insurance covered a big chunk but I still owe 1k and I was not even admitted to hospital. Definitely would not recommend ER here, they will overcharge you, some shady business practices is going on here and they should be investigated.

Hospital is very old. I felt as though I went back in time when I had an appointment for a simple ultrasound. 30 minutes to register at the registration desk another 20 minutes to wait to be seen for the appointment at the radiology appointment. I couldn't believe all the paperwork one department needed instead of looking in their system. You would be out of luck if you forgot your doctor referral. If your thinking of taking a hour and a half off work for an appointment forget it. Plan to spend 3 hours here.. this hospital would be great for seniors who have all the time on their hands to see their doctor not a working professional

We'd like to express our gratitude and appreciation for Jerry Wehage, Nuclear Medicine Coordinator. Â He was doing bone scan for my dad. Â Jerry worked so professionally, he was so nice, caring and attentive, making sure the patient is doing well and feeling comfortable. Â Thank you very much Jerry!

February 13, 2020 at 4:15pm.Â I am reporting on a male nurse who became physically violent on me. I waited for a full week for the hospital to respond to my "Patient ComplaintÂ Form" I left the hospital before I left that day. Not aÂ single word.Due to vomiting and diarrhea lasting over a week my provider had sent me to the hospital to get a couple of bag of fluids in me to help regain my strength and weaken immune system. I've been living with A.I.D.S. for over 30 years.Â I went into St. Francis Memorial Hospital here in San Francisco because it is my neighbor hoods hospital. They had me do a stool kit test. I used the only bathroom in the emergency department everyone else's who is being seen for being sick uses, which di not have any soap dispenser in the bathroom.Â My private thoughts, this is flu season in ER and U.S. Surgeon states hand washing is a must to fight coronavirus.Â I went back to my assigned bed and all of a sudden a male nurse rushes into the my bed area, he does not introduce himself, I have never seen before, he announces I'm out of here, right now! I look up at the bag of fluid and saw that it wasn't even half way gone and told that male nurse that I was to stay until the bag of fluids was fully gone, fully emptied. He said angrily, no you don't, you leave now. I asked him for his name he would not disclose it. He wore the NR badge. I asked to see my doctor because I had further questions about what to do after I leave the emergency room. He snarkily aggressively said, I am your doctor and you are leaving now! I never saw this person before.Â This male nurse then grabbed my arm without forewarning, without telling me he was going to be touching me before he touched me. I flinched my arm away from him he re-grabbed my arm and held tight. I told him politely to stop touching me. He would not stop, he became more aggressive and would not let go of my arm nor explain his actions. I kept telling him, "Do not touch me." "Stop touching me." "Stop grabbing me." "Let go of my arm you are hurting me." "Stop TOUCHING MY BODY NOW!." I was forced to go from polite tone to screaming due to his actions. He would not let go of his grip on my arm as I struggle to get my arm freed. He then grabs the IV in my arm and yanked it out. Blood squirted all over the place. He then announced you can now leave throwing my discharge papers onto the floor and stormed out. When I got into the lobby my arm was still bleeding.Â No one in the emergency department came to see what was the disturbance nor would they disclose this individual's name. I wanted him arrested.My partner of five years was in shock to see this happening as he witnessed this through a window of the lobby. The hospital would not let my partner be with me during this ER visit. Don't know why, perhaps homophobic or afraid of witnesses?Â In my 30+ years of dealing with HIV medical stuff I have never dealt with a rude bedside manners, not to mention their aggressive violently nature. This is the first time in all these years, decades I was treated with violence at a medical center. I went to a safe, non-violent place to seek out help and I left sicker due to this individual and his violent ways. I spent the night shaking and crying, until four in the morning after two sedatives. I am most likely not the only individual who had to face this male nurse's aggressive physical violence. I was taught when a nurse physically starts to harms you, you need to say stop immediately, this nurse did not.Â If you see violence REPORT IT! Stop of the violence!

The level of overcharging with St. Francis hospital billing may be legal but it feels like fraud. A recent stay for 1 day of non surgical treatment (observation and tests only) cost similar to the costs of a full operation in a typical hospitalThey overcharge for routine procedures and scans by 5x or 10x. The overcharging part is all on the part of the hospital - the doctors bills (which were submitted through a separate organization ) were reasonable.

I was there 8/31/2015- 9/27/2015(approximately) because my dads girlfriend called the police I pushed my dad. After I got 5150 my dad and his gf went to tokoyo. They injected me with tranquilizers and wouldn't let me leave for 3 weeks. I wasn't even 5150 material I was coming down off drugs and it put me in an entire cycle of medication addiction to anti psychotic drugs that ruined my life for almost FOUR YEARS. This place tried to tell me I'm schizophrenic when I'm not. AT ALL. I spent my 28 birthday there. I had so much going on in my life that they had students studying to become professionals interview me about ALLLLL sorts of stuff asking me questions about how my brain worked. All they did was ask me things and listen toMe talk they didn't even tell me anything that could help me at all. It was Weirrrrrrrrd.And my actual name is Elizabeth Marie Webb. It is UNNECESSARY for you to respond to MY opinion about your business

At the age of 65, I have either visited or been an admitted patient in more than 25 General Hospital. Without comparison, Saint Francis is THE noisiest hospital I have had to endure.
