As a patient with an extremely painful gallbladder attack, I had already been without sleep for 24 hours before being admitted to Saint Francis. In the following 18 hours after being given a bed, lasting until 4AM the next day, a nearby room's TV was blaring at its highest volume. Even after I painfully made my way to my room's door to close it, the TV could still be heard at half of its maximum volume. Then the night nurse came by and said I HAD TO keep my door open! After asking her WHY was there a TV noise allowed to blare throughout the floor, she said that a "report" had been lodged with the building maintenance staff to UNPLUG THAT DAMNED TV! When I said I WOULD GLADLY UNPLUG THE DAMNED TV MYSELF, she laughed at me. Within 15 minutes, I dressed myself and left the hospital against medical advice. The next day, I admitted myself to THE FAR SUPERIOR SUTTER HEALTH HOSPITAL ON NEARBY VAN NESS AVENUE. 12 hours after being admitted to Sutter Hospital, I underwent an operation to remove my EXTREMELY PAINFUL gallbladder. Saint Francis hospital ONLY PROLONGED MY SUFFERING! I guess the Hippocratic Oath has been completely disavowed by their entire staff of doctors and nurses!

All from 2015: I had a bad ER experience here where I was treated as if I was some kind of criminal for being in pain from a terrible ear infection that had gone on too long from being misdiagnosed. So for the crime of having a painful medical emergency, my boyfriend actually heard the nurses bad-mouthing me in the hallway for crying because I was in pain. A nurse came in and said they weren't going to do anything for me until I stopped crying. I simply had tears coming from my eyes from the pain, I wasn't involved in any kind of audible crying, but apparently it was NOT OK with them that saline was coming from my eyes.Felt like they were on a power trip, were angry with me for being in pain at an inconvenient time (midnight) even though I was one of three people waiting. I don't believe the reviews that talk about the nurses being alright. They seemed callous to me, uncaring of how or whom they traumatized or caused unnecessary intense physical pain. It felt like they had lost their sense of compassion and it had been replaced with cruelty.They ended up misdiagnosing me after ~2 minutes of actual medical attention (2nd misdiagnosis) & giving me the wrong medicine (ended up making it worse + giving *more* pain). I had to pay around $250 out of pocket for this honor. I had to go to urgent care a few days later (also run by "DIGNITY" Health systems). There they MISDIAGNOSED ME AGAIN, prescribed $50 ear drops I didn't need, and a Dr. there says, "ear infection is one of the most physically painful things an adult can experience," [yeah I noticed]. So shame on the nurses at St. F for shaming me for tearing up and making me stop before they would even look at me to treat me.So I was misdiagnosed (3rd! time), given MORE expensive wrong meds that HURT LIKE HELL to put in my ear. Finally got to an ENT COMPLETELY OUTSIDE THE CRAPPY "DIGNITY" System (how ironic a name is that?) after that weekend, and the ENT finally PROPERLY diagnosed me, gave me the right meds, and I got better...but not before I ended up missing TWO WEEKS of work and bursting an EAR DRUM! Took 3 months for it to fully heal and to get full hearing back. I had to do a whole long hearing test to make sure. Whole mess amounted to a grand total of around $500. I WILL NEVER GO TO THE ST. F ER AGAIN!1st Experience @St. F: Had surgery w/ OK outcome here (my great surgeon happened to operate here). Pre-op was fine (even if it did seem to lag for too long...2 hours? Really? Eventually a nurse came in and turned on the bed heat air blasty thing and I was thinking jeez I wish you'd done that 90 minutes ago so I didn't have to spend the last 90 minutes freezing my butt off -- but of course she didn't check or ask before then). From that I sensed a base-level of negligence but ignored it at the time. When I woke up from surgery I seriously had to pee but I couldn't get out of bed yet; it took about 5 minutes of polite but consistent calling out and asking before a nurse came, acting somewhat personally offended at having to bring me a bedpan. She was good about taking it away and not spilling any on me, so that was cool. I gave her all my best thank-yous.It felt like getting released took longer than needed, & they weren't really careful about making sure I was ok + didn't fall, even though I'd just had knee surgery. I was so grateful my partner at the time was with me; he watched over my fall risk. I think the fact that he was a big, tall, white, male with a deep voice and made my requests/advocated for me definitely helped me get better and quicker care. I am sure I would have had a much different experience otherwise. The nurses responded to him instead of me. He helped me instead of them because he was there while they were mostly absent. He helped me dress and had to put my shoes and socks on for me. I'm guessing if he wasn't there I would have been wheeled out barefoot as we got little further attention from any of the nurses once I was dressed and just waiting for an escort to wheel me out. They gave me crutches but didn't show me how to use them properly (I had surgery a few years after this at Post Street Surgery Center and they did show me how to use the walker they gave me after surgery [couldn't use crutches anymore, arm damage] - it took 60 seconds and kept me from hurting myself -- never got that from St. F). I did get two bills post-surgery and it was exorbitant. Did a lot of research beforehand, double confirmed codes for the surgery. The first one was expected. The second bill was some time later and seemed to be the hospital's non-itemized tack-ons, but I was too ignorant then to know what they were doing, I just paid it.St. F. Â I don't think the F stands for Francis. I don't think the St. stands for saint either. Not by a long shot.Go to UCSF, CPMC, SFG, ANYWHERE ELSE! _TAKE A REALLY EXPEN$IVE TAXI / UBER RIDE_ to ANY OTHER HOSPITAL! IT WILL SAVE YOU SO MUCH TIME, MONEY, PAIN+ HEARTACHE IN THE END!

Very disappointing and Really really bad service here. Â I went here it was 2 in the morning for the emergency, because i got really hurt stomach ache and I dont know where to go. So i decided to came to this hospital and expecting for the treatment. after the register process. They called me and asked me for what is going on. And they brought me to the room where i should wait for the doctor. after 40 minutes and the doctor had not come yet, i decided to exit the hospital and i told the nurse inside the hospital if i feel more comfortable to wait at my apartment. BUT, the nurse ditch me by saying "are you still gonna wait for the doctor or leave?" and i just left. After a couple days i received a bill mailed to me for $250 "even i did not see the doctor face" I decided to call the hospital in order to ask what do i need to pay or if i could get any convince for the bill. On the other hand after they pulled my data they told me my bill is actually $850 because i was using the facility to wait in the room as well as because it is an Emergency. I was shocked at the moment because I was only laying on the bed and was waiting. But in the conversation the person told me that the only way to pay is if i am paying right now by the phone i will get 30% discount or i can pay with payment plan. I do not have any payment plan And after all i just decided to pay the $600 after the discount. Even-though it does not make any sense to me and to be honest i feel very disappointed.To be honest i feel like i got robbed by the hospital.But, hopefully this review could give everybody clear explanation of my complaint Thank you,

I went to the ER out of my friends concern. I left with a bill for $5000+ for a blood draw because they insisted on filing the injury under workers compensation despite me telling them I don't have compensation. Usually a blood draw is free with my insurance. The whole experience was bad. Dirty hospital, expensive bill that no one warns you about and bad customer service from the front desk, the nurses, everyone. 6 hr wait, got ignored, Â got yelled at by the front desk for asking for them nicely to file it correctly under my insurance, signed my life away and got no inkling of what my blood results were. Also left crying. The employees here could care less about you.If I'm ever in an ambulance, I would tell them to reroute to avoid this place@julie no one picked up the phone, Would like to talk to a person not a machine. Thanks

I'm sure there are good parts of the hospital. I've been a patient for over 10 years and I can't emphasize enough how great the sports medicine clinic is, but the hospital service quality has degraded since Dignity took over.The world is full of companies that are able to coordinate billing systems but Dignity is not one of them. It is common practice for them to issue old balances on new statements after paying it off. Â The hospital staff and the dignity billing system are not aligned. Â The registration system is a mess. They have three windows, but it's never fully staffed and it's slower than the dmv. Â Every time you need blood work or an XRAY you must register. you get a new account number with a new bill that you need to pay off rather than aggregating total dues under a single account. Â The staff looks very unmotivated and I eventually went to quest because the staff was so slow.Overall between the billing system issues, and the registration, I would opt for another facility as it's become a time sink for you to spend an hour waiting for staff to show up.
Elite 2021
Stop pretending you care by posting those copy/paste response. If you did, my initial dispute would have been properly reviewed instead of some BS boilerplate responses.

Need urgent or emergency care? Â Start here: dignityhealth.org/emergeâ¦You'll be called by a triage nurse. Alternate URL for ~ same thing:dignity.inquicker.com/emâ¦My experience using it: It doesn't seem to change things much. Â Expect to have to repeat yourself many times - even if confusion is one of your symptoms. I arrived at 3:30 - late for my 3:15. Â Checked in at billing/reception right away, told them I'd used InQuicker, and they went and found my completed form, but only after I'd filled out their standard paper form with roughly the same info. Â Vitals taken ~15mins later, and I had to repeat my complaint (symptoms and reason for coming to the ER) that I'd entered and was on my inQuicker form - and had been provided in more detail over the phone to the first triage nurse - then back to waiting room. Â One woman who said she'd been waiting 2 hours, and had only come in because she'd been advised do, even though she it was probably not necessary, gave up and left. Â Another woman who seemed to need urgent care from a blow to her knee / lower leg also wanted to leave without being seen, even though she couldn't walk/ put weight on her leg, but couldn't; she was trying to hobble out using the wall, but couldn't. Â I wheeled over the transport chair she had been in and she accepted and appreciated my help to get to the curb to get a taxi. Â During a second nurse intake ~30 mins later, I had to re-repeat my complaint. Â (During it, I could overhear that a patient OD'ing on some opioid was being attended to, was non-responsive after getting narcan and was given a second dose.) Â I was brought into a bed in the ER. Â I had to re-re-repeat my complaint ~30 mins later to another nurse, and I had to repeat it for a final time ~30 mins later to a doctor. Â He advised me that I would be better off with care for my very rare condition at UCSF Parnassus ER, or Stanford's ER, where I could expect a neurologist to be available who had some knowledge and experience with, and thus could better treat, my condition, plus the St Francis MRI was not open / is not normally open after 5. Â This made sense to me at the time; he offered to transfer me, but we agreed that it would be faster if I just took myself, and was in good enough shape to do so safely. Â So he discharged me with the oral and written advice to head to UCSF's ER, at 5:30 PM - 2 hours after I'd arrived. Â Looking back, it's strange that he said the MRI wasn't available, as it was a Monday, and they're open 24 hours M-F, per google.com/search?q=st+fâ¦. Â That was 5 days ago. I got the MRI at Stanford and I'm doing fine. Â Bill: TBD.

When I found a Sports Medicine Clinic in the St Francis Hospital I thought it was going to dreary. Â I was wrong, perched on 11th floor doesn't look nor smell like a hospital at all! Asked a load of questions which makes me feel comfortable that she knows what to do next!I'm recommending anyone has run issues go see her!
The local private hospital in Nob hill was not actually that clean in private hospital's standards and the charges here are ridiculous

Frustrating experience with the billing! They charge you two separate bills, one for the hospital and other to see the doctor. Shouldn't it just one combined charge? I mean barely saw the doctor! Literally came in twice, once to explain my situation and second to let me know I'm being discharged. I am being charged almost $4000 for the hospital visit and another $1000 just to see the doctor??? Isn't that kinda redundant? I'm going to hospital to see a doctor shouldn't that be include within the hospital bill???!?Why would that be separate !??Also, i dont understand why wasn't I told about this at hospital. The gentleman that taking my info, did not once mention anything about the separate billing.I called the billing office and their answer was "this is just how it is." Horrible answer. So far I received 2 separate Â bills for the same account, I hope this is the last.Hospital aren't places we want to Intentionally Â go but if you have to go somewhere make sure you don't come here.

I had an Urgent medical though non Emergency Room event recently and a friend told me about making an appointment online at St. Mary's. Â I wanted to go a hospital closer to where I live, so I chose St. Francis (I went to a St. Francis Hospital in Illinois a long time ago for several childhood injuries, so the name has some sentimental meaning for me too).I made an appointment online, got there 5 minutes early, sat down immediately with an administrator immediately who took down all necessary information. Â But most important, he had a great sense of humor (that made extra points with me).I might have gotten lucky regarding no one else in the Emergency Room when I got there, but as far as my experience went today, they made it relatively painless.

I was at St. Francis years ago when I lived in San Francisco. I barely made it into St. Francis from work before collapsing at the ER. I was vomiting, my head felt like hammers continuously hammering on my head, I thought I was dying. Immediately they shot me up with morphine, which is good for me, hey, but then afterwards they told me I had a simple migraine and since I'd never experienced a migraine before it feels really crappy. So you shot me up with morphine because I had a migraine? Love the morphine but that's how people get addicted to that stuff. Another friend of mine who had freaking heart surgery only got the weak stuff at another hospital because maybe they're actually responsible and don't want to increase the opiate crisis.Oh, and my migraine. Yeah I was literally bullied by this Asian doctor for an HOUR to "stay the night" at the hospital so they could earn more money. They admitted I had a migraine. I don't need to stay overnight for a migraine. But I was young and they were old and "wise" so I listened. I didn't realize at the time I can leave against doctor's orders. I know better now. Paid over a grand for NOTHING. No one checked on me, it was literally just a really crappy hotel room without a maid or any decorations. Should have spent that money on 2 nights at the Four Seasons instead.Don't go here. Go anywhere but here. Here they are nothing but a money making machine. And fuck you that Asian doctor, I'm not made of money, I was 22, and yet you BULLIED me for LITERALLY an HOUR into giving the "hospital" $1K to stay the night. That is the best word to describe what he did. He BULLIED me, yelled and said I might die if I go home (with a migraine?! Plus I told him I had a BF at home to look after me) until I relented and said I'll stay.

I am lowering from two starts to one star for the following.When attempting to get medical record, there was no mention of the untreated broken bones in my face in the ER. I called the ER to talk inquire about this but the person got mad and hung up on me. I clearly communicated the problem and I didn't curse or yell at her. The medical record does not indicate a serious condition that I presented at the ER. They want to address this problem by hanging up the phone on me.

Horrible Hospital. The care was good enough but they easily charge 2-3X what any other hospital would charge. I have now had to sit on the phone for hours with the hospital and my insurance. If you have a choice I would avoid their ER.

Do not go to St. Francis for anything other an burns. Â My mother went into the hospital for pneumonia and we could not get any doctor to call us to tell us what was going on with her and her care. Â I was out of the country for work and my husband was listed by my mother as next of kin but never once did they communicate anything with us. Â One day my husband went in to visit her and they had discharged her without telling any of her family that they were doing this or where they were sending her.They sent her deathly ill, (literally, she died 1.5 weeks later) to a nursing home that was not equipped to take care of people who have multiple health issues that lead to her dying.So avoid this hospital and their lack of communication and lack of understanding of how ill a patient can be, by all means!

Spent all afternoon in vain trying to get my medical information--through the portal--which I was told I would have access to after registering and giving my email address when signing in at the ER. Â I also have been on the phone an additional 30 min--even a supervisor was no help. She told me to call the hospital, Â they could send the invite--get me access to my records. Â Then the hospital told me they couldn't help, couldn't send an invite--told me to go back to the hospital, re-register in the ER and then they will (maybe) send me an invite.If I felt well enough. Â But I can't get out of bed. Â I can barely breath. Â Guess what? Â That's why I was in the ER! I needed a heart stress test and I can't get one because I can't get access to the form where the dr. said it was urgently needed. Â Been 4 weeks, test should have been 3 weeks ago. Â But no one will help! They never sent the medical records to my dr. Â  Â My dr refuses to call the hospital and deal with it. Â I'm Â too sick to go into SF and jump through Â this General Hospital hoops to (maybe) get a form that I was told I could get on their portal. Â This is stressing me out so much my bp has gone through the roof and I can barely breath. Â Chest pressure, pain....YES! Â All worse!! Â Thank you St. Francis. Only thing this hospital has done is made a bad situation worse.Doesn't matter how good or bad a dr is--if the information, the diagnosis, the test results, etc., if all of those are kept hidden and not provided to patients or dr's--then why in the world would anyone go to this hospital? Â And why should I have to pay?? Â I got their bill. Â Of course I did. Â But I am unable to get any information beyond that. Â  What good are the blood test? Â Xrays? Â Whole experience has been pointless and useless--worse off than before I went to the ER. Â I am so angry at this hospital.

This hospital is a ripoff. Â I sought treatment at the sports medicine office, which is a private doctor's office. Â At each visit, I was billed for a "hospital visit" fee on top of the doctor's office visit, and the hospital bills were 2 & 1/2 times higher than the doctor's office bill. Â I tried to dispute these charges since I had only visited a private doctor's office, and no other hospital ever charged me a "hospital visit" fee, but was told that this was a mandatory charge and that Dignity Health charges anyone who enters the hospital even if it is to visit a private doctor's office. Â Even my own doctor told me that she has tried to dispute the charges since we were not using the hospital facilities, but they refused to reverse the fees.They also charged me almost double for x-rays than what I paid for a MRI at a different company, which is a more expensive procedure. I have since discovered that this is the same organization that refuses to provide women basic health care treatments. If this could be a 0 star it would beThough it is relatively quick to register, and then get triaged, I will NEVER ever go back to St Francis Memorial Hospital if I am having an emergency. Â I have been here three times (first two were about 3.5 stars), and the last time which was about four weeks ago, was the worse experience of my life (if I could it would be 0 star). Â I came in for a medication interaction and some emotional problems and told the triage nurse that I was feeling nauseous. Â She listened to me or it seemed like she listened to me. Â Then, she got me a room and another nurse attended to me and asked me what was going on. Â It took me a long time to see a doctor. Â Actually, it wasn't even a doctor who saw me, it was a Physician Assistant, which I now know only works under supervision of the doctor. Â I think she only saw me very briefly because she already got the information from the nurse. Â So, what did she do? Â Or rather what did she not do? Â I never saw someone so incompetent in my life! Â She just ordered me ativan for anxiety and an anti-nauseous medicine. Â Did she even bother taking blood tests? Urine sample? Did she care that an interaction was actually occurring? Â Nope. Â Then I was discharged. Â Because I demanded I still don't know what is wrong with me, the staff was incredibly rude and basically kicked me out. Â Then, because of that horrible experience and still not knowing what was going on with my body, I had to have a friend pick me up and drive me to another ER, where they did do blood tests and urine, and were incredibly more competent and definitely not rude.

My husband was there for colonoscopy screening, which was supposed to be NO out of pocket. Â However, he was charged a few hundred bucks as a co-insurance. A week after the screening, he was confirmed by the his insurance company that they covered the full cost of screening colonoscopies, so he needs to pay $0 to the hospital. Â  It's been over a month now, but the billing dept. hasn't processed a refund yet. Â The 2 stars are to give the RNs who are nice and attentive.

Super shitty experience. Homeless people galore in waiting room. They just make you wait and leave you hanging. Not big on confidentiality. I heard so much about the people around me and their health issues. They need service design."hello humankindness" = laughable

Dr Chen-Luftig was a godsend in the ER when a friend of mine needed to pass a kidney stone. Shes been incredibly helpful and so informative beyond any expectation, she was incredibly nice and considerate and addressed tons of issues that we have had in the hospital historically, including inconsiderate psychiatrists and other caretakers who were outright belligerent. She assured us of what exactly should be done in the future, she was helpful in speculating diagnoses of other prevalent disorders, and MOST IMPORTANTLY, she said"I do not think you overreacted." I cannot say how amazing this statement is and how rare this is coming from a physician. She was validating and humanitarian and she absolutely should be the one calling the shots in the hospital. I cannot stress how amazing this woman was. Seriously one of the best medical professionals I have ever met. I wish I could talk to this woman forever, she was incredible. A doctor who gives priority to the perspective of the patient. Thank you so much Dr Chen-Luftig. And the mental health unit here is extremely hit or miss. Dr Blaustein, this hospital's head psychiatrist, seriously needs to update his practice. He's stuck in DSM-3. He rejected several diagnoses I suspect I had which were later confirmed by every other psychiatrist and therapist I had seen from that point forward. He needs to retire. That being said there are very genuinely helpful people in the mental health unit. Janice, a mental health nurse, comes to mind. The social workers on that floor are also very considerate and make an effort to connect with the patient. Anyway I'm giving this hospital five stars for the sake of the handful of incredible people who work here. For many of the other staff, I would love to confront them on the bs they presented to me every time I stayed here. Belligerent ER nurses, dismissive doctors, etc. Anyway, if you come here understand that you're rolling the dice and you really might get fucked over but you also might get a golden egg.

Sad how slow and almost dysfunctional this place is. The DMV is more efficient than them, if most of the staff could learn on how to have better empathy dealing with patients instead of being distracted by being too chatty and social with each other. A complete disgrace to have this location provide ER services.
Terrible hospital !! Made me leave without helping me because they said it wasn't life threatening.. but it was my liver and I'm holding St Francis liable if anything happens to me

I live in Colorado, my husband was in San Francisco for a business trip and ended up in the ER due to a medical condition. This was in February. It's now June and I am receiving threatening letters like "final notice" on a bill. Except I've never received an itemized bill, even though I've called and repeatedly requested one. I don't know wtf they expect when they send a bill that says hey, you owe over $400 but I'm not going to tell you for what. They keep telling me they sent one, when I get what they sent, it has no details, only a total of what was billed, what ins. Paid and what I now owe. Not idea what they bill the insurance for, because they won't provide that to me. EVERY TIME I CALL I'm on the phone for at least 1/2 hour. This is ridiculous. So today, to request the itemized bill for the THIRD TIME, while I have my "final notice" in hand the woman said, well I can request another one but your account is still going to go to collections, we can't tell you when, or when you'll get the itemized bill (if ever at this point), not they send it out-someone else does that (of course!) but they can set me up on a payment plan to avoid collections. SHADY, DISHONEST BILLING PRACTICES. WHO THE F KNOWS WHAT THEY ARE BILLING ME FOR?????? NO ONE WILL PROVIDE THAT FOR ME.

My father was in and out of the hospital for a stroke in the last month. Â The nursing staff was PHENOMENAL! Â Acute rehab on 8th floor was outstanding and very attentive. I guarantee if you have a family member in ICU they will get the absolute best care and attention possible.
Elite 2021

Had no idea this hospital was so unethical. Received moderate care for a bad case of strep throat... Flash forward a few weeks later and I'm billed for services totaling nearly three thousand dollars. I was in the ER for no more than 90 minutes and received a strep test, a shot, and a prescription. Billing was unhelpful, unable to share any specific details, and claimed these charges were reasonable for the area. I now have to wait another 7-10 days to determine what they actually billed me for. I have the time and resources to dispute these charges, but I'm concerned for others who may not. Do not go to this emergency room unless you're prepared for extreme price gouging.

$1k for a shoulder X-ray!!! Are you f'ing kidding me! This is seriously the worst robbery....an X-ray should not cost this much let alone a MRI. This is clearly a profit driven institution. Also, I waited 30min for my X-ray so what is the point of having appointments. Yet another example of a profit driven organization where they overbook. I will never come back to this hospital.

If you are having an emergency I seriously hope for your wallet's sake that you go anywhere but here. I visited the ER in September because I thought that I had appendicitis. A couple of hours, some blood tests and a CT scan later I was let out without needing surgery -- apparently I was fine. I expected to receive a somewhat hefty bill as I used the ER facilities, but not to the tune of $15,000. The CT scan alone was billed at $11,000. Of course, I never would have known this breakdown without my EOB from insurance, as it has been 5 months since I went there and have yet to receive an itemized bill even though I have called St Francis 4 times specifically requesting one. It turns out that if you call billing and make two requests, only one of them gets saved in their system. This is literally what the last customer support person told me! I guess it's just too much for their systems to handle when you request a hold on your account AND an itemized bill. I also learned on this last call that the agent had no way to access my itemized bill while on the phone, so I couldn't even attempt to dispute the charge. I REALLY want to know how a hospital can charge 10x Health Care Blue Book prices, send me ZERO correspondence except for one past due notice even though I called them on 4 separate occasions requesting a bill, with 2 of those calls taking place before the past due notice came, and give me literally no way of communicating with them about the charge when I find other means to even know what the charge is (EOB). Complete robbery and horrendous billing department. Can't wait to pay this bill for the next year. Â Meanwhile, a friend of mine who actually did get appendicitis recently is in the Kaiser network and paid $0!

My experience at San Francisco Dignity Health SaintÂ Francis Memorial Hospital has been nothing short of frustrating and downright unethical. Due to some new, urgent health issues, I needed to see a GI doctor. I found a doctor at St Francis through my insurance company. Before I even scheduled the appointments (office visit and procedure), I asked the doctor's office what the cost would be both in cash and with my insurance and they told me they were unable to provide that information. After the doctor's consult appointment and procedure in early April 2019 the total fees wereÂ $7,400. I am now told I owe close to $5,000 out of pocket for this routine procedure.Â  When I received these bills, I was in total shock as I had tried to obtain prices before but the facility refused to provide them. I have since done additional research on fair prices for this routine procedure.Â These fees are significantly higher than the $1,714 fair price listed using the same CPT code I was billed for on Healthcare BlueBook. Furthermore, my family then contacted 2 other GI offices in the same San Francisco area, and both facilities have a total doctor's office and facility fee of $2,300 and $2,750, information provided easily upon inquiring. How can your medical group be charging rates of 200-250% higher than area standards?Â Most interestingly, after receiving these exorbitant bills and outside comparisons, I have contacted your billing department multiple times and have been met with very rude, unhelpful staff members. They have declined to make any adjustments to be in line with other General Hospital in the area.Â I contacted my doctor to inform him of what I had happened to me. He told me that he was entirely unaware of the true costs and would speak to the CMO of Dignity Health SaintÂ Francis Memorial Hospital. Last week I got a call from the hospital billing to say that myÂ dispute was invalid and denied.Â  After this, I emailed my doctor to think him for trying to help me. To my surprise, he informed me he has decided to leave Dignity Health for these unfair and unreasonable practices. Even the doctor at your group is totally disgusted with what Dignity Health is doing and is quitting. Given these terrible, unprofessional, unethical business practices, I have given up on speaking to the billing department and am considering other public avenues to warn others of the shameful practices at Dignity Health St. Francis.Note to Dignity PR - I see that you respond to comments, if you decide to reply, please contact me with a direct line. I am tired of calling your general number and getting no where with your staff.

Absolute crooks. Exorbitantly priced care. I did 6 sessions of physical therapy at those place. The bill? $1800. Every 15 minutes of PT here cost $90. Think about that. And they're not even transparent despite asking about the costs involved.

Behavior health on 3rd floor:Awesome outstanding and very kind staff, Â the 1 star is for the 38 year on job experience doctor, who believes in old style medication by shutting you up with heavy drugs to the point of seeing the patient in seizure mode begging for help, this doctor never returned our messages or neither called the family for information, it took 4 days for the next facility to finally wake him up normal.If you're loved one is stuck there, we hope you have a better experience. Â Love the Staff, that's the only positive thing I can say.

Have not received the bill yet so a little hesitant to review, but really quick awesome care in the emergency room. Flew in from Las Vegas and after calling back home for the nurse care line was instructed to go in somewhere immediately because of swelling and this was close by. Was after hours so parked for free at the angle parking area around the corner from entry and it did not take too long to get registered and settled in waiting. Public baths are filthy but from what I see, not their fault... kind of a "homeless wash room" and it was not long term dirt. Male nurse freaked out a bit by what he saw, (as did I) but that just moved things along anyway. Very kind and attentive care and the Dr. M Todd? did follow up with a call back a few days later when I was back home. Â Seems they have to put up with a lot of mentally ill, drugged & drunk patients and I saw them treat people respectfully.

With my grandpa recently passed away in this hospital, I can tell you guys that this hospital sucks big time. We suspect my grandpa died because of morphine overdose which suppresses his breathing! Yes my grandpa is 86 and suffering for Alzheimer's for many years. But it does not mean we don't want him to live as long as he could with his family taking care of him! Story goes like this: my grandpa was first in the hospital 3 and half years ago due to food got into his lungs and caused pneumonia. The doctors back then dogmatically ruled him that his ability to swallow is none and insisted in getting our family to consent for a gastronomic feeding tube to be put in his stomach. Back then we refused and insisted in feeding him naturally. Guess what he lived 3 and half years longer with the family!  Â 2 months ago same thing happened and the ambulance brought him here again! Same story and ruling from these suck ass doctors. Our family refused the feeding tube again! ( the logics behind refusal was we had 2 relatives who consented to feeding tube insertion all died within a week due to infections!) These doctors got mad saying we are stubborn! And threatened us not to treat our grandpa if we refuse to their suggestions! Guess what, with his 2nd time in the ER this time, they did not do a damn thing to treat him! They did not bother! What kind of doctor moral is that? but just give him mega dose of morphine to kill him without family consent!The doctors there have no respect for life, patient right to choose treatment and downright cold hearted! They only care about $$, how much they can charge u if u agree to their expensive treatment plan!

Made a Yelp account specifically to write this review.People are right. Everything people say is true. This place is pretty bad. Astonished by the price, and disappointed by the service. I don't have much more to add.The breaking point was when I called customer service to ask for a report on my X-ray and was briskly told no clerks were available until Monday. He then interrupted me repeatedly telling me, "Thank you for calling, have a nice day, good bye," while I was talking until I finally raised my voice, asking him what were the contents of the report.As a student staying over the summer with an emergency elbow fracture, this was not what I was expecting. Find a different hospital.

Absolutely terrible front desk a reception. Incredibly incompetent and rude. It's best to have someone already dealing with a life threatening situation as comfortable as possible with their first interaction with the hospital. I will trust my health care with them.

Over time we have all heard stories of poor ER experiences, especially when visiting a busy city hospital. Â Staff criticism can be severe.In the case of St. Francis Memorial Hospital, nothing could be further from the truth. Having recently been in for late night treatment, everyone we encountered from the check-in desk, through triage station, Registered Nurse staff, Radiological Team, and of course the attending MD was 5-Star.Having observed the staff manage all manner of insanity, belligerent patients dropped off by law enforcement, incoherent addled patients seeking to self-admit without ID of any kind, existing patients tearing-up examination rooms turning the floor into a urine slip-n-slide...all I could think was thank goodness the Staff of St. Francis ER is here to help those in need. Â It's hard to imagine tolerating this level of abuse in any line of work, much less as a high-value Urgent Caregiver.Sincere thanks to Dr. Denny and RN, Tom, and the Radiology Team for their care and professionalism.

Their billing is a NIGHTMARE and I have an accounting degree. I get 2-3 statements a month for the SAME ACCOUNT and they never show my payments. I was just on the phone with them for an hour. I printed out copies of my receipts and they don't care! They want me to call my bank and have my bank FAX over proof of payment. What is the point of having receipts if you can't trace them back? And what is the point of sending incomplete statements with outstanding balances I paid months ago? AVOID THEM IF YOU CAN.

Horrible hospital and the people who work there do not care about your well-being. The only thing these leeches care about is your money. I just had an IV put in my arm from an allergic reaction to Amoxicillin and one of the nurses comes to ask me how I'm going to pay for the co-pay and if she can have my card right now. Unprofessional to say the least. I think the proper way to ask would be when I feel better and am ready the leave. The doctor (asian male) also didn't seem to believe me when I told it was because of the Amoxicillin nor did he seem to hear me when I said the whole-body, super hot rash didn't itch. I receive a prescription for 3 medications including cortisol for the imaginary itching. A week or two later received a bill for a ridiculous amount of money for what they actually did (pump saline through my veins, grudgingly show me the bathroom, and keep the curtains open in my "section" so I had no personal privacy while changing. Peepers anyone?Oh, and guess what? Some time later ANOTHER bill came in the mail demanding MORE money this time for the doctor's fee! What was he, a freelance consultant!? This "hospital" and their ways are absolutely ridiculous. DO NOT GO HERE!

I arrived yesterday in San Francisco. Unfortunately, I unexpectedly needed urgent medical care. My hotel concierge recommended St. Francis, and they had a cab take me to the Emergency Room where I was checked in, taken into triage, seen by the RN and the ER doctor within 20 minutes of arriving. Â Everyone there was kind, highly professional and were very motivated to help me. Â Christine, RN and Dr. Chen-Luftig were beyond awesome. Â They were very attentive to my needs and reported Â lab results in a timely fashion, continually communicating to me regarding my condition. I left there feeling better and knew I had been cared for by an absolutely superior team. Â Thank you all so much!!!

AVOID THIS HOSPITAL!! If I could give negative 100 stars I would!I've traveled around the world and has visited clinics & General Hospital, and St Francis Memorial Hospital is the WORST and most RIDICULOUS hospital ever. I had food poisoning and went to the hospital to see a doctor as I needed a doctor's cert to postpone my flight back home. I waited 3 hours in a consultation room because there was only 1 doctor on duty that night. Finally the doctor was free to see me for 5mins after my husband had to constantly ask if we can be seen so I can go back to the hotel to rest. The doctor was brisk, unfriendly and distracted because she's overworked. She gave me a bunch of paper on how to take care of my condition. Well, thank you! I could have googled the information for free! I was given 3 pills and told to go to the pharmacy the next day. The pharmacist told me that the drugs I was prescribed is a strong narcotics used for patients who just went for surgeries and it's too potent for my condition! I guess the doctor was really try to make me stoned before I went to pay for the bill so I won't balk at the amount. Because since I am a tourist, I was told I have to pay the final bill of USD615 in full because they are unable to contact my travel insurance company on my behalf as it is not a local USA company. That's a crazy amount! No blood tests, no x-ray, no drips.. nothing! Well, since I could claim from my travel insurance at a later date.. I just paid and left.But that's not the end of the story.. 1 month later, I received a mail (they sent it by post all the way from USA to Singapore!) from them saying that I owe them money! The total bill is actually USD1778 and I only paid a portion of it!WOW!!!I emailed them back and after a few back and forth emails, I was told the following:"We cannot estimate your price when you arrive via Emergency Room, everything is an estimate because the hospital has no knowledge on how many tests, supplies or recourses will be used, so based on this estimate we charge a portion upfront. We also do not charge based on time, regardless if you are seen for 5 minutes or 3 hours, the fee is a base charge for visit, I understand you didn't visit the pharmacy or any other test was performed, please understand that this is our pricing and is reviewed and approved based on market research that is done every year."USD1778 for 3 tablets and 5 mins of your doctor's time? Â Pricing based on market research? Extorting tourists for money, that's more like it! Even a high end hospital in Europe only charges around EUR300-600 for their emergency services which includes tests. This hospital is charging USD1778 for nothing! They must be rolling in cash! I wonder how much do they charge for serious cases? In the highs of ten thousands?My travel insurance will be covering for the costs (Thank God!) but I just felt really indignant that I was billed such a ridiculous amount for something so minor. It is blatant daylight robbery.Once again, AVOID AVOID AVOID and run the other way!

As an update to my previous review, Saint Francis is threatening me because they believe I owe them $15 for a copay. Except I have to pay a copay to see a doctor upon checking in. Since I paid in cash and lost the receipt (my mistake for actually trusting them), I will have to pay again.I sincerely hope this hospital goes under for their extortion and pitiful excuse for a financial department. I had a very good experience here. I was scheduled for surgery, it went ahead as scheduled and on time. The nursing staff were incredibly kind and let my parents into the recovery room to hang out with me for the 7 hours that I was recovering. Experiences differ but my experience was good.

As an in-patient in their burn unit my experience was mixed. I came in with severe burns and stayed in their burn unit for a couple weeks. During that time I observed some great people doing good work, and some not so great people doing things that had me concerned. I've worked in healthcare for a long time so I pay attention to things most people wouldn't pick up on. My first observation after surgery was that my room was never cleaned by housekeeping. They just came in and did a quick "trash and dash". My housekeeper did not wear gloves when handling items such as trash or biohazards waste, and they did not use hand sanitizer or wash their hands when coming in and out of the patient's rooms. This concerned me based on the threat of infection and these folks were containing the entire place with everything surface they touched. I noticed most of the RN's using good hand hygiene, but I also noticed a few who did not.I really appreciated the guidance and feedback I received from the physical therapist's assigned to the burn unit. Being bed ridden for most of your stay is no fun, and these folks did a wonderful job and really benefit each patient they interact with. I had one RN make derogatory comments about me directly in front of my family members. (I still have no idea what her problem is/ was or what I did to offend her)As an out patient my experiences weren't much better. During my first appointment I was forced to wait in the waiting room for 90 minutes beyond my appointment time. Then the doctor rushed in and exited just as quickly. His entire exam lasted less that 30 seconds. My second appointment followed suit, where I waited for more than an hour after my scheduled appointment, before I got fed up and left and abandoned my care plan. The burn unit has some really great people, but they have several issues as well. Therefore I would not recommend them with a lot of confidence.

I chose the surgeon, who is stellar, and followed him to St Francis... but I would never choose this hospital to have overnight care after surgery.San Francisco has many excellent choices, but this is not one of them.The hospital staff is not evil or unkind... they are just clueless as to the service and care that they ought to be providing.The surgery prep nurses were fine.It is the In patient (overnight) nursing staff that is awful.I would not want to be at this hospital if I could not fend for myself.

The medical service was fine, if a bit institutional, but the billing has been a horrific nightmare. Â went in for one visit to Nicholas Mast, Ortho surgeon. I was billed for three separate charges. Wow. What a bad experience. I came in for outpatient surgery. My surgeon and anesthesiologist were great. Everything else was horrible. The pre op nurse hardly looked at me. I ate bad oyster and diarrheal so I visited San Francis Memorial Hospital emergency room at 3/27/2014. The nurse tried to do a blood test for me. However, he was inexperienced and unprofessional. After I returned to home, both of my arms were bruising for a month. One of the nurses visited and said, "Since you told other nurses you are not willing to do any more drip, we have stopped your drip." However, I didn't say anything to any nurses about that. The information was totally from nowhere! I told the nurse that I didn't understand what she meant since I didn't say anything. She challenged me "are you sure you didn't say that?!" My family was with me for the whole time, and we didn't say anything about that for the whole time. After two weeks, no response. I followed up again, she said that they can't provide any discount.

Avoid this hospital unless your life depends on it and it's the closest emergency room to you.The emergency room, specifically the individual rooms and bathrooms are filthy. I actually had a really bad experience with radiology one day. Circumstances aligned to make a terrible day worse. Mercury was probably in retrograde. But this review isn't about that. I received a survey in the mail and I filled it out honestly about my experience. I asked to be contacted. A week or two went by and Tara Piazza, who is the new supervisor in the radiology department, reached out to me with compassion, a plan to rectify the situation, and a sincere promise to do better. I was very impressed with her follow up, the fact that she didn't let me fall through the cracks, and that she helped us get to a satisfactory resolution. Stellar service recovery on the part of Tara. I'd go back to St. Francis despite my first experience based on her service.

I previously wrote a review about my experience in the hospital. This review is specifically for the Acute Rehab department at St Francis. I was very fortunate to be able to get in here and really can't say enough good things about the people here! Wonderful, caring, supportive, kind. I Â don't see how i would have managed without them! I actually enjoyed being here and was quite sad to leave. I still come over to visit sometimes just because i love them.

Such a scam. Had to go to the emergency room twice here and had to dispute charges for both visits (one on 12/4/15 and one on 12/6/15). After completing my dispute on 12/6 I received documents saying my charges had been lowered and I paid them. Found out today that are saying I still owe the full amount on both visits. Beyond frustrating dealing with this hospital.

With such a big hospital, this review obviously misses on most of the departments. This place really is in shambles.I went here with a work's comp issue back in 2001. Fast forward to 2014 and I get a bill in the mail for it!!! I called them and the accounts department were totally incompetent claiming I need to pay a bill that was paid years ago! Two weeks later I get a generic mass mailing saying they had a problem and sent lots of people old bills! This hospital is seriously backwards.

This review is for the ER at St. Francis. As far as ER experiences go, I didn't have a terrible one when I was there last night. I was there about 3 hours, which included nurse triage, x-rays, and finally seeing the doctor. They did tell me upfront it was busy, so I was prepared to wait. Saw the nurse after maybe only 30-45 mins and she gave me ice while I waited (sprained my ankle badly). X-rays got done another hour or so after that, finally got in a room after another hour, and saw the doctor some 20-30 mins later. My main complaint now is that they have a policy that they will not under no circumstances call a prescription in to a pharmacy. I left their around 9:45pm last night with a prescription for pain medicine, which I would very much love to have right now. I'm at home unable to walk (unable to go to the pharmacy) and unable to have someone pick up my prescription for me since they won't call it in. Very frustrating. I'm going to need someone to first come to my apartment, take my Rx to the pharmacy, then bring it back. Completely unnecessary. It's for Motrin. What is the big deal. :(

The worse hospital I been to. Hell getting here and then I go into the garage and the guy in there with broken english tells me just the ER can get vailadated for parking, wrong after I just parked in Valet! Tuh, and was there for 3 hrs to see someone! Glad when this is over!

I was severely burned on my hands, sitting in the ER. An enormous male nurse comes in to give me a painkiller and drop off a jug for, well, what you do in a jug in bed in a hospital. He hands me the jug, puts the syringe in his pocket and walks away. The man kept the fentanyl that was supposed to be injected into my IV. I never took my eyes off of him.I reported him to the nurse in charge who called me a liar and then rushed to get me discharged when I asked her to call the police to report the theft of narcotics.

This is on behalf of radiology. My husband is being discharged today after hip surgery with Dr. Mast. Everyone has been excellent from surgeon, anesthesia, nurses, PT, Xray tech...I am a nurse and I give everyone we came into contact with 5 stars!!! Excellent care!!!

Got a simple X-ray and was charged 12 times the amount quoted by my insurance. Called the hospital for an explanation and got sent to 3 different billing departments without getting a proper explanation other than "that's how much we charge and it's set in stone". Bad customer service, unreasonable pricing, not planning to go back any time soon.

Unfortunately, I had a visit to the ER. Alex and Irene were amazing. Waking up in a hospital, I was petrified and anxious -- they both worked together to make sure I was healthy, understand the root cause, and also offered a significant level of empathy and compassion, which made all the difference. Thank you so much.

This is for the emergency room. I came here for really bad food poisoning. I was attended to fairly quickly and most the staff were really nice. There are a lot of homeless people here as stated in other reviews. One huuuge thing is that this place It is filthy and smells so bad. Horrible experience. Â I had a deep gash on my forehead. Â They didn't even do anything for it except put a bandaid on my face. Â They ended up charging my insurance $1500 and I had to pay over $200 out of pocket. Â Very dishonest hospital...they should be ashamed of themselves.

Was charged $500 for bloodwork that would have cost $50 elsewhere (I checked a number of places after the fact). Â Did not find out what the cost was until I Â received the bill a month later. my experience with the outpatient admitting registration department was an example of ineptness and indifference. i spent 30 minutes - not waiting, but engaged in the process of simply trying to register for some very ordinary blood tests (it literally took a half an hour to complete). the collective indifference by the employees at the outpatient registration desk(s) was stunning and scary considering this is a medical environment. i will need to return to have one of the tests repeated as my doctor implies a mistake may have been made in the lab concerning the result. considering the circumstances of my visit as noted above - i intend upon following up with the hospital joint commission, if true.
St. Francis emergency room is ran by prison guards. Jamie RN ? is in the wrong place. All black people are not drug addicted. Now run and tell that.
Thank you PACU and the 10th floor nurses. Nurse karen B. Rose and eva from the floors. They treated me with respect, while a was recovering from a total hip replacement this month

I have been going to St. Francis for several years now to see the doctors in the Sports Medicine practice. NOTE that this review is for the hospital, NOT the doctors in Sports Medicine. I love the doctors and their practice.Sadly, I cannot go to see those wonderful doctors anymore. Every time I go, I seem to get billed 3 times or more. One bill is from the doctor, but the rest are for various odds and ends the hospital charges for you being there. I keep getting bill after bill in the mail, and I keep paying them, because, well, do I have a choice?I had a relatively routine foot surgery at St. Francis, and it cost me all-told about $6,500. Again, bill after bill kept showing up, and I kept paying them, and finally at the end of the year, I added it all up. I was shocked. Go ahead and try to talk to them about the billing, or what the charges are for, and they will give you a back and forth with the doctor's office that will make you just give up.So, my recommendation is to stick with a hospital that is transparent with their billing. This place is not, and I think it is safe to say that it's the most expensive hospital in San Francisco.

Very shady billing practices. After treatment the receptionist said my medical bill for my wife's emergency room visit was $1100 and could possibly be even more. The receptionist then demanded that I pay half right away. I did not know at the time I was not legally obligated to pay any kind of estimate until the claim was fully looked at and calculated by my insurance, which was weeks later. I was more concerned with my wife being okay. This hospital was only legally entitled to the $100 copay for an emergency room visit as stated in my wife's blue shield plan. They charged me $500 that day. When I finally got the bill from Blue Shield, I only owed $100 out of pocket, as stated in the blue shield plan documents. If your plan has a set copay for any type of service, do not pay more than that copay even if the the hospital demands it. It is against California law for them to refuse emergency services due to non payment. Pay your copay and only pay what your insurance actually determines you are supposed to pay. Don't let a hospital tell you otherwise, no matter how demanding they are in asking.
Elite 2021

Common wisdom has it that you can get away with all that rough and tumble physical stuff when you're young. Maybe. But the dues you pay later...whoa! So here I am at later, in a moment of almost meditative motion when in comes the dues collector.Snake-arms are a fun - beautiful, even - Â part of bellydance vocabulary. So, I'm minding my own beeswax, imagining (laugh if you must) that I'm Goddess of Time and Change, Kali doing her damn dance. My arms (all twenty) are waving in the air - snakes, if you would. Mesmerizing, terrifying, yet...alluring... I was rudely awakened from this little reverie when one of my 'snakes' hissed. Loudly. I was alarmed, bummed, etc. when I realized that the hissing was actually me, booking an extended stay in Pain City. Ice, heat, limited movement, anti-inflammatories, nothing interrupted THE PAIN. Â Then, over a period of a few weeks, the whole arm/shoulder gizmo started to lock down.Well, nothing's gonna get in the way of my shimmy-shimmy-shangalang for too long, m'kay?!!A check in with my regular doc at East Bay Family Practice and a referral later, St. Francis was on the list of physical therapy possibilities covered by my insurance. Saint Francis Memorial Hospital is okay as General Hospital go (see previous review on the hospital overall) and thanks to physical therapists like Len and Sarah, the SFMH physical therapy department rules! Physical Therapy is located up on the 11th floor and shares space with sports medicine. They have pilates equipment, bright digs, Â and plenty natural light streaming in. There's pervasive air of competence and well-being that some how translates into me feeling cool about coming here as opposed to feeling like a loser for having effed up my body (again).I drug my (increasingly) Hunchback of Notre Dame ass on in. Enter Sara and Len. Positives: They both talk to me about what they're doing and why. Joking and laughter are part of the deal if you like (and about the only way I can get through some of Â the pain on the way to cure) I get CHOICES...well...most of the time. Sara always has this little House of Pain thing she apparently MUST do in the funny-bone-I-never-knew-existed area at the top of my rib cage to get things started. Drat!Occassionally, my inner-2-year-old even gets possessive when I must wait my turn. Outside I'm going "Oh, that's fine, I know I'm early, I'll just read" but the inner brat is squealing, "NO! MY therapy! GO AWAY, stinky poo-poo head!" Most importantly pain has gone from a 7 (out of 10 OW-ees) down to a 1.5 and will hopefully be a 0 before long. Pretty damn good for a little over a month with even some modified snake action thrown in. Â I honestly thought I was gonna have to hang up my belly dance pants for good when I got started, but the snakes are back in effect and with the info I got from Len along with the ice, stim and assorted therapeutic hands-on I got from both him and Sarah, I'm almost out the door.Ah! I almost forgot. Â The ONLY reason this isn't a five Â star deal is probably something that can't be helped. Scheduling appointments can be a headache. If you ain't quick (and even a leetle beet pushy) it can be hard to get in Â the requisite amount of therapy due to lots of other people wanting the same great treatment in the same great place. Natch.
I work there and know first hand that it is not the place to go and yes I quit.

Terrible experience all around at the ER for a Kidney Stone emergency, with the following low lights:- When I arrived at the ER, the taxi driver went in to ask if someone could come out with a wheelchair. 10 minutes later, when no one came out, I decided to (gingerly) walk in on my own rather than waiting- Even though I'm doubled over in pain, registration couldn't have been less caring. They were very casual and more focused on getting my email address than actually getting me to a doctor.- Three house into the visit, the nurse lets me know that drinking is the most important thing I can do. Meanwhile I've been off an IV and not given anything to drink for 2 hours.- Frequently the curtain was drawn and no one checked in, so they had no idea how I was doing- After three hours of almost constant pain and nausea, they let me know that I'll need to leave because they need the bed. A doctor, who I hadn't seen until then asks what they can do for me, which totally mixes me up because I've been there for hours. She comes up with the brilliant idea of giving me pain killers. Of course I've been on pain killers for hours, which hasn't helped. She then asks a few more silly questions before letting me know that she doesn't know anything about my case. I'm amazed that she hasn't taken a moment to get background info before spouting nonsense to someone in a great deal of pain.- That doctor, along with my nurse, who has constantly been contradicted by others in the ER, then let me know that I'll be safer in my hotel than the ER, so I should check out. Keep in mind that it's 1 am, I'm still in pain / nauseous and have challenges walking. So, I'm amazed that they think it'll be safer for me to walk to get a taxi, take a 20+ minute taxi ride to a 24 hour pharmacy, wait 20+ minutes for medication, take a 20+ minute taxi ride back to the hotel, walk through the hotel to end up in a room by myself rather than being in their ER!!!!! In the end, given how bad my experience was in the ER, I decided that I would actually be safer on my own.- They didn't prescribe Flowmax, so the kidney stone took longer to pass- Three days after leaving, my pain killer prescription was out. I tried to speak with a doctor at the ER about extending my prescription a few days, since my understanding is that they sometimes prescribe up to 7 days of medication, but the receptionist refused to let me speak with a doctor and hung up on me.JUST A TERRIBLE EXPERIENCE!!!!!!!!!

Top notch ER and overall people at this hospital. Lots of humanity and touch among everyone I dealt with in various other departments as well; they get the combo of quality care, timeliness, and bedside manner. A+

Went to the ER here. The doctors and nurses I interacted with were spectacular, but the intake staff made my visit stressful and difficult. The employee who took my information was rude and condescending. They also wrote down my information wrong, leading to my bill being sent to someone else, and me almost being late on paying it.

ER visit for our son while we were on vacation. Â We were very pleased at the care he received. Â The ER was literally empty on our "visit". Â Everything turned out okay for him and released soon after. Â It did take a while for the doctor to check on him, but I think that's the way it goes these days in health care.

Pros: the triage nurse was so sweet and brought me a phone charger when my phone died, another nurse brought me food when I was hungry, and they correctly diagnosed my blood clot.Cons: the whole process took over 4 hours
Elite 2021

OK, it's a little weird to be writing a review of an Emergency Room, but we had a good experience, so I thought I'd share.We took my mother in law in to the Emergency Room because she had chest pain - turned out to be pneumonia. Â From check in time, we waited only about 5 minutes before the triage nurse examined her. Â It was a few minutes later that we were brought inside and she was hooked up to IV's and started to settle in. Â She was seen by several nurses and a hospitalist within a short amount of time. Â Everyone was nice and polite, the facility was clean, and we were able to get a private room in the ER. Â The doctor was a little terse, but I suppose that's forgivable, given that she was not in imminent danger.We spent about 6 hours in the ER before she was transferred to a room upstairs. Â Spent 2 nights in the hospital, and overall, I think she was well cared for. Â Definitely needed to remind some of the medical staff a few times ("You unhooked her IV so she could eat dinner; she needs to be hooked up again."), but I don't think they were being remiss or unattentive (just busy).Overall, a quality experience, and if I had to choose an emergency room again in SF, I would probably put St Francis at the top of the list. Â (I don't have any other ER experiences to draw from, but this one was entirely positive.)All that said, we had a followup question about the medication she was given after discharge, and was not able to reach the prescribing doctor at all. Â So, wish that part of the experience were better.

The goodDr. BlakefriendlylistensniceThe Badsometimes wait an hour to see DR.sol orthotics Â made feet Â worsesuperfeet made feet better black dpm modeloffice staff absolutely the worst. do not listen to them when they saythey are preferred and $25 copay and parking is easy in the garagewhich is always full:))))))lolbilling a nightmare be careful WARNINGPHCS is not $25 co pay lilke office and insurance tell u because of funky hospital billing get ready to pay big:)also now i am hearing hospital is not preferred and yes even though its a Dr. visit like every other clinic u get dinged by st. Francis:))) gotta luv it...

Early this week I had severe headache and high fever so I rushed into the ER. I was diagnosed with meningitis and hospitalized. I will review the ER and the Hospital separately.Bare in mind this is my first ER&Hospital encounter in the US so I can't compare.ERThe wait time was very good. I was seen by a doctor in around 15mins or less. Everyone was very polite and professional. They did a lot of tests, even a spinal tap and I think they did an amazing job. Within few hours I was diagnosed with meningitis (a very rare disease) and hospitalized. Overall rating of ER - 5/5. Fast, efficient, everyone very friendly (doctors, nurses, administration).HospitalI was hospitalized in a private room and I asked if my wife can be with me. They agreed and even provided a bed for her so she can sleep next to me, which was a great deal of relief for me, given that this was my first time being hospitalized and it was for a disease that had 37% mortality rate. Just allowing my most loved person to be with me made a world of difference for my emotional state. The room was small, but clean and they provided me with blankets, pillows, personal hygiene accessories, TV and free high speed wifi. I had a private bathroom and shower too.The nurses were great. Very friendly, always asked me if I need anything, if I am in pain etc. I noticed that calling for a nurse will sometimes take them long time to come (like 15-30min) but I guess they were just very busy.My biggest complaint would be the bed - it SUCKED! Prior to they hospitalization I had a spinal tap procedure which has super strong headache as a side effect. The bed was so uncomfortable that in a few hours my back would hurt more than my head and let me tell you - the head hurts a lot! I could barely sleep around 2hrs at night because of the bed.Anyways I was discharged yesterday and overall, while the whole thing was a terrible experience the nurses and doctors at Saint Francis Memorial Hospital did a fantastic job!!!

Absolutely horrible experience. I went in for knee replacement surgery, I was not given a shower for days, nothing to relieve the constipation caused by morphine, a nurse who could not find my veins after 4 jabs-left the needle in my arm and walked out. Another nurse, Marylou would not bring pain medicine for nearly two hours when I was suffering terribly. No instructions were given to me by the "pain doctor" how to taper off morphine nor given a semi opiod to transition from morphine. I have filed a complaint about him with the state medical board and he is being investigated.. The doctor on duty changed my blood pressure medicine without consulting me and refused to have the staples removed until the day I left the hospital. I became so sick after quitting morphine that my electrolytes went out of balance, I was completely dehydrated from morphine withdrawal and had to be rehospitalized. Â If you still go to this hospital, have an advocate with you at all times! You have been warned.

I had patient care under my own dime in Walnut Creek at a Podatrist. Â The doctor I saw in Walnut Creek was awesome Dr. Hyatt! Â However the billing department is NOT. Â I have been waiting for six weeks after paying my bill in full, and taking their applicable discounts off my total amount and paid by credit card. Â six weeks later I'm still getting bills saying I owe the discount but when I call them they say I don't owe it! Â This is the way credit ratings get bad! Â I called four separate occasions to have this removed and they all said it was happening, then today I got another bill. Â This Hospital is great on sending out bills and not crediting you for what you paid. Â I help for this supervisor and that supervisor and finally got to an Operations Manager. Â Everyone up to him was rude and not helpful. Â I hope to NEVER attend this hospital for any reason.

This hospital has an extortionate pricing model. Â My wife went to her podiatrist, then needed to get a toe x-ray. Â They could not tell her the cost in advance. Â Later, we were sent a bill for over $800 for the toe x-ray, more than 5 times the median cost in San Francisco. Â  When we disputed this charge, they never responded and sent the account to a collections agency. Â When I called they claimed to have reached out to us via phone, but we never received any messages. Â They also said they do not send anything in writing regarding a dispute, but told me verbally that price is not a valid dispute. Â I guess we are lucky they decided not to charge us $5,000.

Came into San Francisco for New Years.Had some low back issues, but who doesn't.Woke up New Years Eve morning and felt ok.Had room service, stood up and Wham!Dropped to my knee's and Â my wife needed to call 911.Arrived at St Francis, took a minute or two.Got the room, nurse came in.I was being treated before I was really signed it.They made sure I was comfortable and, they controlled the pain very well.They arranged an MRI and, only would take me once I felt comfortable to go.I was never rushed for anything.I was made as comfortable as possible.The doctor explained the MRI results very well.He even gave me some RX's for the ride back to Orange County CA.While I can't say, it was what I wanted to do in SF while visiting.They really did an exceptional job in treating me.I greatly appreciate the service and professionalism. Thanks very much Â St. Francis.

pretty good ER. very easy access from Marin by boat, ferry or water taxi - quicker and more pleasant than the dreaded big General Hospital like Marin General etc. I had to come here for Kidney stones, not fun but you may as well make the best of it. They do not have telephones or any T-Mobile coverage which makes for a real panic situation for family, however if you are conscious they will give you WiFi and a lap top so you can get in touch with family plus you can roll out to a phone some time if you are not tied to an IV. They have TVs in the "room" where you can watch the Giants.Even better - this place is hospital to the SF Giants and I just had a sighting!!! Everybody is all excited. But I don;t know much about baseball except that it was one of the Giants fellows.If they had phones or iPhone chargers or open WiFi I would give them 5 stars; If I didn't have kidney stones I would give them 10000 stars but what can ya do.Lap top is key to entertain you as it is really unpleasant listening to all the suffering going on in the ER including my own. Thanks to the nice staff here for fixing up the boo-boos
don't have a feeding tube inserted here in the ER. Â I don't think they train their ER docs to do this procedure. Â Mom's pleural cavity punctured and lung partially collapsed.

This review is as a result of balances going back to 2009 which remain unresolved at this time, and two letters have been forwarded to the entire senior management of Dignity Health and St Francis. Â No Response! Â One of them was a balance with a date of service in excess of 10 years and the incorrect insurance carrier. Â It was later found that this was indeed a billing error. Â Close to a year has passed and no response, Some of these balances were forwarded to Grant and Weber, their collection agency; and to no avail and I find this agency has more than 40 cases filed with the Better Business Bureau and the Attorney General's Office.All the work was done at the Sports Medicine Center. If you have a similar story, let me know. Â Thanks!

Avoid their ER, they upcode like crazy (bill your insurance and you for a higher level of service than is actually provided). I got a $3k bill for a quick ultrasound and about 5 minutes of discussion with the doctor - the $1,300 to perform and read the ultrasound was steep, but the $1,800 bill for the ER visit to have the doctor to poke me in the leg a few times and give his opinion was inexcusable (and wait a few hours in between his visiting other patients). I'm going to avoid all Dignity Health (the management company) General Hospital from now on.
Had a minor incident while traveling in San Francisco. Â Received excellent care at St. Francis ER. Â Love the team and great Doctor who knows how to make people feel comfortable.

If you are unfortunate enough to get badly burned and have to go to the SF Burn unit consider yourself blessed. It's a state of the art facility with the most wonderful staff you could ever imagine. Unfortunately the rest of the hospital I'm giving 1 star only Â because I don't have an option of giving a zero.

This hospital is horrible. My mother went in emergency for possible stoke. When she explains her symptoms to the staff and doctors. Dr. Sun and the RN laughed like it was a joke. The new doctor came and my mom explains again her pain and he wants to prescribe her stomach medication. She refused and said she's not hurting her stomach. No one came by to change her and let her urinated on herself. I had to help her with everything. This is a terrible place. They definitely do not care about you and your health. This hospital used to be a great hospital 10 years ago. If you want great service, try to avoid here.

All the stars. I was stitched up here recently. I can personally attest to the quality and craftsmanship of the work. I had great rapport with the physicians and administrative staff. I've never had such a fun time visiting the emergency room. And on a personal note, their gauze is incredible. I'll definitely be coming back!

IF YOU CARE ABOUT THE MEDICAL ATTENTION YOU OR A LOVE ONE RECIEVES, DO NOT COME HERE!!!This review is for the emergency room. I don't know how many people believe that the administration staff is the face of the company. Well I do. I've done plenty of admistrative work and worked with many wealthy people to know this. My review is on the poor service I received from Carmen with the glasses, who sits in the front and the reason why I or anyone else I care about Â will never be attending this medical facility again, if I can help it. I'm fortunate I can make this decision thanks to a wonderful PPO plan. Lets start with arriving after my mom's anxiety attack and her temporary memory loss. Fast forward...Dr. Pearl sees my mom. (She was fine. Not the best... but fine...nothing wrong with her.) Then...Carmen comes in asking my mom to sign liability papers and financial agreement papers. I ask Carmen, what are these and may I sign these for her, I'm her daughter and she is hysterical and incoherent right now. Carmen says sure. (Does anyone think this is wrong?!?!?!....My mom has temporary memory loss - medical term transient global amnesia..she was in no position to fill out anything because for the rest of her life she will not remember this event.)Then I'm wondering why this was given to me while I'm in the ER... don't know if this has happened to any on you...but its never happened to me in an ER before. I asked Carmen and she got defensive. Then I asked may I read them. She says sure while she is watching me like a hawk. This liability form had numbers on it. She was already turned to the last one before explaining to me what I needed to sign. She had papers there that a patient is not suppose to see in that clipboard due to HIPPA regulations. However, before handing me this she should have explained that to me and not snatch it out of my hand. Not only that then she told me I owed her $50. I know for a fact that I don't pay for anything for any visit until insurance bills me. Something was definitely wrong right here because 2 weeks later the bill arrived and I owed less than the $50 she claimed I owed. Next day I called her manager Priscilla who did not return my phone call until I escalated this issue about patient care to her director which means 3 days later. I'm sorry but if you care about the medical attention you receive it will have to be elsewhere. I'm not sure where but this place is simply not it. This hospital use to cater to the elite of Nob Hill and Pac Heights but that has long since changed.

This hospital by far Â gets a 1 at the most. I can't vocalize enough the experience my mom and my family has been put through. My mom was admitted last Tuesday, no one person contacted family members to let us know she was there. My mother of course didn't want us to worry so she kept silent. Â Found out Friday night she was going to have surgery the next day. No one could tell us in detail what was going on. Where does the line of communication start???Following day, surgery then my mother was moved to another floor. This was only the beginning. Last Saturday until today when my mom was discharged, it was frustrating and the level of service provided by the few nurses themselves, Mary, Rose, Sigrid and Susan on the 6th floor did not care about my mom's well being being her first major surgery. I am appalled by their attitude and it could be they were selective of whom they chose to give their attention to. I felt like we were being discriminated because of our color and asking the most simple requests. No sympathy for the condition my mom was in. How many times did we push the nurse call button and no one came until my mom rolled out of bed herself, laying there in pain and no meds yet, going to the nurse station and not even a pleasant "how can I help you", asking a general question such as a cup or even to substitute a food, everyone carried on doing their own thing. At times, they would speak in their own language, nod their head or roll their eyes then laugh while I am staring right at them! I knew they were irritated with me but I didn't care.
