That's their freaking job!!! If you don't enjoy what your doing, go somewhere else! Less talking and sitting on your ass and more support. I do wonder if they were in my situation, where would their comfort level be and when is enough is enough!As days gone by with me being there daily watching every single move, it got worse and worse. My mother was starving, started with ice, then the last 2 days before discharge, just clear liquids. I understand it all depends on the doctor's recommendation. Even the on call surgeon whom did the surgery had no intention to meet the family or consult with us about the procedure. Shocking but true. Gave us no answers to questions we had. Said he didn't care if we want to go with a second opinion meaning he doesn't care about the patient! My mother was lying in her own feces!!! No one nurse wanted to deal with her or cleaning her up. My mother wiped herself. I watched and seeped as I saw how my mother was being treated. Trust beyond this level is not highly suggested. The staff does not provide Dignity Health Care, it is their paycheck they are there for!!! Unbelievable...The doctor even wrote up painkillers that contained an allergy reaction my mom would be affected by. How is that??? I will make sure my mom receives the best care moving forward. It was their job to keep my mom comfortable, safe and attended to as with other patients. I would never place any family member in this environment. Pr

I had surgery done here in Jan. 2013 and all I have to say is, when getting treatment here, be on your toes. Do not be afraid to speak up if you need something, if something hurts or feels uncomfortable, and certainly if you know something should be done a certain way. If you are discharged and have any questions, call your doctor or the hospital and do not rest until you get an answer. They will not offer information. In terms of administration, the right hand did not know what the left hand was doing. I have had 3 surgeries now and CPMC is better. Good thing those surgeries preceded this one so I knew what is supposed to happen.

I sprained my ankle at 9:30 PM on New Years Eve, and needed to go to the Emergency Room. Anyone familiar with the Emergency Room (my mom worked in one my entire life) knows that most Emergency Rooms don't have a great turnaround time. I made it to the Emergency Room at 10PM, certain that I would be ringing in the New Year from a bed in the Emergency Room.Surprisingly, that was not the case.The staff worked incredibly hard to get me out of there, and back on my feet, as quickly as possible. I've never seen hospital staff work so hard, and so quickly, to help an individual patient who didn't have a life threatening injury. By 11:30 I had gotten x-rays, crutches, and a boot for my ankle, and I was already out the door and headed to meet my friends to enjoy a great evening. Words cannot express the gratitude I feel to the staff for their dedication. I've been in more emergency rooms than I can count, throughout my life, and this was by far the best experience I've ever had in one, despite the fact that it's the worst injury I've ever had to be treated for. This was my first time at this hospital, and hopefully my last, but if I'm ever injured in San Francisco again I will definitely be going back here

I'm a chef and had to visit the E.R. with the worst laceration of my career thus far. Â Dr. Â Chari was not only extremely skilled and proficent with her sutures but she showed caring and charisma that before now I had not seen in an ER setting. Â RN Suzanne Â was kind informative and very helpful. Â All in all I recommend this ER over any other in town.

I just wanted to write a review THANKING Saint Francis BILLING DEPARTMENT for their willingness and dedication to patient billing...Sure, it may have cost me $700 (and my insurance even more) to tell me that a tampon can not get 'stuck' or go beyond the cervix...but hey! At least when I forget to pay, they call me to remind me...They also send monthly statements - unlike other General Hospital - who put me into collections after we make a payment arrangement but I never get an updated statement or reminder or call or anything! Thank you billing department. Keep up the good work on trying not to destroy patient's credit and due diligence on updating records, phone numbers, account balances and doing what a billing department is supposed to do.

My friends ended up driving me to the ER at his hospital, after a huge car accident -- the 18 wheel big rig that smashed into my compact rental car never bothered to stop after the collision. The pain was so severe that it made me cried so my friends drove me to this hospital, after much cajoling. The front desk, doctors and nurses were very professional and nice. As it turned out, after a battery of tests, the doctors discovered that I had contracted a food-borne illness, which was why my abdomen felt like it was about to explode and causing me to experience nausea and vertigo. I would give the hospital ER a higher rating but for the X-rays and CT scan technician, who took no pity of me -- a grown man in tears from the pain and unable to move (the doctors drugged me to calm me down and to relax my muscles). I had the chills. I was pushed into a very cold metal tray that was used to push me into the CT scanner and they shot me up with dye (which made my blood vessels boil) -- the most horrific experience and I'm wearing a hospital robe with nothing under it. I guess when you are trying to get the best possible CT scans, the technician has to take charge and be, well, merciless. I sure wouldn't want to wish this upon my worse enemy -- CT scan is not fun, especially when you are at your weakest. I feel bad for anyone who has to get a CT or CAT scan. But it's necessary and I just wish the process was more gentle.Everyone is nice and kind. Â I was surprised at how many regular patients in this ER seemed to be local homeless people who check themselves into the ER for minor treatment and often for some food. Â The staff are wonderful about this and know the regulars and treat them with dignity and do give them food.

never in my LIFE did i think i would have to walk myself into the emergency room of a hospital gasping for breath...... to preface this, I will admit to having extremely bad allergies to dust, pollin, etc. when in extreme, these allergies turn into asthma. After a week of practically OD'ing on my inhaler (which wasn't working!) I could feel my asthma just getting worse. This developed into a deep hacking cough which scared the sh*t out of my coworkers. Which in turn left me unable to sleep...... and also a little delirious. Well, I'm tough so ignored the asthma and waited for it to go away. Didn't happen. Fast forward to last week..... I was walking home like an 80 yr old gasping and wheezing for breath at every corner. I felt like my head was going to explode from coughing. People were openly gawking and staring at me..... I knew the time had come. It took me about 3 hours but I finally made it up Pine Street and stopped at my place to tell my roommate that I might die soon and I'll be at St Francis should anyone be looking for my remains. She valiantly offered a ride, but I declined not ready to be fully defeated yet....... I felt like a warrior as I hobbled up the hill slowly and proudly walked myself into the ER reception announcing I was having an asthma attack. I barely finished writing down my name when they whisked me in and started listening to my very constricting lung capacity. They quickly ushered me into the ER bull pen area, and wow, it was just like on TV! Cool. People were rushing around, ambulances were unloading gurneys of people, it was wild. The doctors and nurses were so nice and I felt bad about some of the "interesting" people they had to deal with. (One lady had come in from OD'ing on something and was screaming for someone to bring her a bottle of wine) The medical staff was fast, calm and they worked hard. I was exhausted watching. Dr Ross made me wear one of those ugly hospital dresses but he gave a pill to help me breathe and a little coedine syrup to suppress my cough.... so I compromised. he told me to hang out for a little bit and enjoy the show. It was quite a circus. Finally, after a few hours they let me leave and I walked out alive and feeling as good as new. Whew, now that was a close one. St Francis ER---if you have to go, it might as well be this one!

You've been going to the gym for about two weeks now, so it really doesn't surprise you when you accidentally shatter a red wine glass in your powerful grip. "Not bad" you'll mutter to yourself. "Oh my god your bleeding!" your manager will shriek.Look her in the eyes and say "I ain't got time to bleed". You really don't, because some dipshit just ordered six mojitos. Start muddling!"Oh Jesus Christ" your manager will go on. "That's gonna need some serious stitches!"Tell her "I ain't got time for stitches, I gotta keep my mind on my muthafuckin riches!" Grab your tips off the bar, smell them, then stuff them in your pocket. Don't forget to wipe the blood off of the bar. Do like in the movies and pour some whiskey over your shredded hand. Your pretty sure they do that to fuse the wound. Since you won't be able to stop screaming, and your hand is now both bloody and inflamed, you'll concede that maybe you should go to the ER. Because of the speed and ease of the checking in process, and the pills that one of your coworkers gave you for the pain, you'll be surprisingly at ease, as long as you don't look at your hand. "Describe your pain, on a level of one to ten" the nurse will ask you."The world is a triangle!" you'll blurt out. This phrase will surprise both you and the nurse, and you will stare at each other with equal looks of shock on your faces. You'll wonder what those goddamn pills you just ate were. From that point on, try to speak as little as possible. The nurse won't press you for conversation. The doctor will come in about half an hour, sew you up, and you're out the door! Fast and painless! You've got a pocket full of cash, a head full of mystery pills, and at least a week off. Congratulations, you're living the American Dream!

Fuck you St. Francis hospital. Â Thanks for the creepy ass doctor and the incompetent Asian nurse who couldn't speak English. Â Also thank you for the $400 charge for doing absolutely nothing to help me.

DO NOT GO HERE IF YOU CAN HELP ITMy friend was rushed here from a fire. He had been in an explosion and was brought to their burn unit. When I got there he was in the emergency room. The nurse attending to him was doing everything so half assed. He was just in an explosion, an explosion! He was in shock and not at all with it. She was annoyed with him and asking me if he was on drugs. Are you kidding me??? Have you ever heard of shock??? He needed to go to the bathroom and she just handed him something to go in and left him alone. It ended badly and she was upset that she had to clean up. I've never seen such awful help out of a nurse. Next he was moved up to the 10th floor to stay over night. When I got there he was asleep. The nurse came in and said he needed cream on his face. I tried to nicely wake him up as I knew he would be disoriented when he woke up. Instead of letting me do so, she loudly and abruptly started yelling at him that he needed to wake up for medicine. She then just started rubbing his head with cream. As he looked at me with pleading eyes not even knowing where he was, I had to calm him down and explain where he was and why. She had no concern for his well being what so ever and just wanted to get her rounds done. My friend lost his home and everything he owned in the explosion. He didn't even have the clothes on his back to go home in. He was obviously in shock and upset. I finally calmed him down and was getting him to sleep when the same nurse from earlier, Nef Abat, R.N. came in at 1 am. She needed to give him meds via his IV drip. Instead of calmly coming in and just quietly taking care of her job. She came in, turned on all the lights and loudly announced what she had to do at 1 am. She then proceeded to ask him if the police had talked to him and if the police had interrogated him and read him his rights. This nurse had no idea what happened to him or his story. She immediately upset him and confused him. He was then upset all over again, now thinking everything was his fault. Upon confronting her on her behavior, she became very upset and started to blame me. She said I had had a very bad day and that I was misinterpreting her actions. Asking my friend if the police had read him his rights for no reason at 1 am, I really don't think I was confused. I then spoke with her supervisor, who agreed that she shouldn't have had such a conversation with him. Though she agreed and tried to calm me down it was obvious my complaints were falling on deaf ears. The funny thing was that the other nurses were more than happy to help me get this nurse's name and the supervisor's name. It was very clear this nurse, Nef Abat, was a problem and she had some enemies for coworkers. Â My friend's brother also stayed with him at the hospital and when I wasn't there he had several run ins with other nurses as well. Please do not go here if you can help it. I've talked to other friends who have been here and they too have had horrible experiences.

By far the smoothest, easiest trip to the ER I've ever experienced.I cut my finger with an exacto knife at work, and after some encouragement from my coworkers, I headed over to St. Francis. There was NO ONE in the waiting room at 10am when I arrived. They got me in triage, then a room, and I was all stitched up and out of there by 10:45am. Glad it's so close to my house (4 blocks) if I ever have a true, scary emergency!

One star for charging me $1000 to take my blood when some quack 'THOUGHT' I might have Type 2 Diabetes. A blood test that took 15 minutes of work IN TOTAL.Guess what? I don't!!5 stars for Emergency Room visits. Â Twice I have been, and this staff doesn't make you wait and actually comfort you when your friend slices their hand open on a can or you have a 102 degree temperature and can't get cool by yourself again. But again, be prepared to pay a pretty penny. Overall, their billing department and the need to keep making these ridiculous charges is a obvious cry of funding help and two things need to happen;Either make the fat-cats take a pay cut or get a better accounting system to manage the bills better. Take it or leave it- 3 Yellow STARS.

DO NOT GO HERE IF YOU CAN HELP ITI went to St Francis ER one evening when I was having problems breathing. It turns out I had pneumonia but this was only discovered by my PCP on a followup visit. The doctor at the hospital said I was suffering an allergy. I was treated for a problem I didn't have an they failed to TREAT ME FOR THE PROBLEM I HAD.On arrival there was no-one around so I waited, around 12.30am I was 'checked-in' that is they wanted all my insurance details, nothing of the medical emergency was discussed until they had the insurance data. Once I had changed for the exam I was taken for an Xray and the equipment I was aasked to stand beside and hold was COVERED IN SOMEONE ELSE's BLOOD. COVERED IN SOMEONE ELSE's BLOOD. COVERED IN SOMEONE ELSE's BLOOD. No care, no apology no concern just LET ME RECHECK YOUR INSURANCE DETAILS. If only I had died then they could have been sued.

My doctor used the hospital to do a cervical spinal fusion surgery. Â Coming out of surgery I was in extreme pain. Â A mix-up in doctors' orders by the hospital staff severely restricted my access to pain medication as well as my regularly prescribed medications. Neither explanations from my GP or pain management doctors nor from me corrected the problems for over 24 hours. Â This caused me to be in extreme, unnecessary pain, and to miss critical therapeutic medication for a deadly disease whose resistance is increased if I miss doses of medication. Â I must admit that the night time nurses, both in the Critical Care Unit and the Post-Surgerical Care Unit were incredibly kind, attentive, and professional--it is a shame they are hamstrung by the non-functional hospital systems. Â However, the day time nurses in both these sections did not care about patient needs, but only about what was convenient for them to do. Â For non-critical illnesses it may be ok but I definitely would warn anybody who needs attentive care to stay away from this hospital at all costs.

I've actually been here a couple times.. First time was to get my blood tested. They were fast and friendly.. My second time was June 5, 2007.. The day I would never forget!It was another day at culinary school. I loved going to class, especially Plated desserts. The chef instructor was so HOT! I would never miss a day even if I was sick because we only had him for 6 weeks.. On June 5, 2007 @ 1:10pm, I was cleaning my knives and tools and was having a great day. Next thing you know, my SERRATED knife, for those that cook, you should know what that is, the knife with teeth, slid down my left hand between my thumb and pointing finger! Â You could see the inside of my fat tissue and blood was EVERYWHERE! I had to run to my partner and scream for a tissue! It was horrible! My hot chef runs over to me like a hero and grabs my hand with a tissue and clean towel and holds it tight.. I was crying but happy at the same time. He brings me to the office and calls a taxi for me so they can bring me to St Francis...Upon arrival, every one that worked there was really helpful and fast... not a long wait at all. We then went into the room with beds everywhere.. That was when the wait started.. I had to wait, for the LONGEST 2 hour of my life! I was waiting to get stitches.. I was getting irritated and didn't even want stitches but they said I really needed it so I stayed.. Thank goodness my partner was there to entertain me.. So during those two hours, we were just listening to whoever was next to us and their conversations about what happened to them.. Then it was my turn. Finally. The nurse was extremely nice and knew it was my first time getting stitches. She made me calm down and laugh. I was relaxed and my partner was recording me so I was laughing the whole time. The nurse made it painless for me. Thank You! Then another male nurse was wrapping me up.. I had asked him Â if they had Pink wrapping tape thingy and he said he wasn't sure. Next thing you know when we were about to leave. He comes and finds me just to give me a new roll of Pink wrapping tape! How sweet! I loved everything about St. Francis, especially the nurses! -1 star for taking 2 hours!

I went to the ER because I was having breathing issues and was very concerned. Well, after 3 hours, 1 xray, 1 EKG, being moved to 2 different beds, watching the 2 homeless fight in the waiting and having an old man trying to get my phone number, I got a bill for $3800. I'm responsible for $1700. Now the question remains: how will I pay for this bill? Not sure if they offer a payment plan or maybe they could give me a discount for not being able to use the restroom because the homeless people were taking turns locking themselves in it back and forth. Fun times!The staff was nice but this was such a different experience from the time I went to the same ER last year.

Hospitality was just as stellar on the day of my procedure. I was very scared. I ran into Joanie again, and she kindly guided me to where I needed to be. I felt better already. The nurses and doctors were comforting. From pre-op (painless IV, thanks!), to post-op, the procedure was simple, and over before I knew it! Even though it was the end of the work day, the staff was still supportive and engaged in helping me feel better. I was never rushed and got to take my time in recovery for as long as I needed. An assistant brought me to my cab and even stayed with me and my mom until they saw us off. Thank you St. Francis!
The quality of care at this hospital is phenomenal. The staff are well prepared, knowledgeable, and more importantly, they treat patients with care, attention, humanity and integrity.

This hospital has outgrown its check-in process. Â I normally don't fall for the everything-looks-new-so-people-must-be-good-at-their-jobs fallacy, but I do lose a little bit of confidence when I'm shuttled into a room to go over forms with someone whose all-in-one printer takes up literally one-quarter of his or her tiny office. Â (And yes, both offices I've stepped into have been dominated by these printers.)But you're reading this because you want to know whether Saint Francis is a good hospital, and it is. Â All the people I've dealt with on my three different visits have been friendly, helpful, professional, and competent. Â The nurses and blood-drawing people are no-nonsense but caring. Â That's an important balance to strike, especially for people who are undergoing scheduled outpatient procedures.There's parking across the street in the 909 Hyde building, but it seems expensive. Â Whatever, you're being cared for in Nob Hill; what do you expect? Â There's a certain down-to-earth-ness about this place that doesn't seem to fit but actually does. Â In fact, it reminds me a lot of my GP, whose office is across the street.

Sometimes, I make incredibly poor decisions.Like that time I decidedTripping on migraine medsThat I needed to "run an errand"And careened down the stairs And turned my ankleAnd trippedAnd hurled (headlong, flaming from th'ethereal sky)Down what stairs remainedDrugged up and bruised as I was, I was utterly convinced that my ankle was broken. And, after a blurry hour that involved ace bandages, ice packs, health insurance cards, calls to ex-boyfriends, and Googling various combinations of the phrase, "Can I take Vicodin with Topomax?" I found myself in the ER of Saint Francis Memorial.And it was quite wonderful.My expectations: blood, dirt, methadone, and random bums chilling in the waiting room (we are right next to the Tenderloin, after all).The reality: clean facilities, friendly staff (who seemed unphased by the fact that I brought my health insurance card, but *no* other form of ID in my drugged-up stupor), and short waits. I was in an out (in a fancy-ass wheelchair, no less) within 90 minutes: triaged, ex-rayed, bandaged, medicated (again), iced, (co) paid and ready to face the world on crutches. The next time I make a poor decision, I will plan to get myself to St Francis, soberly total.
Rude ER staff and very unclean waiting room. Â I'm glad my condition isn't that serious. Â I'm about to walk out

This is a serious review.Today while in a lunch meeting with my agency I experienced the scariest thing which has happened to me in a long time: An unexpected allergic reaction to something - I still have no idea what - which caused me to suddenly become unable to breath and break out in hives.I am a kind of allergic girl - I do have a long list of things which cause me to have asthma attacks (could I BE any more of a Poindexter?) and cause me to be sickly. Â So, I am very careful about what I put on and in my body... for this specific reason.It was quickly determined that I needed medical attention - being embarrassed by this display of weakness in front of press and my colleagues - I decided to jump in a cab and just hie myself hence to the nearest ER.In the cab I started to panic as I was trying to get in touch with various emergency contacts (my family is in the Midwest and not accessible to me for occasions such as this). Â When I got to the hospital the cabbie dropped me off at the wrong entrance. Â Which caused me to panic more.By the time I found my way inside and found someone who could help me find the ER I was clearly hyperventilating and crying. Â A sports medicine doctor interrupted her lunch to walk me to the ER and find someone who could give me immediate attention.I was taken straight back - the RNs were friendly, calm and comforting. Â  The doctor (Dr. Piccinni) was professional, reassuring and knowledgable.They quickly assessed my problem and started remedying it immediately. Â They allowed me to explain why I was anxious about how I was feeling; and, they reassured me that I would be fine. Â They allowed me to call my family from my cell phone - as well as calling my best friend (who was on her way across the Bay Bridge to attend to my emergency for me) and my office.The staff checked in on me frequently and kindly. Â I was very impressed with how quickly they figured out how best to communicate with me; and, the expediency of their diagnosis and treatment. Â They clearly explained exactly what they were doing during every step of the treatment and clearly explained what/how I should be feeling.I have to say - Dr. Piccinni and his staff made what was a scary, horrible situation much easier for me. Â Though they were not able to determine exactly *what* had caused me to go into anafalctic shock - they gave me thoughts on what *may* have caused the reaction (anchovies in my salad dressing, dyes or fillers in a new vitamin I've been taking.) Â And, though I feel pretty worn out and still a little sickly several hours later - I am confident in the treatment I received; and, that I will recover due to that treatment.So thank you to the St. Francis ER staff - and, thank you to the un-named Sports Med doc who helped me find where I needed to go.I hate General Hospital & avoid them at ALL costs... so, it says something that I give this one five out of five stars.

I was in SF for Cisco Live 2014 when I experienced what felt like a heart attack. Â Turn out to be pneumonia. Â  The E.R. staff was professional and friendly. Â The think I like the most was they made me feel welcomed. Â  The ER that I have experienced in the past always gave me the impression that the patient was a burden to them. Â Also they helped my wife entertained my 19th grandson while I was being treated.

Beats the hell out of General, unless of course you've had a major accident and need a good trauma team. Waiting time is ok, the doctors are friendly, (considering that they have to put up with the TL riff-raff) & its a good hospital for the basic broken bone/ stitches type thing. Apparently they have a spectacular burn center.

I'm posting a review for Sarah P. who is Pilates- based physical therapist at the Saint Francis Memorial Hospital.She is very knowledgeable in her field and continues her education by attending seminars and studying the latest advancements in her field.I always felt comfortable with her manual work because she always explains what she is doing and why.Sarah helped me thru several Â issues and I'm grateful for all her work.On top of all of the above she is a very intelligent and bright person and she is a delight to chat with. :)

I just went to their ER last night for the first time. I have to say, if it's possible to have a pleasurable experience in an Emergency Room when you're feeling like hell, this would have to be the best I've ever experienced.They had me registered immediately and in a room within minutes for severe abdominal pain, vomiting for 48 hours straight, and other really awful symptoms.I was given an IV with anti-nausea meds and morphine right away, in addition to tests and exams. The entire process from start to finish took about 3 hours. Amazing!The doctors and nurses were all extremely helpful and kind. They seemed to really give a shit about my well being. If I ever have to go to the Emergency Room again, this is DEFINITELY where I'll be going.

I'm writing this review on behalf of one of my AirBnB guests who recently required emergency treatment while experiencing a kidney stone. Â They raved about the care they received from Christine and Jeremy and I wanted to share their story. Â The following is cut and pasted from their AirBnB review:"My boyfriend flew in for the last night and mid-Christmas Tree decorating party had shooting kidney pains...NEVER FEAR! Allison and David are both trained medical professionals and we were quickly sent to St. Francis ER (where Allison works) and had the most enjoyable experience someone could have in the ER on a Saturday night. Allison called in and made sure they were expecting us and we were greeted with warm blankets and hot beverages... in an ER...it was amazing."I've personally used this ER for many years for all of my friends and family and I think it's the best hospital around. Â I recommend it to anyone who needs quick, friendly, comprehensive emergency medical care by dedicated professionals.

After writing a negative yelp review about this place, miraculously someone can call me back now. I am seriously floored. Maybe the exorbitant costs of my "treatment" really go to funding the PR department.

After reading this review, the hospital contacted me. Â They informed me that my out of pocket payment was a result of my insurance plan. Â I'm satisfied with their explanation. Â They were very polite and professional throughout the conversation.However, it still didn't change the fact (which was confirmed during our conversation) that the physiotherapist billed me for two procedures that took 15 minutes each. Â Total charge: $172 for 30 minutes of treatment. Â In total, $300+ for a 50-minute visit with a physiotherapist. Â Wow. Â Skyrocketing insurance premiums suddenly make a little more sense...I guess I'm partially at fault for not confirming their billing rates and not understanding that you will receive bills from both the facility and the service provider when you visit St. Francis. Â I'm from Canada. Â Except for the occasional co-pay, everything there is free.Next time I have a non-life threatening sports injury, I'll do my homework before I receive treatment.

I had a surgery performed here on March 2, 2012. I must give a BIG THANK YOU to the entire staff. I can't remember all the names, but going into pre-op Attyna was so accommodating I felt like I was at a 5- star hotel for a minute. My anesthesiologist Justin, was on top of the game. My surgeon Dr. Richard Sherwood was on time and came to see me and talk to me to make sure I was comfortable. The most impressive thing.......if anyone second guesses the facilities at St. Francis? Let me tell you, they have the MOST impressive Operating Room! Wow! Super high tech, state of the art, computers, flat screens, monitors, unlike anything I have seen on TV. It was so clean and uncluttered, I felt like I was on a set of a sci-fi movie. The staff told me they had a major remodel about a year ago, and because they do so much for the City, they had a good dose of some funds. I don't remember anything after that. The drugs kicked in.When I woke up in the recovery room, Karen and Susan were so helpful, I wished I could have taken them home. Bottom line, the Staff at St. Francis show compassion. Many times in General Hospital, I felt some of the workers feel a patient as just a number. The lack of sympathy could be ridiculous. This does not happen here. The people at St. Francis show that they enjoy their work and they enjoy making their patients happy during a crisis. 2 words, Â They care.

I hate General Hospital. This one is a newer building. They did a good job with the architecture. Unlike most General Hospital in the city this is not an eyesore. I came here to the ER for a deep glass cut to my elbow. They took X-Rays for no explainable reason... And charged me a fortune. I was disappointed in that sense... But happy with the doctor that stitched me up. Although I am sure I was charged about $100 for the extra band aid I asked for. I'll make sure not to have any accidents for awhile... An ER visit is not cheap!

I came to the ER after getting yelled at for sitting on the floor at SF General in excruciating pain from a kidney stone. I was in tears when I walked in, I was in tears when I left. Kidney stones are not a stroll in the park! I was very pleased by the staff and the care. I got instant help within ten minutes. They were professional and efficient, though the bill was large I was more than happy to incur the expense to a place that helped me at a time when I most needed it.Thanks St.Francis!

My grandma had to spend two nights here, so I decided to visit her. First of all, I never even knew this hospital existed. It's like the smallest hospital I've ever seen in my entire life. Secondly, parking is a major beeyatch. I circled around for twenty minutes, up and down hills, round and round cause of stupid one way streets before I was able to find parking. Granted, it was a Saturday night, but still! Thirdly, the security guard that was manning the doors disappeared by the time we left around 8PM. Um, please do your job and watch the doors. Thanks!The only perk was the nice view of the city from her eighth floor room window.

This concerns the emergency room.So, I went in at 1am, because I was in serious pain. I get in a room, and while changing into a gown, I overhear a rude nurse yelling at a patient, telling him to get out of a wheel chair. (What?)Next, when I see the doctor, he basically makes me feel like I'm wasting his time and totally capable of bearing the pain I was in at 1 in the morning . (Apparently, because I wasn't dying, my problem wasn't serious, which I understand, but I was still in a lot of unreasonable pain)And then they prescribed me weak medication, which would be the equivalent of taking candy.Very disappointing, because I had two finals that day and I could've really used some relief.

I live alone on probably the steepest hill in San Francisco with the most stairs. Â Not the most convenient place to fall and sprain your ankle while clicking down the stairs to work in high heels. Â With no one around to wisk me away to the ER, and had to rely on the fine gentleman of the SFFD to give me a lift to Saint Francis. Â I've been in quite a few ER's in my day, (due to other freakish occurences and strange illnesses) but apparently this hospital is ground zero for the peanut gallery convention. Â Maybe it's because it was the end of the month and San Francisco's homeless population was low on funds, but I've never seen people just hanging around a hospital just because they had no other place to go. Â Anywho, minus one star due to the new doctor. Â It was her first day at St. Francis and she seemed a bit frazzled, but she wasn't listening to my answers to her questions. Â All in all, they had me in, medicated, diagnosed, splinted up, and out lickety split. Â That's all I ask.

I was charged $27.00 for walking in here "after hours," which occurs between 10:00 PM and 8:00 AM. I'm sorry, but can you really tell your agonizing pain that woke you up at 3 AM to wait 5 hours? The answer is no, you can't. If nothing else in this world should be easily and (relatively) freely available and accessible 24 hours a day it should be the gosh darn emergency room. That and my astronomical bill aside, I was pleased with the decent care I received at this hospital for a nasty infection nestled deep within my digestive system. The nurses remembered my name, pumped me full of pain medication, and turned on the TV for me because I was happily incapable of doing anything except enjoying the sudden departure of my pain. And if that weren't enough, my doctor was super cute. I regret that our conversation was mostly about my bowel movements.

My husband required major, life-saving surgery and I am very impressed with the service we received at St. Francis. We arrived at emergency at 8:30am and he was in surgery by 2:00pm. The nurses--especially Rose Eberlas--were fantastic the first three days we were there. They let me stay, even getting me a cot to sleep on so that I could stay in the room. We had a private room and the most amazing view--I kept telling my husband that it was like staying at a hotel. Granted, under very stressful circumstances.My only complaint is that the nighttime nursing staff was a bit scattered. One nurse came in the morning before hubby was discharged and wanted to put in a new IV. We said, no, we're leaving today. She comes back and insists that hubby needs an IV. He's already had 4 at this point and is pretty needle weary, so again we refuse. She comes back a 3rd time and hubby almost lost it. Another nurse kept coming in to say that she needed to draw blood and then would giggle and say, oh, I mean take your vitals. She was the one who kept insisting, in a very insincere way, that she really cared about my husband's health. Then she would mess up about three things and then abandon us for the night. I have to say that I was really glad that they let me stay so that I could take care of hubby overnights--and alternatively very upset that I had to be there for him because the nursing staff was flaky. Overall, very good surgery--the surgeon was excellent and hubby is recovering well. I understand that there's a nursing shortage, but some of the nurses are flaky, inexperienced, and downright scary at times. Maybe more training is in store.

The plus side- everyone is very polite and there is minimal waiting time. You are seen quickly but the time you are seen is the same as any other factory medical approach in the US like 5 minutes. Five min in Er to triage, five more min to a room a few min to see a nurse in the room then done in less than an hour which is great . BUT it was too hasty. Having papers given to me with out much explanation, or even time to ask questions.I went in for a work injury. I was told to not go on an evening when I could have went to the ER by the employer. The 1099 bush st building is not clearly marked, you have to guess if it it is the correct place and forget about calling. The girl answering for the dept was clueless and transffered me out three times then chastised me for not calling the dept the proper name when I was told by the ER to "call this number for Physio therapy".I ended up reading the sheet to her and she had the nerve after chastising me to then tell me she knows what the sheet says. Ugh. I try to set up an appointment time and she has little interest in communicating with me that it is a drop in clinic and I make an appointment with her that actually was not an appointment. I finally get to see the Dr. the next day after not seeing one in the ER the night before. Thanks again to modern practice for not even seeing a DR in the ER with a spinal injury!!!Injured on Saturday, not able to get seen til Tuesday then rushed through then the only time we have left to schedule for physio is at one time slot for the week, Solution, their website needs updated to have the work injury clinic listed. Their staff needs training on the phones to communicate not get rid of clients. It would have been great if the Nurse was a DR in the ER who could tell me more than what I have told him. It would have been great to have the DR give me some assessment on the current status of my spinal injury.I guess there is no happy balance in medicine and you have to choose nice, clean, quick over clarity, quality and treatment. At least the scales here offer something positive over sf general.I am not sure if I trust them enough to not get over charged now that I read the reviews....

We recently had Â a tragedy in our family. Â Our family member was brought to St. Francis Hospital emergency and was admitted to their burn unit. Â Although she perished, during her short stay, the staff, physicians and nurses, showed us how a hospital should be run. Â They were accommodating to our very large family, allowed us to spend time with our severely injured family member, and helped us navigate through this mentally and emotionally challenging time. Â I would not hesitate to use St. Francis hospital again in the future. Â They truly care.

A truly great ER experience - in and out with prescriptions in 45 minutes. I am moving to the SF area but have an HMO based in Maryland. Â My options were to go to an urgent care facility ($60 copay) or an emergency room ($100) at one of the General Hospital that my insurer, CareFirst BlueChoice, participates with.I read about St. Francis on yelp, and chose it over the urgent care facility in the area which received poor reviews. Â I expected I would have a line and a long wait at the ER, but nothing was further from the truth. I was the only one in the waiting room when I arrived at 2pm on a Wednesday.The process was efficient, staff were grounded and positive, excellent listeners, and conservative practitioners (appreciated). Dr. Nadius and the male nurse who checked me in both had me feeling very comfortable, wholly heard in a complex (double-infection with chronic history) situation, and took the time to answer all of my questions and advise on matters that were related to my visit, but not immediate priorities. SO THANKFUL! Great experience, wish I hadn't waited so long for treatment thinking it would be all complicated!

It's difficult to write a review for a hospital, so i'll just say- people: 5 stars. i walked in, very confused, holding the parts of my finger, and was led to the er by the nicest woman ever. (cutting review short (no pun intended). too difficult to type) briefly,I am patched up and everyone there did great. I wish they didn't have to take your insurance, address, etc. before going to work on you, though the lady who took my info was quite cordial as I sat in a cold sweat while my life fluids soaked through the towel i had wrapped around my hand.Note:This article was written before I filled my prescription.

We had to come here while on vacation, when my wife developed severe back pain. The ER and 10th Floor staff were courteous and pleasant. The facility was clean and comfortable, and the service was above-average for a city hospital. Drs Yu and Hong were attentive, friendly and helpful. Dr. Yu completed insurance forms without having to ask twice. The ER doctor, whose name escapes me, was also very helpful.We were fortunate to have chosen this hospital while away from home and without anyone to really guide us.

First and foremost, I must say that the psychiatric ward at St. Francis Memorial Hospital is the best in the entire Bay Area! Â They went the "extra mile" to take care of me when I was at my lowest point of wanting to end my life after finding out my husband of 33 years was having an affair. My favorite nurse "Janice" would come and talk to me in my room when time permitted giving me that "extra burst" of self confidence. Â She gave me a little stuffed wolf to hold on to telling me to grab on to the gusto in life and never look back! Â The staff there is phoenominal, caring and professional. Â If it wasn't for them, along with the psychiatrists, psychologists, and transitional living at La Selva in-patient home for a number of weeks, I would have never made it!!! Â It's been a year since I was there (May 2015), and I am no longer under psychiatric care, totally off the meds, AND I left that horrible man who hurt me so badly. Â THANK YOU ST. FRANCIS MEMORIAL HOSPITAL!!!!

This weekend my dear friend had a diabetic reaction that resulted in a call to 911 followed by an ambulance ride and a day in the ER. Â Out of the two paramedics that were assiting us the female was very kind and patient while the male was pretty much threatening my disoriented friend that if she didn't comply he would take her to the ER. Â She finally agreed that she should go to the hospital and once there the nurse who assisted us was very kind and helpful. Â My friend was very scared and he helped ease her concerns.Thank you to the female paramedic and the ER nurse, my friend has regained her memory and strength and is feeling much better two days later. Â Thank you so much.

I am very happy with the serviced I have received here! I have seen Melissa in PT for about two months now and she has not only showed me how to heal my foot but how to keep from hurting it in the future. I also Dr. Wingfield who was able to address my problem and made it very easy and comfortable to explain what was going on with my foot and why I wanted to heal it.I then saw Dr. Blake who was able to make me some orthodics which have helped the way I walk and really improved my posture as a whole.I am quite pleased with the service I have received here and will go back for all future needs.

Sharon is awesome. I feel so much better!!! Had a torn TFCC in my wrist with 2 other microtears and she helped me avoid wrist surgery and I'm back to my Insanity workouts with tons of pushups and full on Power Vinyasa yoga. Â She's the best.
RUDE nurses on 9. Just another hospital where the staff does NOT CARE.. Join St Lukes.

I had a Ski injury 4 weeks back and I visited emergency dept here..The doctor told me that I'm fine and its only a sprain with no damage. Somehow this could not digest so went ahead and met this other great surgeon at SOAR (Dr. Akizuki) who ordered MRI which came positive with 'Complete Torn ACL'. Â Dr. Akizuki while ordering before the MRI told that I've torn ACL. Now I'm waiting for Dr. Akizuki for the surgery but happy that I found the Orthopedists who can perform it. I don't recommend St. Francis Hospital@900 Hyde (Including Emergency) to anyone for sports injury and best is to seek professional advise from either Dr. Akizuki or where reviews shows positive results.

The Come and Go Unit was great for my mom. Â She had a colonoscopy done yesterday and the staff was so nice and helpful through the whole process. Â From the time she checked in and to the time my mom was picked up to go home, someone was always there to translate and to make sure she is ok. Â Thanks!

3 i.v.'s, 2 shots of anti-nausea meds, and an hour and a half later the bf is feeling better after a severe bout of food poisoning from King Of Thai Noodle in North Beach.I couldn't believe how well run St. Francis is. The staff was thorough, friendly, and prompt. We waited maybe 15 minutes in the ER before being seen/treated. Nice to have such a well-run & clean place so close to home.

I've been coming to St. Francis Sports Medicine for many years now and a few things have stayed consistent:1) They always successfully treat / heal my ailment2) The doctors are phenominal3) The PT staff is greatI've been here for herniated discs, broken bones, torn muscles, etc. and they have always been incredible professional, accurate, helpful and caring. Â With each ailment, they fully examining you, explaining as they go what they are testing or looking for. If you need follow up tests (xrays, MRI, etc.), they explain what the options are and why they recommend those tests. Â Fortunately, you can get all of them done in the building. Once they have identified the issue and come up with a solution, it may involve PT and if so, you are in luck - they have a PT group attached which have been excellent (particularly Matt who I've used for the past few issues). Â One thing which I like and respect, however, is that for certain portions of my treatment, one doctor actually recommended that I go to a PT at another establishment because she was better and somewhat more aggressive on rehab, which I needed for my timetable. I have no hesitation in recommending St. Francis to anyone and have sent friends there who have been pleased. Â My only caveat would be that when you are scheduling follow up appointments, schedule a few in advance because their schedules get pretty full, but they are understanding of cancellations.

Ended up here in the ER after a fender bender while in town and pretty pregnant. Â The ER doc was seriously the worst. Â Terrible bedside manner, made a not so funny crack about "if the shoe fits" in terms of a 30 week pregnant lady being chubby and when I asked for his professional advice as to whether I should seek a 2nd opinion from a hospital that actually had a labor and delivery unit (FYI- they are NOT equipped to deal with maternity patients, so don't go here. Â not an opinion, that is a fact) he told me not to ask him b/c he "goes around with broken bones all the time and doesn't get them checked out". Â I would NEVER go here again.

No one likes General Hospital. Â Not that I know of. Â Anyway, we had to go there today because my boyfriend had to have an MRI for his MS to see if there is any activity.The hospital was clean, the outpatient section was clearly marked, and it was super quick and easy checking in. Â The X-Ray department was also pretty quick and clean and nice to work with, and right after the X-Ray was done, it was instantly available at his Neurologist's office for her to review with him and prescribe him some new medicine. Â I guess if I"m forced to go to a hospital, this is not a bad one.

I walked in the other day, asking for info at the desk, and this incredibly nice 85 year-old grandpa didn't give me the answer, but stood up with the help of his crane, then walked me all the way to the place that I wanted to go. On my way there, I kept thinking and feeling really bad, you really don't need to do this.....i just need to know where it is.....They are not the most efficient people, but everyone was so incredibly nice and helpful. Easy parking nearby on the metered spots.

Visiting from out of town and we had to visit the Emergency Room. First thing Â was to make sure the Facility was in network for our insurance and then I crossed referenced both Yelp and Angie's list. Â The reviews have been very accurate and we are very pleased with the quality of care so far. Â This afternoon the surgery will take place. Fingers crossed .

Physical Therapist Holly Klopfer helped me successfully recover from hip surgery. Â Both Holly and her team provided great service (i.e. professional, knowledgeable, kind, etc.). Â I recomend both Holly and her team.- G.G.

just got back, was so upset at my treatment that I left in the middle of it!! I actually slipped and fell leaving I was so upset!!! I fell so hard I broke my phone, I am covered in bird poo, and I am writing this BEFORE I take a shower!The bathroom was FILTHY and the toilet seat had faint blood and bloody handprints on it, the floor was wet and there was an awful smell, and the bed had wet handprints on it and a smear of white stuff AFTER he cleaned it.Go to this hospital if you don't value your health.If you have any other choice...take it!Oh I almost forgot, they pricked my finger for a blood test without wiping it first and I had been in that awful bathroom! the nurse grabbed my finger and just poked Â it Â when I was expecting a swipe first, and he was rude when he did it...I was standing in a hallway, not even in a proper room! My hands were dirty...they have no protocol there!
Sharon and Lilly are the best. Â Very knowable and helpful. Â Helped me get out of pain!

After having my usual check up, I opted to get a blood panel done. Instead of waiting around, I figured I'd run across the street to get it done. Sure, the registration takes a while but overall it's a seamless process to get yourself setup so long as you have the right paperwork in hand.

Had blood work done at the lab and requested the results faxed to Stanford. Told receptionist and had it written on the lab slip also. Called lab to check to see if my instructions were followed after the results were posted on my online account. It wasn't done so time to find another facility.

I've broken 40-50 bones, at least. Â Honest. Â Yeah, I have that glass bone disease.On Saturday while awaiting a table at Cheesecake Factory, I fell over one of those large metal blocks on their viewing deck and my shoulder took the impact. Â I heard it crunch and the pain was immediate and overwhelming.My wonderful friend quickly got my car from the parking garage and hauled me over to St. Francis for xrays etc.I've been to a lot of ERs and seen a lot of doctors. Â General Hospital scare the living hell out of me. Â Normally I go to St. Luke's 'cos that's where my Orthopedic Surgeon is, but the last time I went to the ER there it was to take my husband in for abdominal pain and that was a 6 hour trainwreck of misery and fail.My visit to St. Francis didn't start off on the right foot. Â As I stood shivering in shock and unable to form coherent sentences, the registration desk staff failed to notice me standing there for a few minutes. Â After my friend filled out the form for me, we went to the triage nurse, who was, frankly, a bitch. Â I was in blinding pain and when the automated blood pressure cuff proved to be too much for my poor brain to take, she got very exasperated and frustrated with me. Â I'm sure had she taken my bp manually it would've been fine; instead, she tried three times to do it with the machine, each time resulting in pain and fail. Â She finally gave up, making it clear that she found me very annoying. Â  Sorry, lady. Â Ever break your shoulder in 3 places?That said, my admittance and treatment in the ER was fast. Â While the Xray staff was a bit like "Who's on first" and my xrays were less than optimal, the nurse treating me in the ER was top-notch - friendly, understanding, sympathetic, caring, and concerned. Â The doc who read my xrays and prescribed my immobilizer and painpills was also friendly and jovial - he said he'd run out of bubble wrap for patients like me. Â All in all I left in a much better mood than when I came in, and we were in and out in under 2 hours. Â That's saying a lot when you have a three-part shoulder fracture.Now I get to have surgery to put a plate in there next week... aieeee.

I'm almost alway impressed at the registration counter how clean and quiet it is, and that there is usually no waiting. Â I like that the hospital is right across the street from my doctor's office and within walking distance of work. Â I have to go there semi-annually for regular blood tests now. Â They always ask if it's OK for an intern to take the sample, and I agree after the last time I asked for a regular staff person, who botched it. Â He missed the vein, causing spasms, during which time he aggressively forced the needle into my arm, causing severe pain. Â I've never been hurt by an intern, who have all been gentle and accurate. Â I want to give special accolades to the staff in the imaging department (I believe they are on the 7th floor.) Â In 2007, they assisted my doctor with EKG/treadmill stress tests, on the first day without, and on the 2nd day with echo-imaging. Â I was impressed by the professionalism and personal warmth that they gave me during an otherwise uncomfortable and awkward procedure. Â The female tech gave me a complimentary image of my heart and even explained how to read the test results, which my PCP didn't even bother to.

After coming here for a come and go surgery. I found myself staying in the hospital. They're trying to get my severe pain under control. While in my hospital room for shall I say a week. I saw and heard many things that struck a nerve ( no point intended) the lack of compassion and care and patient understanding. With that I was placed in a room by a supply closet that all you hear is that door constantly being beeped and opened. Not to mention when You complain enough times about the banging of hospital carts and over. Floor lips like there in a hurry to see who's going to bang there cart the loudest. You ask them nicely to wheel things around quietly and that doesn't happen. They constantly come in your rooms and wake u up, even if you are trying to recover yourself after having a major surgery. Â They just don't listen to patients. I found 3 nurses that were helpful and understanding, but when they were off the clock and gone home. It became time to go back to lore hell. Heck some nurses just barge in at midnight into your room and turn on lights and stat banging things around even tho your sleeping and trying to rebuild your energy. NOPE!!I'm lost for the experience I've had in my medical care here.

This place almost cut open the wrong patient, after so much confusion I am appalled. Â I spent the whole day in this place, was admitted twice within 3 hours. Â Every single person I talked to said something like "This doesn't seem right" or "That can't be true" while either reading my patient notes, or asking me questions I answered truthfully. Â I never saw the same physician twice in the 10 hours I was there. Â I was mistaken for another patient. Had symptoms read back to me that I never indicated, in fact some where the direct opposite of what I had indicated. I am disgusted in the level of service, the lack of sanitation and the out of date technology and lighting int he facility. This was the worst experience I have had in 34 years of medical care. Â Most concerning, was that all my paperwork was taken from me, and wouldn't be returned upon request, paperwork I received from a separate clinic. Â I am horrified by the staff at this facility, and disgusted that anyone receives such awful treatment. Disgusting humans, if you can call them that.

I used the inquicker service for the ER. Â I was seen right on time by Nurse Allison. Â She was tremendous! Â So knowledgable and helpful. Â Most importantly, she relieved my ear pain! Best ER around! Highly recommended.
