1. I broke my wrist and needed someone to put a cast on, according to the emergency room doc. . Â After explaining this to the receptionist, she scheduled an appointment for me with Dr. Nguyen.2. Dr. Nguyen doesn't do casts. Â She asked Dr. Lewis to advise her on how to proceed. Â After a quick physical eval of my wrist and a check of the x-ray, it is decided by all that I may avoid a cast, and am sent across the street to get a splint. (Why don't they have splints on-site?)3. BOTH doctors charge me for the visit, each charging about $300.4. Neither uses the billing code that will trigger my insurance to pay for the visits, so I have to pay this out of pocket. I have Aetna, by the way.5. On my next visit, which I schedule with Dr. Lewis only, (I do not know at this point about the billing code issue) I return from x-ray and am escorted by Dr. Lewis herself back to an exam room. Â A full hour and a half later (I was engrossed in my book and didn't want to be a bother) I left the exam room to tell the receptionist that I was going back to my office. Â She got the doctor, who had apparently simply forgotten that I was there. Â The office was pretty much empty at this point. Â She glanced at the x-ray, did not even look at my hand, and told me that nothing had changed, to come back in three weeks. 6. I just got another $300 bill for the visit in #5 above.7. The day before my third scheduled visit, the receptionist called to tell me that Dr. Lewis was not going to be there after all, and that my appointment was cancelled.8. Â I have made an appointment with a different orthopedist to finish my treatment. Â Seriously. Worst ever experience with a doctor.

I had a tendon suture/repair surgery here last week on my foot. Very stressful for me. I am extremely grateful that everyone was so helpful, considerate and upbeat. I mean everyone, and I came into contact with about 12 different members of the staff for this out patient surgery. I can't remember all of the names unfortunately, but as he helped to put me in my friend's car to go home, I promised the male nurse Robert that I would mention his name in my Yelp review. He went out of his way after surgery to get me going, to show me how to use the crutches, and to just put me at ease, to say nothing about how he stayed late and made sure I had all the attention I needed in the recovery room. Again, all of the nurses, and the rest of the staff, were wonderful. Speaking of late, that was the small blemish, namely that my surgery was delayed two hours past the anticipated start time because things were running late from the morning schedule, and then (I am told) the surgery ahead of mine in the operating room I was scheduled for had unforeseen complications, so that led to some further delay. Not the hospital's fault or that of the staff - it was the middle of the holiday season and apparently these things happen. Indeed, I got scheduled for this surgery on one day's notice, so I have no reason to complain about that - just lucky the surgery was able to go forward on such short notice. Â I might mention that my foot surgeon and the anesthesiologist were very professional with great bedside manners, but they are not employees of the hospital, and that may be the subject of a different Yelp review.

DO NOT GO HERE!I went to the ER to treat a bad allergic reaction, or so I thought, but I'm not normally allergic to anything. I waited for over an hour, took some of my own Benedryl. The P.A. came in for 5 minutes, pretty much told me to drink more water, don't eat almonds and gave me a prescription for stronger Benedryl. However, by the time he saw me most of my rashes subsided. Month later, I get two bills, one massive one from the hospital and another from the Doctors. Billed twice apparently by different departments that don't communicate with each other, hospital vs. doctors. How does that make sense? I'm suppose to pay 1000 just to sit on their beds for 1 hour while waiting and another 200 for the two doctors, one of which I never even met. Don't go here if you can help it!!!!

If you're coming here for an emergency or planned surgery, I cannot comment.My review is based on seeing an orthopedic doctor for an exam and subsequent visits plus physical therapy at their Sports Medicine facility across the hall.Unbeknownst to me until I arrived in the waiting room to fill out some forms, every time that I would see this doctor I would be charged a separate fee paid to the hospital. I wasn't happy upon reading that but figured if I left I'd have to pay a fee for not showing up for my appointment. So I bit the bullet. (THEY SHOULD DISCLOSE THIS POLICY ON THEIR WEBSITE, OR VERBALLY WHEN SETTING APPOINTMENTS.)Had to wait a really, really, REALLY long time in the exam room, so long that I was getting pissed that no one even came in to update or apologize for the long wait. Finally the Dr. breezes in with barely an apology and ends up asking me some advice after I tell her my profession! WTF?She diagnosed me quickly, suggested an MRI. Came back for follow-up, thankful that she had conservative approach & said I didn't need surgery. She did recommend (expensive) physical therapy 2x/week. Four months pass with quick follow-up visits & more p/t, when I realized that my doctor & physical therapist don't communicate about my care/treatment and were not on the same page! Got a 2nd opinion to find that I had a moderate problem, p/t prescribed to be done at home, & no need for p/t at the facility! Wish I had not selected this facility/doctor and it's my own fault b/c I wanted a female physician, it was conveniently located & it accepts my insurance.Will not go back here to see a doctor unless it's an emergency or recommended!

The worst "hospital' I have encountered. Poorly managed and operated on every level.I write this as I am so very outraged by what I witnessed recently. I work for the SF District Attorney as an Investigator and recently I had to go to St Francis' Psychiatric ward to interview a victim of domestic abuse. I was appalled by what I saw. Dirty beds in dirty rooms in a hidden 3rd floor ward. Broken fixtures. Broken furniture. The patients are basically drugged and left in bed all day without any medical treatment if needed. Patients forced to fetch their own food which looked like it came right out of the garbage. Friends, I am not in any way exaggerating. This place looked EXACTLY like One Flew Over The Cockoo's Nest. The staff is the worst group of unprofessional, disinterested, callous and downright cruel people I have ever encountered in a supposed care facility. It is a shameful situation. The patients have no TV, No Radio, No Reading material. NOTHING. They lay in bed staring at the ceiling for anywhere from 3-14 days depending on how long St Francis can bilk an insurer or the city. They bill 1000's per day per patient. Their website touts "intense therapy, counseling, compassion, outreach etc. They provide none of that. Here is the truth:1. When a patient is first admitted (day 1) they see a Psychiatrist for about 10 minutes2. Patient is assigned a bed (not even a hospital bed, they look like $99 Ikea cots).3. Patient is given plenty of meds during day. sleeping pills at night.4 Typical day: wake up, get terrible quality breakfast, lay in bed, get lunch, lay in bed, get dinner, lay in bed and then go to sleep.5. Patient may be seen once or twice more at most by psychiatrist even if seriously mentally ill and even if staying the full 14 days.6. This house of horrors literally simply medicates the hell out of patients to zone them out and get them "stable" enough to be discharged. I saw patients literally given $2 for bus fare and a juice box and sent on their homeless way.This place is shameful. These patients are amongst our most vulnerable citizens and need compassionate care, monitoring and follow-up.If any decent San Franciscan saw this human tragedy, they would be outraged. Yet, it goes on. I spoke with Doctors at UCSF, Kaiser and CPMC and all said they were aware of the deplorable conditions and did everything they could to prevent patients going their. The problem is that there are only 3 Psych wards in all of SF. UCSF, SF General and St Francis. It is a travesty in that a city so rich in so many things utterly fails to aid our fellow citizens in dire need. Thank you for taking the time to read my comments

An unexpected visited to the St Francis hospital ER met with very caring, thorough, knowledgable and supportive doctors, nurses and specialists. Was even able to pull up to the valet and drop off my car at no charge. Was admitted within minutes of arrival. Was in and out of the ER within 2 hours. A convenient Walgreen's across the street for picking up medications after the visit. St Francis is the local burn unit for the northern SF Bay Area. The care was excellent and of high caliber.

This hospital will rob you blind!I went in for a routine blood draw. I was seen by a student nurse, who had not been practicing more than 2 weeks. This does not bother me, but does not account for the $1000 that was billed. My insurance covered half, but I still think it's outrageous that a routine procedure cost me $500. Especially when I went to have another blood draw a few months later at LabCorp (the place where the hospital sends the blood to be analyzed anyway) and was only charged $134, with my responsibility being less than $10. How can the hospital justify this?! And there is no recourse. If you call and complain they will simply offer to send you an itemized bill confirming their insanely high fees and tell you "that's just what it costs." I'm furious, but have no option not to pay. All I can do is strongly recommend that you never never go to St. Francis for routine procedures.

Ladies and Gentlemen, I am not superman. I cannot fly. My lovely boyfriend challenged me to a **who can jump further from the rickety swings in golden gate park** Â contest. He won. My knee, and it's cartilage, lost.I hate General Hospital. I'm self employed with no insurance.. but I remembered going to Saint Francis in the past and the care being excellent, so I figured: awesome. I'll go again. They were nice.And nice they were... the care was great, everyone was easygoing and gentle with me, offering me pain meds while i waited like they were a X-Ray techs were all awesome.The Administration was not.As far as quality of care and the actual Healthcare Workers here? 110% 5 stars wonderful caring knowledgeable.The Admin lady comes up to me as I'm getting fitted into an mobilizing brace and goes "your account has been flagged, you owe us 600.00.""excuse me??"" In 2008 you saw us for a shoulder injury and the balance was never paid. We cannot continue treatment" she proceeds to wave off the guy putting the brace on my leg. Guy putting the brace on my leg keeps going anyways."I'm sorry. Last time I was here I had insurance and I never received a bill. I'll be happy to check into my records for you""If you cannot provide a payment today we can't do anything for you but this brace. This is a PRIVATE hospital you know... " and then rolls her eyes at me and my bright red hair..." we need a payment to ensure you'll continue to pay"...She asks for my name again, my address... and repeats the apartment number to me three times... looks at her records... looks at me again and shuffles away.AND THEN tried to keep my ID when I told her I had 15.00 on me since, ya know, I was going to a hospital... it's not the kind of thing you pay up front for...

I came into St. Francis ER on a Friday afternoon with a locked knee. Â I was placed in a wheelchair, waiting to see the triage nurse, for about an hour. Â The ER waiting room was pretty much empty. Â There were no people getting wheeled in on gurneys off of ambulances. Â The nurse triaged patients on a first-come-first-served basis. Â Meanwhile, the longer my knee was locked, the worse my knee hurt, and the more contorted my leg was getting. Â I was crying, shaking, loudly in the ER. Â I'm no wuss. Â I didn't cry when I broke my toe when I was 10. Â I didn't cry when I dislocated my shoulder when I was 15. Â But eventually, I was ready to gnaw off my own leg in the ER at St. Francis, particularly when I was first told I would be seen in 2-3 minutes after being seated in a wheelchair that I couldn't sit in because my leg was bent at some crazy angle.When I finally got seen by the nurse, I asked to be sedated. Â I believe it was at this point that I was labeled a drug-seeking patient. Â In my defense, I knew they were going to have to straighten my knee. Â I didn't want to be fully conscious for that experience. Â And who would blame me? Â I've had my shoulder dislocated (and relocated?) a bunch of times. Â I've been sedated on each occasion. Â That's the way it's done. Â I even asked for some pain medication. Â You know why? Â Because I was in a heckuvalotta pain. So, I was put in the back, in a bed (hurrah), where I was left for what seemed like forever. Â No drugs, no information, no nothing. Â Some 15-year-old looking kid finally asked for my medical insurance info. Â Finally, I got a shot of valium, which was of an amount that did absolutely nothiing. Â When I mentioned that I didn't feel any bit relaxed (in response to the nurse's question about how the valium made me feel), I was told that I had been given enough. Â Fast forward quite a while, finally given some pain medication. Â A bit of relief. Â And then, hours later (when pain meds were wearing off), the physician's assistant decided it was time to straighten my leg. Â I asked for more valium. Â I was told no more sedation, no more meds, because they were concerned about my breathing. Â Hello? Â I'm in an ER. Â Aren't they pretty well equipped to deal with any breathing problems? Â Meanwhile, I'm completely, 100% awake, lucid, and not relaxed. Â And the PA is going to try to straighten my leg. Â I ask if a doctor will do it. Â She says no. Â So here's my situation. Â I've been in the ER for hours at this point of time. Â I'm being denied any more drugs and the right to see a doctor, and my leg has to get straightened somehow, and preferrably hours ago. Â It takes 10 excruciating minutes. Â I'm screaming in pain the entire time. Â Afterwards, I'm a shaking, crying mess again. Â In complete agony. Â I get written a prescription for Motrin and discharged. Â  I get helped up out of bed and handed crutches. Â I've used crutches before; I know how to use them. Â But I can't use crutches at this time. Â Because I'm in too much pain to move. Â The nurse yells at me that my leg shouldn't hurt unless I'm putting weight on it (which I'm not). Â There is nothing I can do at this point. Â I can't get back into bed without help because I can't lift my leg. Â I can't use crutches. Â The only saving grace is that I also can't sit in the wheelchair that they're trying to shove me out the door in because, since my leg is immobilized, my knee won't bend and, therefore, I can't sit in the wheelchair. Â So, I make the orderly put me back in bed and I refuse to leave until I see a doctor, because I believe something has got to be messed up with my knee. Â I finally am seen my a doctor, and by seen, he looks at my knee while it's in a huge brace and gives my 6 vicodin, which is supposed to last me until I'm able to see a real doctor (i.e., one who can take more than 15 seconds to examine me) as soon as I can get an appointment next week.Turns out, my knee is royally messed up, I haven't been able to bear any weight on my leg for the past week-and-a-half, it still hurts a ton, I'm getting semi-emergency surgery next week, and I definitely think the folks over at St. Francis treated me in a way you wouldn't wish on your worst enemy. Â Be warned.

My visit to the hospital for an X-ray was pleasant enough, but their billing and customer service sucks!They billed an incorrect code for my visit and it's been a year since my visit and i still do not have a resolution on my billing. This is after my doctor sent repeated faxes giving information on the correct billing! Every customer service representative has inconsistent Â information, they are least bothered to actually help you and just refuse to actually do anything!Never going back!

We have twice been vastly overbilled.My wife wentinto emergency. The bill was $4100 yes $4100. Then they reclassified the bill so we paid $800 over insurance.My son waited 6 hours before they could sew up a nasty gash on his face.I had a simple operation and they made me wait for an hour with a needle in my arm hooked to plain water. There was no need.When I asked why I had to lie there for over an hour doing nothing, the nurse said because it's procedure.Stay as far away from this hospital as possible.I have nothing good to say about it.

01-26-2009, at 05:00 I was injured at work. I damaged ligaments in my ankle and chipped a bone in the process. My ankle swelled like a baseball and walking was impossible...hopping was excruciating. My company cabbed me to St Francis Hospital and I arrived at the front entrance at 05:30. There was no one in the lobby or at the front desk at all. I looked around for assistance and found none. I saw a sign saying "Emergency" with an arrow pointing down the hall. I followed it down the hall, then to the right, then to the right again, then to the left where I came Â upon two large oak doors, closed and locked. The whole time I was hobbling around the hallways in agony I was thinking to myself "Why is the Emergency entrance so far from the front door?" And now I stood before a wall of oak. I knocked, no answer. I was hurting and aggrevated...almost getting pissed off actually. I hobbled back in much pain to the front lobby, standing there in disbelief. I started calling out "Does anyone work here?" "Is there anyone in this hospital?" No answer. I looked for a "courtesy phone/intercom" and found none. A woman walked in the door off of the street. I asked "do you work here?" She said "Yes" I told her that I thought I was in the Twilight zone as there was but an empty building pretending to be a hospital. She said "Yeah they quit staffing this area recently" ("this area" being the front lobby) I told her about the Emergency room doors being locked. She became very snotty. "Did you punch in the code?" I said "What code? People in emergency situations may not be capable of punching in a code...I didn't see anything like that" She sneered "Well, do you want me to help you or not!?" I thought about it and said, "No actually I don't because I don't trust this place." I went behind the front desk and called my company from the hospital's phone and told them of the absence of humanity (and humans). A second employee walked in off of the street so I suppose the day was about to start at St Francis. I used their telephone to call a cab which took me to Kaiser on Geary, where there were human beings working. I would recommend St Francis hospital, unless of course you are seeking medical attention and then you might wish to look elsewhere.

For a hospital near the TLoin I was very surprised. Â Spend two days here from an emergency and probably had 30 different nurses and other taking care of me. Â All were great, nice, empathetic. Â The place is clean and seems to have all current technology. Â Only downside is food isn't so good, but what do you expect. Â Highly recommended if you have a choice.

I'm sick. It hurts everywhere. Earaches. Cough. Runny nose. Fever. Achey. The whole bit. Being that I recently moved here I don't have a general practioner yet. So I get a recomendation from my chiropracter. Being that we are all located in Portrero Hill, he suggests this place right down the street that just happens to be located in Pac Bell Stadium. I call. They take walk-ins. Very cool. Only open till 4pm though. The front assistant, very cool. I get put in a room. The nurse asks wher it hurts and I say everywhere. The doc comes in. Doc Moi. He doesn't even listen to anything I say. And to top it all off he tells me...I'M NOT SICK! Wtf? Are you serious? He looks at my throat and taps on my sinuses. That's It! And then proceeds to tell me that he can't prescribe me anything because I am just NOT sick. Now, I can understand if I was in the Tenderloin and I was asking for Morophine or a couple pick me ups, but I just wanted some antibiotics or a little cough medicine. Maybe even a Z-Pack? He says take two apirin every every 4 to 6 hours on a full stomache and a bunch of Nyquil. Are you F#C*$N serious? And he was. All this weezing and yucky coughing is a figment of my imagination? The aches and the pains are not real? So I refuse to leave without drugs. I want something. He gives a prescription for Z-pack says don't fill it unless I really absolutely need to and shuts the door on me. That's it. Â I go fill it. Go home. Chug some Nyquil and wake up this morning just as shitty as the day before. Thanks Doc. You just won an award for the most useless doctor I have ever been into in my life. ::Cough::, ::Cough::!

I went to their outpatient facilities to get an x-ray. In the waiting room, the television was turned up at a volume that made my head ache. I finally asked if they could turn it off (there was no one else in the waiting room) and she turned the volume down by a few notches. I had to ask twice to turn it down again.When I finally got my x-rays, they made me wait about 40 minutes supposedly because their radiologist needed to review it. He never did, and they finally told me later that they'd just send the results to my doctor. They never sent the results either. After hearing nothing for 2 days, I had to call up my doctor who had to explicitly ask them to send the x-rays. What an awful experience.

The worst ER and inpatient experience I've ever had. Â Failed to diagnose a fracture for over 24 hours. Â Rude and incompetent staff and doctors. Â Later I contacted administration regarding my treatment (or lack of). Â Ten weeks later, I'm still waiting to hear from them regarding their "investigation." Â Don't treat here! Ask ambulance to take you anywhere else.

I have never been treated so well at any hospital ever. I was greeted at the lobby, taken by a volunteer to the radiology lobby. The woman behind the desk apologized for the delay and gave me a free cab voucher to get back to work. The technician was efficient, friendly and respectful. I couldn't have asked for a better experience!

Some may have found relief on the 11th floor, but unfortunately---I am not one of them. Â My initial visit which was very difficult to get scheduled, began with Sarah advising me that I should not expect my appointments to be available on nights or weekends, and that the only reason she was doing the work at all was to keep her license active. Â Now that she had a family, this work was not a top priority.That should have been my clue.The next two visits were with other therapists since Sarah went on vacation (why they scheduled me to see someone who was already absent is beyond comprhension), and since neither of them knew me either, they were not comfortable getting into a full treatment.By my 4th visit, I got to see Sarah again who couldn't remember me, and so she had to start from the beginning. Â I did not go there to talk--I went there to be treated.It was over a month between initial schedulling and my 4th visit. Â Not only did I not receive any professional help with my injury, but I wasted a full month of opportunity to recover.On top of it all, the amount of money they charged my Insurance for this inadequate and wasteful 'service' was alarming. Â If you want to get better, don't put yourself at risk by going there. Â You will be taking your chances.

Recently had a series of hand therapy appointments at the St Francis Memorial Hospital Hand Clinic. Â Many years of keyboard use and have tried many other places.Hands down (pun intended) the most professional, attentive, efficient therapy in town. Â The clinic didn't prolong treatment, rather gave me extensive evaluations, exercises and advice to rely on self care and independence. Â Amazing. Â Ask for Sharon Verdi--actually insist on seeing her.

I can't say I've had a ton of experience with General Hospital, but probably a litte more than your average Joe...or Sally...or whoever. But I have to say my first visit to St. Francis Mem was stellar. Thank goodness I was only there for outpateint services and not an emergency, but regardless, the mark of a good hospital is how happy the staff seems to be who work there. At every turn, from the Information Desk to the Lab Techs, I was met with smiling faces. My services were performed On Time and within the amount of time they told me to plan. There was never a wait of more than a few minutes to check in or get your services. And everyone is kind and professional. If given the choice - have your services performed - or your amublence take you! - to St. Francis Hospital.

I'm normally not a fan of emergency rooms but if you gotta go you're lucky if you're in the proximity of St. Francis Memorial. I was recently the unfortunate victim of a flying hockey puck to the mouth during a game. (thank heavens for mouth guards....still got my teeth) Big deep gash right down the middle...Youch!!! In true Gordie Howe fashion, I finished the game and stopped by the bar afterwards. On a tip from the bartender Â I decided to stop by the emergency room for some stitches. To my surprise, it was empty, clean with flat screen tv's!! I signed in, took a seat and waited for about 10 mins. The nurse was kind of a tool:Nurse: we're you assaulted?Me: No...hockey puck...spit spit....Nurse: if you were assaulted we need to report itMe: ok i was assaulted by a puck..."smirk"Nurse: let me see your lip.......ooo that's a nasty one...that's going to swell upMe: mmmph....(no shit sherlock!) Nurse: I need to give you a tetanous shot.......hmmm your blood pressure is 151 over 95 that's pretty high for someone your age....Me: well you have a big needle and i'm bleeding profusely from the mouth.....I'll try to calm myself down...Nurse: haha...no kissing for youMe: WTF???Aside from the game of 20 questions, it took about 1/2 hr to stitch me up and I was outta there within the hour and got to spend the next couple days with a bad mexican botox job. Â But for reals, this would've taken at least 5 hrs at Stanford!"just an update (5/28/08)" - wow! mouth injuries must be their specialty. One of my team mates got wacked with a stick the other night and I had to take him to emergency....again we sat for about 10-15 mins and he was all stitched up in no time... I think it's kinda routine now, half my team has been here at some point.

ok ok, sorry about the string of doctor office reviews, but really i been to many, many, many of them.i've been to St. Francis for my previous hip replacement, so i went to back for the revision surgery as well. Dr. Victor Prieto was my surgeon & really he's a nice, nice guy. first the hospital: -clean, easy to find stuff, & the admitting staff was curt, but ya know, nice enough. Â -the nurses were all really nice, both the first time & the most recent time i went. they sympathized sweetly that at 26 this was my 4th hip surgery, & were prompt with the pain meds. (always nice)dr. prieto:-nice, nice, nice. i need some serious good bedside manner to make me feel comfortable, & this guy delivers. -i always bring my dad to my orthopedic appointments cos there's a lot of information to soak in. Dr. P. talks to me to be sure i'm ok with what's being planned, then turns to my father & addresses his questions as well. i'm pretty happy with the results of the surgery, & his willingness to fulfill my needs:meds too strong? i'll change 'em. you wanna go home a day early? i can do that. just lemme write the orders.so if you need any major bones revised & filed down, give this guy a call. and stay at St. Francis, they're quite nice. the food is still hospital food tho, it's not Shangri-La for gad's sake.

I never thought I'd write a review for a hospital ( I dislike anything medical ) but here I am. I ended up at St. Francis ER Saturday night. I was involved in a minor car accident and was talked in to going to the ER. In my opinion it was not life threatening and to my surprise I was seen by a doctor who agreed with me!. One nurse came by a few times to make sure I was doing okay and didn't need anything. They ran a couple of tests and an xray of my shoulder which surprisingly didn't take that long. The whole thing was quick and efficient and every one I met was both helpful and friendly. As I mentioned earlier I'm not a fan of General Hospital, but I had such a good experience at St. Francis ER that I felt I had to share. If I have to go gently into that dark night this would be the place I would consider.

A past colonoscopy on 2/23/12. Great detail and service. Fast and efficient with pre-appointment video and instructions and inpatient processing. Excellent, patient-friendly, knowledgeable/skilled nurses, quick, safe, and painless procedure, post-procedural care instructions, spiritual care services, and hospital transportation available for home. Saint Francisco Memorial Hospital, a Dignity Group.

The best place to go for treatment related to the hand, arms, and shoulders.Gives exercises and treatments for relief of pain and discomfort. I had Sharon Verdi and thought her excellent for diagnosis and treatment.

San Francisco Clinical Neurosciences specializes in helping people put the pieces of their lives back together. Â This group offers medical adjustment counseling, cognitive remediation, psychotherapy, and neuropsychological testing.
I've been here a few times only to have my blood drawn and it was very fast. Â The most recent time they gave me juice and granola after they drew my blood because I was fasting.

I turned and missed a step while at Powell near Bart. The ambulance took me to St Francis. From the competent folks in ER to the X-Ray techs, to the staff on the floor where I spent the next two days, everyone was attentive, professional and responsive. I highly recommend this facility. It has been5 months, my broken leg is mending well and that is in no small part due to the excellent after-care by the staff on the eleventh floor (thank you staff and Don Kemp).
well let's see...this place is for dire emergencies or if you have a serious crack problem.

Wasn't pleased. I had my boyfriend take me to the ER a few months ago at midnight. There was ONE patient in the waiting room. My legs were going numb, and I was in excruciating pain. We asked the front desk 4 times how long it was going to be. It took almost 2 1/2 hours to get me in. My boyfriend and myself were both pissed off. What's the point of an ER if they don't treat you like you have an emergency. Â Didn't think my doc was that friendly, but the nurses were all nice! I'll stick to CPMC where I was treated much more to my standards.

I had the misfortune of having to take a friend to this ER today, but the nurses and others we met definitely helped to make a horrible situation more bearable. First of all, everyone we came in contact with here were nice and friendly and actually seemed to care how my friend was doing. This didn't feel like some big, impersonal, urban hospital. Secondly, I noticed that the staff were really nice to each other, too -- it really did seem as if all the nurses and support staff enjoyed working there and liked and respected their colleagues. They definitely have their challenges (the argumentative crackhead having a meltdown on the lobby floor for instance), but clearly this ER is doing something right.

I must say I was really surrpised with what I saw in the ER. I saw a handful of people go in while my friend had an emergency Constipation Treatment and they were seen within 2 minutes on a saturday night. My friend had to be taken to Emergency from a restaurant to the Hospital and they saw him really quickly. It's good to know that living in the Nob Hill area I will not have to worry if I am to have an emergency (KNOCK ON WOOD).
St. Francis Memorial Hospital -- one of only two General Hospital in the BAY AREA!!!!.....with specialized burn units

I went in there for something, maybe a fall down the stairs, had ex-rays, etc, yet I forgot all about it when I saw the most gorgeous guy (doctor). Â He stared, I tried not to stare back but the memory of him lingers. Of course, the meds they gave me were great, I didn't feel a thing for days. They took care of me I was in & out, everyone was nice.

WARNING! Â I went to St. Francis for doctor visits over 5 months, for surgery & then post-surgical follow-up, since my doctor's office is there. Â Today I learned the hospital is retroactively billing me almost $4,000 in surcharges for those visits -- that's FOUR THOUSAND DOLLARS, on top of the surgery, and the doctor's bills which I already paid, just for the privilege of using their space. My insurance company says Sorry, not covered! Â St. Francis says Not our problem, should be covered by your insurance! Â In my book, this is extortion! Â I'm switching doctors so I don't ever have to set foot in St. F again -- but that won't stop them wrecking my credit or worse if I don't pay. Â Anybody know a good pro bono lawyer? Â or a hospitable foreign country with socialized medicine?

9:00 pm... so student health at uc hastings was closed. Â called the 24 hour nurse hotline, and they recommended that i go to urgent care in case my throat closed up (tonsils were swelling and had white sores on them). Â i went to the urgent care listed on my school's website, but i couldn't get in!! Â it was supposed to be on the 3rd floor of the building, but i couldn't get in because i needed an ID card to scan. Â wellll after calling and not reaching anyone, i decided to just take a cab to saint francis memorial hospital just down the street.for 10 o clock at night, it was pretty empty! Â i was the only one in the ER. Â i got called in within 5 minutes. Â the nurse was so nice. Â he chatted me up so i relaxed a bit! Â i was having a panic attack so i was having even more trouble breathing.dr. chang came and saw me and within the next 10 minutes. Â he was very honest with me and didn't waste any time to explain what was wrong with me. Â he gave me two options of getting a very painful shot + some steroids right on the spot + no medication after besides advil if necessary, or he could give me a prescription to take for 10 days.i chose the very painful shot + steroids.well, apparently the entire process was $50. Â i was there for an hour and a half, and i thought it would take much longer + be much more costly. Â anyway, glad i came here. Â it was worth it. Â by the time i left, more people had come. Â yay. Â my cab rides there and back almost added up to that amount.

In my experience, this hospital is run by incompetent and dishonest people. I'd advise not to trust them with your medical records and if you need copies, go down in person if you can. I ordered my medical records history from them going back over a decade and ended up receiving another person's records! The person had a name similar to mine but totally different address, state ID and social security number, all of which I provided for them. When I called asking what I should do about it, they were very casual and asked I return them but not to contact the agencies who deal with HIPAA violations or state medical licensing and that they would do if for me. I was suspicious a hospital would report themselves (which they are required to do) but trusted them. I said I wanted to let the person know whose records I received or that they should and they laughed saying it would only upset them and they really didn't need to know. I didn't view the records but did see their name at the top of the forms under my cover sheets that had MY information all over them. I'm physically disabled and had to get assistance to the post office to return the huge package to the hospital. I had to borrow money to pay for the return shipping with certification of delivery to be sure it arrived there safely. It cost me a lot of money out of my extremely budgeted income to go down to mail it and for the postal charges. I mailed the receipts (which I still have copies of) to the correct department and person. I have called since and talked to people aware of this and told they'd call me back. Some of the people I had talked to in the medical records department said the reimbursement would be mailed out that week, that it was taken care of. That was over two months ago. I've called since only to get blown off and no one is taking me seriously. They are now saying it's still being 'taken care of' and acknowledged they never sent me the refund for mailing back someone else's records. Makes me wonder if they actually reported themselves if they are this dishonest.. and cheap.

If you are visiting avoid to go there. They overcharged for everything. For instance, they charged you $90 for using the elevator and for sitting in the waiting room!!! The front desk charged me $300 and then the doctor charged me $160 for the same visit. Who was right and who was wrong? I unfortunately paid $300. I have written, called to have explanations and never get any answer. It is too bad because the doctor was good but you can also find good doctors outside of the hospital.

I walked into the emergency ward wheezing heavily and gasping for air. Â The staff brought me in for treatment first and did the paperwork after I settled down. Â I am truly thankful for their professionalism and to the care I received!

These punks keep sending me bills for an accident that I had to visit the emergency room for a while ago. Doctors are elitist, ego-heads who treat the general public like test subjects. Stop sending me bills you money stealing, rich, middle-aged, over-educated jerks!

The ER is great. Â Visiting from out of town for a bachelorette weekend when one of the girls fell down some stairs (drunk). Â Woke up the next morning with a swollen, black & blue foot. Â St. Francis was the closest hospital so her and I took a cab to get her foot checked out. Â Now I should mention that I work in an ER in my hometown. Â This place Â made me want to quit my job and go to work there. Â The staff went above and beyond to not only make my friend comfortable but to also make me comfortable. Â They gave me drinks and snacks, updated us on the process, and we were in and out in about 3 hours. Â They even paid for our taxi back to the hotel. Â Unfortunately my friend broke her foot. Â The staff arranged for her to follow up with an ortho doc back home the following Monday. Â If I ever have an emergency in SF again, this is where I'm going. Â Back at work a few days later, my coworkers were amazed at my experience. Â Food and a free taxi? Â Hard to beat.

Just spent five days in the hospital after being admitted through the ER. Overall, the quality of care was great. The doctors appeared very competent, and they worked well together on my case. The ER was especially efficient. I think I met every nurse in the hospital, and they were all very nice and caring. Not everything was perfect, but the criticisms are minor. I'm very glad I was taken here.
The staff was great, the wait time was non existent and as emergency room experiences go it was probably the best. Â I was there 2 hours and non of it waiting in the lobby.

My daughter went to St. Francis Hospital ER for acute back pain, stomach cramps and diarreah after being turned away from a Urgent Care Facility. Â  Â She said she only waited 15 minutes and was treated immediately for her discomfort. Â It was a very difficult Â waiting at the Urgent Care facility for two hours with the discomfort she was in only to be told to go to the ER "because we can't help you." Â It was a tough day for her but she said the hospital's promptness and efficiency was a huge relief.
Elite 2021
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I came to get an outpatient ultrasound, which Is hard enough since I was told it was 24/7 and you just show up and they see you. No appointment. I then just show up and get sent to the basement which no one is here. I then went to the information desk who told me it's either building 5 or the basement of this building. Since, I have already walked to the basement, I decide to go to building 5 which I then ask I guess An admin in the little sectionals in building 5 where radiology is and I was talked to immediately like I was incompetent and/or a criminal because the building didn't open until 7 and I needed to leave. It was 6:15. Ok, well, I was sent here so where do I go now? Instead of trying to help me find the information or point me in the right direction, I was told this wasn't her job.Honestly, I worked at Emory in Atlanta and this is no way to treat someone who is just trying to find the proper place for care. In fact, I was only follow directions from your information desk.I am going to just assume that woman woke up in the wrong side of the bed but in return, you made a patient who is already getting an ultrasound for something scary more uneasy. appreciate it
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I am really appalled by my visit that I had the other day.with this Hospital, when I came in I explained to them that I have been hit in my face but they were very adamant about me wearing a mask. even though I already had one on.but check this out another person comes in a homeless guy. the nurse does not do anything to make him wear a mask he had his nose hanging out the whole time. this is very upsetting, I as a woman of color who has African ancestry was told  with a face injury, that I need to wear a mask I'm I'm just a regular person coming in , but a homeless individual can have their nose exposed what is wrong with this picture!?! and then they had the audacity to send in some Doctor Who is very nasty towards me,and confrontational and combative,I can't deal with these people ever again you GUYS NEED TO GET YOU'RE CRAP TOGETHER Â AS A HOSPITAL and learn equality and fairness across the whole entire board and Common Sense MENTAL ILLNESSES Â IS NOT A EXCUSE FOR A MASK VIOLATIONAnd if you are wondering where they put this individual they put them right in the lobby with their nose still hanging outâ
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: This was terrible. I'm not sure what San Francisco has done to healthcare but it's bad now. The place was like something I would imagine from a third world country. I was treated poorly. Treated like. Homeless junky. Was instantly dismissed by the nurse practitioner. And was essentially denied healthcare. They wouldn't even X Ray my goddamned ankle which they even agreed looked really bad. ( there is a weird bone not in the right place) I also have lumps growing around my body now and signs of lymphoma. They told me with half a passing glance that what I had was lipomas. They did not care about me. They are a giant scam. Ever since that zuckerburg put his name on that hospital, it has just been health care for the wealthy. The poor get murdered. Your money or your life! But isn't that the way it is in all of America these days?
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Elite 2021
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: The various teams at SF General try to make a difference. if you are coming here for a Vaccine or Virus test you will quickly notice there is no shortage of staff to walk you through the process. For Lab work it is quickly done once your sample has been obtained though the registration process can take a great deal of time on some days. Screening to enter the 2 main buildings can take a great deal of time also which is why I prefer early appointments before the crush of visitors. Garage Parking can become full by mid day , but there is a great deal of street parking just pay attention to street cleaning signs. SF General also partners with UCSF so the staff tends to be top notch but this campus is busy so have some patience , but never be shy if you need something.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I work here and usually I never set foot inside the cafeteria, but this morning, I was unusually hungry and had to settle for this junk.. Â They definitely need a new team of workers because the chefs can't cook and the servers and cashiers are the rudest people ever. Â Here you will find the nastiest tasting foods a kitchen could serve. Â When I got to the line to pay, this old Latin lady cashier was busy chatting it up with another person while collecting my money. Â No greeting or thank you, nothing but an ugly dry looking face that's typical of a comfortable city worker who feels unobligated to provide good service because she's protected by the union.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I went on an externship for BAMA here at building 90 ward 92 for phlebotomy and i have to say the nurses and MA's here all are super anxious and disorganized and they hold you to a standard that they don't even follow, hypocrites all I did was sit around kept my mouth shut and followed the directions of whoever was teaching me and it seems that some of them didn't want to sign my papers, and or listened to reason all they listened to was their feelings and became judgmental and hint at incompetence, somemight be undercover racist and each MA or CPT1 has their own method of doing a draw and each time you learn you learn a new way and it's very stressful for one student learning ineff ways to do the job...
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: My brother was born in this hospital back in 1985. A coworker with anxiety and I came to get the first Coronavirus Vaccine about 2 weeks ago after having been told repeatedly by housekeepers at work to get the shot. I think we got the Pfizer Vaccine. Smooth-sailing all the way! After getting the shot, we stayed in an area to see if we had reactions. I'd only eaten my morning fruit bowl prior to coming to General Hospital...
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: 3M Â is a disgusting dump, full of rude women and men pretending to be doctors and nurses, when all they really want is to be insidious unhelpful snotty, mean, jerks, the white men wander around doing nothing, while the women/women of color run that place.BUT BEWARE OF THE RECEPTIONIST TO YOUR RIGHTAHE HATES HERSELF AND YOU MORE.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Visited the hospital for the first time to get covid-19 vaccine in April. Was so impressed how professionally and well organized everything is. Not organized but even virtuously Orchestrated! Despite there was a line of patients, we moved from one point to another almost without delays, everyone was polite and thoughtful. Hats off to our medical heroes who are able to keep their class even in such unprecedented times. 10 out of 10.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: In April 1921, my mother, Kogan Iokhabet, Â was at the General Hospital, building 25 H38, room 3817. I want to express my gratitude to the doctor Gol for professionalism and attention. But my special thanks to nurse Ganna, who helped my mother as a nurse and as a translator. My mother is 99 years old and it is not very easy to deal with her, but Ganna was very kind and patient with her. When my mother was transferred to another department she helped me find all the contacts and advised me to contact her, if I have problems with communication.I thank the administration of the hospital for the correct selection of employees. Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Absolutely amazing experience.Yes the outside is scary to walk around... I got milk thrown at me. But Unit 5M women's health center is absolutely amazing. The entire staff is super friendly and works extremely fast. I came in with a issue that two other Drs could not fix. I was paired up with Dr. Allison and Dr.Mangashia please excuse me if I spelled their names wrong. During the procedure we literally just chatted about random stuff which made me so comfortable. Extremely amazed. I usually hate going to the drs because I either get scared or people are just plain mean to me. Coming back to them two forever. ( If I can )
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Specific to 5M women's clinic. Extremely rude and racist receptionist. I called in to make an appointment and the person guesses that I am a Chinese, directs me to a Chinese interpreter. When I pointed out that I never asked for a Chinese interpreter and try to correct the issue, she calls me rude. Not even an apology. Absolutely unacceptable, rude, racial receptionist.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Despite Mark's name being unfortunately attached to this hospital (because we know that if you throw enough money at an institution, they change their name), my memories here are more than decent. When we lived here in the city, they cared for not only me and my brother, but also my parents--and did an efficient job of it. Many of the nurses and physicians who work here do not get paid what they're worth, and for them to provide medical services to the indigent is awesome. The parking I found difficult, but the city is known for this and standard for pretty much any hospital or clinic in San Francisco. I also find it intimidatingly difficult to get around, due to the sheer size of it. But updates to the buildings have made it infinitely more snazzy compared to when I went there. Despite the reviews elsewhere here, my experiences were uniformly good, e.g. friendly and helpful.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I had a family member brought in with a massive stroke. They made mistakes all during his stay. The medical staff have horrible bed side manner. You have to call to alert staff your on the way to see your loved one. The care is minimum at best. By the time my relative left he had bedsores, a needed amputation and several other issues that all surfaced being under General Hospital care. I do not recommend this hospital. They do not operate in the best interest of the client.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: What a bad place to be at. They messed up my appointment after I waited fir 3.5 months. They have inexperienced people working there. They are extremely rude and literally hang up on you. PLEASE STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE IF YOU CAN !!!
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: When I comes to my business reviews, I typically stick with my Grandma's attitude that when I don't have anything good to say about a place I rather say nothing at all... except when a business has the responsibility to care for people on a much larger scale. As is the case with my brief ER visit and one day stay at Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital for a minor digestive issue.I am NOT going to list the things the hospital has done RIGHT for me while I was in their care simply because there is an expectation of a certain standard levels of care one expects to find at a major hospital and trauma center that doesn't warrant pointing out unless a hospital either exceeds or comes in below expectations (much like you would expect to get food at a restaurant).If you are one of the unlucky people who gets taken to or chose ZSFG Hospital, here's what you need to prepare for:- Very long wait times- Homeless and erratic people approaching you in the entrance area- Loud, often -colored, adult-themed arguments erupting in the waiting area (watch the little ones- Partly due to that, feeling generally unsafe- Being made to feel like a nuisance for showing up with "your" problem on "their" busy day - A never ending flood of 30 page probably well intended yet completely over-the-top (PAPER) surveys to fill out with pen on paper the old fashioned way (seriously Mark Zuckerberg?!?!) from every department you touched while you're there to arrive in the mail for weeks after you visited (has ZSFG heard of online surveys that don't kill even more trees)- Lots of "hiding" being policy and little explanation when dealing with treatment and care plans- Glaring disconnects between MDs and nursing staff- Feeling like you're not being helped or cared forAgain, to be fair, Zuckerberg San Francisco General did NOT ignore me, kick me to the curb or mistreat me! They provided me with the BARE MINIMUM level of care needed to provide to keep their jobs, maintain their licenses and retain their investors. To stay with my initial analogy about a restaurant not being praised simply because of the fact that they serve food (that fact alone is not worth mentioning because that's what a restaurant does, just like we have the reasonable assumption of care when we go to a hospital).I have had brief conversations with most of the nurses and doctors who treated me during my short stays at ZSFG so I could provide them with my honest direct-to-them feedback before I would post my review publicly. I'll update this review as needed.Update 8/7/2019: Over the past month I received three (3) more 1/2 inch thick envelopes from ZSFG - all of them just more ridiculous, voluminous surveys. Again, striving to improve ones business by asking for customer feedback is generally a very good thing, but considering how ZSFG goes about it makes it clear that in their particular case these are simply mindless job-security exercises that have always been spam in my book, but are now starting to become borderline harassment.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Now days, when everything changes quickly and not always for the better- it's So comforting to discover, that Gastroenterology department at Zuckerberg SF General Hospital under the supervision of Dr . LukeJohn Day stays the same- even better!Three years ago I had the same test, this year it went even more smoothly, thank you, Vanessa,Jay and, of course, Dr Day, who remember his patience and goes extra steps and pays extra attention in order Â to rule out suspicious symptoms and find a right way to treat or cure diagnosis. Even in time of COVID - the work and process is established perfectly , including personal touch , which is so imperative to the worried patients . Thank you, again!
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I've been trying to get physical therapy at their rehabilitation center for weeks. When my doctor put in the referral, she said they would call me in about a week. They never called. After that, it was really difficult to get through to a person to schedule an appointment. When I finally scheduled a video appointment with them, they let me know I would get the video link for the appointment right before the appointment in an email. I planned my day around it etc. Nothing. They didn't send anything, so I wasn't able to attend the appointment. Add to that that you can't get through to their office, so there's nothing I can do. I called the main line and they gave me attitude saying that they are probably with a patient. I told them I'm the patient they're supposed to be with lol. Â I called their comment line and no one picks up lol. And from what I can tell there's no way to email them from their site. Who knows how much longer I'll have to wait to get another appointment and hope that they'll send me the right information the next time. I am in pain every day. I previously avoided going here for blood labs, and I'm glad I trusted my instinct because this is truly not worth the trouble. If I can't schedule another appointment, I'll probably just go to Youtube for physical therapy exercises to help with my pain. Bad place that can't seem to get it together to do basic things. From the look of the reviews below...yikes.....Update, I just got an annoyed voicemail from their physical therapist John saying that I missed my appointment and to call them. LOL. Please say sike. (Of course, I tried calling them again, and they didn't answer)
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: It took an hour to get a hold of someone. He was really kind, but couldn't even find me in the system. If they're too bureaucratic to figure out a phone system and record management system, I definitely don't want my health in their hands.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I had a surgical operation to remove chronic otitis media and restore the eardrum in January 2018.During the operations when I was under the anesthesia they inserted the urinary catheter. After the operation was completed and I was released home, I started to have severe bleeding from my penis. They didn't tell me that a urinary catheter was inserted in the hospital .I was very scared and thought that maybe I started having kidney problems due to anesthesia or drugs.My family urgently took me to the Emergency room. There the doctor told me that during the surgery Â the urinary catheter was inserted and my bladder was damaged, and the catheter was inserted incorrectly. Ear surgery was also unsuccessful.eardrum perforation has not been eliminated and hearing has not improved .
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I have never encountered such rude nursing staff as I have at this hospital. And I work in medicine. They are overwhelmed and probably overworked and don't care about the patients. It's disheartening to see that. Nursing care is so imp in medicine. The clinical decisions by medical staff are borderline negligent. Zero coordination between medical staff. Please if you have any choice, ask to go to a different hospital.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Kiss my behind you nurses at SF general hospital. You cheap, rude ass wiping nurses in the ER department. Enjoy this season. Lol.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: My INSULIN PUMP was removed for overc24 hours causing lifelong trauma and extreme medical expenses. They keep hanging up on me .

Reviews: For Adult Urgent CareIt was lucky that I had a very competent and intelligent nurse to care for me. Emilia is one of the best nurses! While the other nurse practitioner told us they did not do ear wax irrigation anymore due to the lack of equipment or something. Emilia was able to set up the procedures quickly and helped clear the stubborn wax stuck in my ear that caused complete loss of my hearing in one and affecting the other. Excellent customer service and very professional!
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I understand this is a public hospital and they are likely over stretched. I've been dealing with them awhile lately & some of the people have been absolutely incredible & I'm very grateful to them. Other people and aspects of the way they operate can lead one to feel like they're trying to help you lose your mind. The BIGGEST REASON is their propensity to LIE TO YOU. And I've had more than one person who works there admit it to me. One even told me that they LIED TO HIM! So, part of their delivery of medical attention includes LIES!!! This is something I cannot comprehend. How can LYING be beneficial to a person in any way? There are times the whole thing is like a visit to The Twilight Zone. If you're the kind of person that likes to be involved in your care, ask a lot of questions, get names, ask for confirmations. BE VERY PRO-ACTIVE & then still be prepared for craziness. My last two weeks with an injury & pain...sometimes unbearable able has been hellish. JUST BE AWARE of what your experience might be.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: If you have been fortune enough to have a nurse like Eliza Newbold, are you in for a treat! This racist nurse has become notorious among patients for her self entitled racist attitude towards patients at this hospital. I'm sure is just as nasty of a person if nothing worse outside of the hospital. What a disgusting human being. She should be ashamed of herself for acting in such a nasty disgusting racist way towards her patients. I ok not a hospital in SF would hire this person
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: They do not answer their phones, their voice mail boxes are always full so there is literally no way to contact people about bill questions.They only accept payment in person or by mail (but only if you're able to take time off work). Talk bout rigging the system to make people late on payments.- Can't talk to someone about their issues- Cannot e-mail someone about their issues- Makes them call back daily hoping to talk to someone- Bill becomes lateGreat cycle!I did not choose to come here and am forced into this crazily inefficient mess.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I am truly appalled at the way my boyfriends nurse spoke to him while in front of me. I'm a nurse as well, but much younger than this woman and I politely told her I didn't appreciate the tone she was using. She then proceeded to argue with me and asking me what kind of nurse I was. Mind you, my complaint was not medication based or any thing like that. The only thing I was concerned with was the way she was speaking to him! I would NEVER speak to any of my patients the way she did. I've had patients cuss me out, throw things at me, and disrespect me and still have never spoken to them in such a horrible manner. My grandmother died of cancer in 2010, before she did she donated thousands of dollars to this hospital and for what?? To staff nurses who have terrible bedside manner? To staff nurses who disrespect not only their patients but their patients family as well? I will never settle for less than professional when it comes to healthcare and respect. The nurse told me that she would give us her supervisors number, and never did. We were told by her and by his doctor that we would get to speak with the charge nurse, and that never happened. I personally believe we are being discriminated based on our age. As a nurse, I know the rights that patients have. This hospital clearly is just as shady as Mark Zuckerberg himself.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Elite 2021

Reviews: UPDATE: We waited three hours for a 15 minutes "checkup". 7/3/19Dear Facebook dude, your hospital sucks. We have been waiting for over three hours now for a simple eye appointment. The office's excuse was that because tomorrow is a holiday (July 4), that's why no one is working. And there's proof with the picture attached below, your workers aren't working. So far she's been talking the whole hour. Only one doctor is able to attend to patients and they obviously overbook. We have come two other times and we have also waited 1-2 hours. Countless people are always waiting. They should build a bigger waiting room in my opinion. tip to the hospital: STOP OVERBOOKING. your patients have lives, they got somewhere to be instead of waiting for THREE HOURS (no lie) for a doctor to only take 10 minutes of their time in a patient. Fix your system. Zzzzz

Reviews: It's been about 2 weeks since this awful experience, and my swelling is just about gone, revealing an area that should be smooth but there is a pointy piece of bone sticking out just under the skin. Shoddy, shoddy work.Back in the late 80's I had a friend I'd made in recovery who was dying of AIDS on their AIDS unit. Another woman and myself used to go sit and read to her and just generally be there, although she was in and out of dementia by then.One night she slipped into a coma she would not be waking from. To our shock and horror, it was apparently normal procedure to use the still living, comatose bodies of AIDS patients to teach surgical students things like amputation.We would not allow it. We threw ourselves over her body and made a huge fuss. This went on for hours and frankly I'm amazed we weren't arrested. But Cindy went to her grave intact. I wonder if they still do that.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Many Posts about SF General only deal with the experience of a few hours there. Â I went to urgent care feeling lousy and was transferred to emergency then in the hospital for almost a month. Â SF General is like a village with many different departments dealing with things in different ways.I want to offer some convenient tips about SF General...1) You should know all of the doctors at SF General come from University of California, San Francisco. The doctors are among the best and brightest. Â The nurses and support staff are civil service employees of San Francisco County Government.2) If you are in pain - ask your doctor to consult with Dr. Pain. Â Dr. Pain is the nickname for a brilliant clinical pharmacologist Dr. Ed. Â Dr. Ed is the go to man dealing with pain issues. Â The MD's all refer to him for pain control issues. Â In my case pain was preventing me from getting discharged. Â With Dr. Ed's help I got out in three days. Â Usually your attending physician will defer to Dr. Pain's opinion regarding pain treatment. Â My sincere thanks to Dr. Ed for his help - he is a great guy who cares!3) Late Night MD's. Â If you are an inpatient and are suffering you should ask your nurse to call one of the two on call 24-hour doctors who are on campus at SFGH. Â Apparently, they come from the emergency room and cover all inpatients. Â Depending on circumstances they might take awhile to get to you as they also cover emergency and as a regional trauma center SFGH can get very busy late at night. Â I knew one of the doctors from my time in the emergency room and they are among the best at SFGH. Â They are excellent doctors who are caring and compassionate.4) The inpatient food at SF General is scandalously poor. Â I lost 60 pounds while in the hospital mainly due to throwing out almost all of the inpatient food I was served. Â The food was awful and I'm not a foodie. Â I threw it away as it was cold and sometimes stale - the day of my discharge I was served crispy pancakes. Â How stale does a pancake have to be you cannot cut it with a plastic knife and fork?My hint to you is if the food is too bad to eat ask your nurse and often they have several varieties of sandwiches at the nursing station. Â They also often have pudding and jello too. Â Availability varies so better to ask sooner rather than later before they are all gone...5) If you are calling for help know SFGH is notorious for telling people there is a number to call for help at which you will only get an answering machine or a notification that they don't make appointments and you have to come in person. Â I tried calling the patient advocate with a gripe and only got a chance to leave my number. Â I never got a call back from them...The only worthwhile number for help is the advice nurse line. Â That line might have an hour waiting time for being picked up but they usually can get things fixed.6) SFGH can be expensive... Â My inpatient bill was about $37,000 which thankfully was covered by insurance. Â That covered emergency, lab, medical treatment, X-Rays, and almost a month in the hospital.The services I got range from five stars to zero stars. Â I give zero stars to the inpatient food service and outpatient pharmacy (they are jackasses). Most other services were five stars.I wrote a longer review but it exceeds the maximum I can post here. Â So, I hope my tips might make your stay easier... Â If you want a copy of the full review message me...
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I am trying to figure out what else you guys expect to get here, especially since this is a government-funded facility where nobody pays a dime to access different services. Complaining about the hospital is easy but in my opinion the negative reviews are not justified. Sometimes it does take a few weeks to get an appointment but in the end the services you get are just the same as you would get at Kaiser, so all of you please start having realistic expectations and you'll see that the hospital provides the community with the basic healthcare we have been asking for years. I have had a few emergencies and I have nothing to say but wonderful things about the doctors and nurses who assisted me. Since Obamacare became law the general hospital has improved in a way I never thought it was possible, so please let's be grateful for what we have now.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: This experience is regarding a recent visit to the ER. The nurse practitioner on duty, Christina Jee was very rude, dismissive, condescending, and refused to listen to my concerns. Her attitude towards me as a patient was terrible and she needs to learn how to respect patients. She tried to prescribe me pain meds that I had already taken and did not work, so when I mentioned this to her, she simply dismissed me and told me to leave because there was no solution that she could provide. I am not going to take meds that don't work and that can't be the only solution they have available. The people who usually go to general hospital tend to be lower income individuals on Medi-Cal, or the homeless, however, I am a paying member as this insurance is not free for me. Regardless of how much you pay, every patient deserves compassion, especially when they are in severe pain and are not able to function. I spent 5 hours in the ER, 3 hours in Urgent care, and 2 hours in the pain clinic over the past few days. As of today, no solution and the severe nerve pain in the my leg that keeps me up at night is still there.The gentlemen at the front desk who was checking in patients (do not remember his name but he was Caucasian, middle aged, and had a beard or mustache) was terribly rude as well. I asked him to disinfect equipment that did not look particularly clean and the patient before me did not look clean, and he started swearing under his breath. I have never met ruder people in any hospital. I understand this hospital deals with a segment of the population that may be more challenging to deal with, but that does not give them the excuse to treat patients the way they do. Get out of healthcare if you can't be understanding.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: SFGH does not contract with any private insurance plans so expect outrageous out of network costs that your insurance won't cover. Avoid the ER at all costs unless you really need a Level 1 trauma center. I was in a hit and run accident. Ambulance took me to SFGH. I spent 4 hours in the ER, CT scan, and x-rays. Total bill was roughly $35k and insurance only covered maybe 10%. Care was poor. During my orthopedic follow-up, the doctor was appalled that they discharged me without proper immobilization and protection for a broken bone.Seriously - don't go there unless your life depends on it.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: The medical care is amazing but the billing will be outrageous. Â They actually don't tell you that there are an OUT OF NETWORK facility until your get your Explanations of Benefits and Hospital Bill. Â You are required to sign all of the paperwork without any wording in their documentation that they are OUT OF NETWORK for all insurances. Â You may not be slapped with all of the costs of the ER and medical facilities, but you WILL be in charge of a good 65 - 80 percent of charges even with insurance. Â  Be forewarned, you will be victim of the insurance companies and this hospital. Â You will asked to pay the pay bill regardless.My symptoms were not resolved under two visits to the ER, so I had to go back multiple times. Â The care was sufficient, but the cost is definitely not worth it.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: My great uncle came in because he fell and had trauma at 6am in the morning. And I never write a bad review unless it's warranted. I'll walk you step by step about my experience:1. Had to walk through a metal detector where my brother was stopped because he was wearing a belt. They made him basically pat every inch of his body to show the security detail he was of no threat. 2. The worker who was opening the doors for us (cause they all had locks on them) was sweet, but was later switched out with an incompetent coworker who took 15 min trying to find the room my great uncle was in even though I told her the name and wing. 3. We had to constantly ask and tell the doctors of my great uncle's health needs. The communication between the staff was horrendous.4. It took them more than 12 hours to move him to a more permanent room. 5. One nurse in particular in the emergency named Amber kicked my brother, sister, and I out of the room because we had too many people in there even though the rest of the staff said it was ok. She was horrible to work with and I would recommend asking for another nurse if she is your attendee. 6. They didn't let him eat or drink anything this entire time. They didn't even give him an IV. 7. His gout is flaring up because he's been laying down this entire time and the doctors are dragging their feet to give him his medicine. 8. UPDATE: they won't even let my great uncle transfer to another hospital even though he's stable and no longer technically a trauma patient. After reading all the reviews they probably want to overcharge us like everyone else.Overall, this hospital has been a nightmare to deal with. I understand that they're the only hospital in San Francisco that has the equipment to deal with trauma patients, but they need to seriously evaluate how they run their business (because General Hospital are businesses after all).
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: If I could give this hospital negative stars I would. I would also like to add I have put the exact message below on Facebook in several locations with no response. Thank you so much Mark Zuckerberg and any of the people in charge for not caring your hospital is this way...My sister died in your hospital, on June 1st. My mom and I traveled from Oregon down to your hospital and by the time we got there about six hours after she died (the soonest flight available) her belongings were gone through and things were STOLEN. We were provided a number to give the nurse for when reached the hospital so they could locate her belongings. Once we arrived her things were sitting under a nurses desk, not locked up where they should have been. We later find out that it's a known problem at your hospital Mark Zuckerberg.PLEASE can you address this problem. It's heartbreaking enough to lose a loved one, and then to deal with the fact that there last belongings have been gone through and things have been STOLEN makes it all that much worse. No one should have to go through this on top of losing someone. Get rid of the thief's that work there.... Get whatever you need to stop this from happening again... Make the necessary changes. Your name is on that building you should take pride in making it the best it can be.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Their billing has been so outrageous that Vox has even done a year-long investigation of their billing practices and have come out with this article: vox.com/policy-and-politâ¦In short: they do not accept the majority of private insurance plans and therefore end up out of network, where they end up charging anywhere up to 12X as much as medicare pays. This hospital price gouges those who are in emergency and trauma situations.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Elite 2021
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: I hadn't been back to this hospital in over 33 years, I was young and didn't have a decent job that offered healthcare at the time. My very first visit to the emergency room was memorable and I definitely would never forget it, while I did get good care it wasn't the best atmosphere. Sharing a triage with drug addicts and drunks with only a curtain dividing us wasn't ideal but oh well, what do want for free?! So this visit was a circumstance that I never thought would happen but that's how life is so you have to just roll with the punches, my husband lost his job and so our health care insurance had just ended. I was having unexplained heart issues (fast heartbeat), because of my first experience 33 years ago I did not want to go to the General Hospital emergency room. Finally I had no other choice but to go, long story short, the hospital has improved tremendously! I signed in, waited 10 mins for a nurse to take my vitals, waited another 10 minutes for a nurse to check me in, then lead me to my own private emergency room where I received immediate treatment from 2 wonderful informative doctors and a couple of amazing nurses. I was fine, hormones was just acting up (menopause), out the door in about 3 hrs (waiting for blood test results). I definitely will not hesitate to pay a visit to this hospital again! I have to say when we were PAYING for health insurance, I didn't receive this kind of great care, makes me wonder.
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: This hospital is the prime example of what is everything wrong with the health care today 1. Hospital is dirty including their bathrooms2. They take a long time to check you in and the same questions will be asked multiple times3. Very slow to act . Had a better care and response in urgent care then this ER4. No proper diagnosis 5. I was in deep pain for few hours and they just let me suffer6. High cost for bad service
Hospital Name: Zuckerberg San Francisco General Trauma and Hospital

Reviews: Worst clientele medical service every... employees too busy worried about lunch and young homeless people showering in the restrooms... because they are too embarrassed to go to a shelter to shower the right way. ER says appointment on Wed, last Sat, now Orthopedic says they don't know about the appointment. They never answer their phones, because why? LAZY & overpaid!!! Zuckerberg can F*CK OFF !!!
