Awesome covid testing! Staff was friendly in the most unbiased way! Reggie killed it while taking my vitals! He was quick and straight to the point! Dr. Kim Nguyen...one word...legendary. Answering all my medical questions with a friendly smile I could definitely tell even under the mask!

This review is more so for billing than it is of the actual service. Because service was average or slightly above average, my review is 2/5 rather than 1/5. I've been to the emergency room in MemorialCare twice now: once in October and once in March. The first time in October, I was informed that I had two health insurances on my social security: Medi-Cal (which is invalid and should no longer be used) and Anthem Blue Cross. This was the first time I was aware in 2 years I was still on Medi-Cal so I was shocked to find it was still on my social. Even more shocked that they pulled my social rather than use my insurance card that I provided them. My health plan states that I cannot be on Medi-Cal while having an HSA. I Â specifically told MemorialCare not once, but MULTIPLE times that Medi-Cal is the incorrect insurance and should not be billed when they asked me to authorize the charge against my health insurance. Paraphrasing, I was told it didn't matter what I said because they will bill Anthem and then Medi-Cal if Anthem did not cover everything. When they stated this, I told them NOT to bill Medi-Cal and explained to them why over and over. They said they'll do the best they can which translate to: we will bill whoever we want because we want to make money as a hospital. Surprise surprise, I find out that my bill was billed to both insurances and now I have a headache and a mess to untangle. When I called MemorialCare billing to sort this out, I was basically told they would do the best they can, which meant I was still screwed and had to clean this mess up myself. In March when I ended up in the emergency room again (my fault for thinking everything was settled), I specifically told them not to run my Social and to run my Anthem insurance as it should have been, explaining once again, I was no longer eligible for Medi-Cal and Medi-Cal made a mistake for keeping me on their plan (had to call Medi-Cal to do a clean up as well). They couldn't guarantee me that Medi-Cal wouldn't be billed and I would have to follow up with billing. This is absolutely ridiculous

Terrible Hospital my husband had a hip replacement and because of someone did not do the job right He had A very deep infection from the surgery room because they did not clean and sanitize something drawing the surgeryMy husband have to go through 4 more surgery after the infection happen

Just in regards to how they're handling covid protocols - went in June 2021 as soon as you're in the doors waiting for ER they're not making anyone wear masks (people accompanying patients too) their own NURSES were not wearing masks some had it on their chin others didn't have it all and would come to my room like that. Very disappointed. Dr. Kiarash Noorizadeh was also the rudest dr I've encountered. She wouldn't let me talk after asking me a question and said she thought i should leave since i was refusing treatment (I was unconscious when they brought me in so i was unable to swallow a pill they gave me it just came back out when they shoved it in my mouth, that was her example of me refusing treatment)

I went to the ER Saturday after a fall. Found out I fractured my patella (knee cap). Surgery was scheduled for the next day. Everyone was attentive, efficient and kind. After being admitted, the nurses took great care of me pre and post surgery. I felt like I had great quality care and as hospital stays go, this was as good as I could imagine.

I've delivered both of my children here (many years ago now) as well as recently used their surgical department. Â I have to say, I've never had a less than stellar experience. Â I felt that between just their overall professionalism and their genuine care sets them apart from other hospitals. Â I never felt that my concern(s) were not listened to or brushed aside. Â I'd recommend their facility to anyone.

This is about the Breast Center at Orange Coast. Been going to them yearly for mammograms, for about 15 years. Moved to the desert and the first year I went local. Didn't like the facility or the brusque way I was treated.Returned this year to Orange Coast and the difference is remarkable. First of all it's a quiet, nicely decorated space for a waiting room. Everyone is treated with care and respect. At this moment during COVID, they are very careful to limit the number of people in the waiting area as well as in the rooms in which you change into a gown and lock up your belongings.Their technicians are not clinical in the way they treat patients. They are unflaggingly pleasant and take their time as they go through the testing. A few days after I got scanned I received a call that there was something they saw on the mammogram and needed to take a second look, plus reserve the right to perform an ultrasound.  Immediately getting nervous on the phone the person could hear it and offered to get in touch with my primary care doctor for me to get the permission to do the testing. They scheduled me quickly and were very caring when I got there.To my surprise and relief, although I needed the ultrasound, someone looked at it on the spot and I got the good news as soon as the radiologist had seen it. It pays to schlep from Palm Springs for this and I've learned my lesson.

I've been tho to this facility many times for many occasions. This was the most memorable one of all. I met two of the most wonder couple of people from California Heat Assoiates at Memorial Org Coast Med Ctr in Fountain Valley, Ca.Ron was just super. He listened to me and seemed like we knew each other for ages! He 'nursed' be along the halls Â from one procedure to the next. Who does that?? Genova was in line for kudos also. Not just because she laughed at my musings, she was as pro as they get! I can whole heartedly (no pun intended here :) ), recommend that this is the place to go for prompt, curtious and profesional help, if you are in need of heart concens.

It's very clean and I have never had problems with parking. I go there for my obgyn appointments with Dr Minal Mehta and I love it! It's always a great welcoming from the valley guys, they people by the entrance who checks your temperature, they security guys and everybody who you passes that works there.

This a review specifically for Labor and Delivery!My husband and I want to give the biggest shout out to all of the nurses and Doctors and everyone else who works in this department. We had our daughter there on 9/12/2020 and it was the best experience we could have asked for. It started out with normal labor, but ended up being and emergent C-section. We had the most caring and nurturing staff help us from the check in all the way to our discharge. They made us feel as though our daughter was the most important baby in the hospital the entire time. We know they see dozens of babies each day, but our care was that good, that we felt like we were the only ones being looked after! We have to say that Nurse Leah is simply the absolute Â best! She made our terrifying situation bearable and made it extremely clear that she cared about our small family! She checked in on us several times after we had moved to postpartum which wasn't even her department!! You can't ask for that level of care! I cannot remember every single person that helped us, but those names I do remember are nurses Gigi, Sheila and Joanne, and our anesthesiologist (cannot remember her name either). We can't say thank you enough or show our gratitude for how well you all handled our delivery! There were several other nurses who were amazing and I wish I could remember their names, but please know we appreciate you just as much!! If you are looking for an OB, Dr Elizabeth Tracy should be your pick! She was so calm and professional throughout the entire pregnancy and through the delivery! We couldn't have done it without her! Needless to say, we were extremely impressed by this team (the A-team) and would absolutely, without a doubt, have our second child here again...of course with the same staff! Baby "Brooklyn Eleanor "Ellie" Hay" thanks you all!

Antoinette from the Patient Relations department reached out to me about my experience a couple days after I posted my initial review. I appreciated her following up with me as we discussed my experience and how I felt. She asked good questions and was engaged and assured me that any information I give her will be routed to the appropriate party for feedback and will not be used in any type of retaliation. I do hope that she takes my feedback into consideration about communicating the visitation policy upfront for everyone visiting the hospital but she was nice in offering additional care to my grandma (although she already checked out). Antoinette did also mention that there were translators available if we were not allowed to be with her, but I'm not sure if there was someone with her, who spoke our language, that could have eased her.Nevertheless, I appreciate Memorial Care following back up with me with their prompt response. Hopefully, my grandma will not be back to ANY hospital, but if so, we will give Memorial Care another chance, as Antoinette hoped we would.
Elite 2021
Elite 2021
I'm in ER waiting for Dr. more Â 2 hr Â not happy for that early morning Er not busy Â still taking long time Â i don't know what happened to the day time how to take care the patient

It was Friday night at 10:15 and my wife told me her water broke - 1 1/2 weeks early so we were caught completely off guard. We packed up the car and headed to labor & delivery. When we got there we were welcomed by our nurse Ashley. From that first interaction we knew this would be a great experience. Ashley was patient, helpful and calm which put us at ease. She called in the midwife on duty, Sarah, who was the one we had hoped would deliver our son. The care team was absolutely amazing! We couldn't have asked for a better experience! While Ashley missed the delivery because it was right at shift change, she came to check on us in postpartum the next day. That extra stop went a long way in making us feel cared for. Thank you Orange Coast Memorial!

I had my son last year in labor and delivery at Orange coast memorial. I had the best experience, Even though I ended up in the hospital for 5 days due to my son being very stubborn on coming out of the womb. Mary Barton and Ashley were my primary care takers. could not ask for better people to help my little family on growing. Thank you so much.

I have nothing to discuss with anyone from this 3rd world medical facility. Â Thank God we got her to Hoag the following day. Â She spent a week in the ICU and nearly died. I love Memorial Care Orange Coast Â Hospital. Doctors and nurses are wonderful Best hospital in Oranges County. For your convince valet parking.

I had a perfect delivery for my daughter but giving 3 stars because I thought the nurse who picked up the phone who I called for help on the button felt lazy and just felt like she didn't want to help or her tone of voice. I was transported by the paramedics to Orange Coast ER and I was treated very fast and with a lot of care and respect. The nurses were great and the doctor was amazing, they made me feel safe. Orange Coast Medical Center is one of the hospital that I will choose without hesitation.

My wife gave birth here and my son was in the NICU for nearly 3 weeks. The staff, from the valet's to the security to the nurses and doctors, were all wonderful and made a hard experience far easier to deal with. Not only was everyone very professional, kind, and compassionate but they took wonderful care of my wife and son. My wife ended up having to have an unplanned C-section and they helped to make what was a scary situation as easy as possible and made us feel like we were in great hands through the whole experience. When my son was born he ended up having some complications and had to spend some time in the NICU. The NICU nurses and doctors were without a doubt some of the most profession and caring individuals I have ever had the pleasure to work with. They took wonderful care of my son and made sure no stone was left unturned in making sure he was healthy by the time that he came home. I cannot thank the wonderful staff at this hospital enough for all that they did for my family.

I wanted to share how Wonderful the Doctors & Nurses are at Orange Coast Memorial Hospital. I came in thinking I had stomach flu and thanks to Dr B Rhee (ED) they found an 8mm stone in my bile duct. Thank you to Dr P Chen & Dr la for doing an ERCP on a Sunday morning and Edinger Drs B Yu & K Don for managing my care. Dr T Nguyen & Dr R Zelner we're also very helpful in my care. I recovered in a non -Covid area, Oncology and Nurses Luigi, Nicole, Diana, Jenn & Mandy took excellent care of me along with PCA's Sinthia, Olga, Mirna & Ileana. In this crazy times with a Hospital full of Covid patients I felt safe & well taken care of. I highly recommend Orange Coast Memorial Hospital.

Larry had major back surgery and he also had it last year at Fountain Valley and that was a night mare. He ended up in rehab for two weeks. I refused to go there and I chose here. I can't say enough about how great the nurses and doctors were. They were compassion, patience and gave service I think more than they had to. They were friendly and I called the nurse, Annie, twice during the night and she was very helpful, friendly, and a sense of humor. Her assistant, Susan, helped prep Larry to come home. The surgeon's Dr Khan and Dr Ryan are the best. I saw Dr Ryan after the surgery in the hospital and he is so nice and friendly and never acts like he is in a hurry. The hospital doctor, Dr Nanissir, was also caring and took his time with us. I don't know everyone's name, however; they were all great. The room was perfect also. The one drawback was the relief doctor for Dr Khan. Dr Zachery was not very friendly and we had a disagreement on when Larry was to come home. He finally agreed to one more day. Larry couldn't even get out of bed by himself and still can't. This doctor didn't seem to care and had no compassion at all. I don't think he wanted to be there. The case manager got us set-up for Home Health Care before we left the hospital and we will need this for sure. It will be a long recovery process and if done correctly then the surgery will be a success.

I so wish I did not have to leave this feedback however I have been trying to contact risk management for weeks the mailbox is full. I was admitted to the emergency room department with the laceration to my leg in 2020. My injury was due to a glass door falling on me and I required staples. The doctor and nurses treated me in a hallway, no pain medication and left me for over two hours unattended, only to staple my leg shut with no x-ray. Later I found out that the doctors negligence led to an additional surgery needed to remove a number of pieces of glass stuck in the bone and near my artery. I'm lucky to be alive however this incident cost me thousands and thousands of dollars and I have no one to talk to at the hospital regarding this negligence. I can only hope by leaving this message here that someone will contact me to further review my incident.

The level of care provided was average. Â Basic, obligatory at best. Â The nurse assigned "Gabby" lacked any human emotion or compassion. Â The fact she chose to be a nurse is shocking given her dismissive attitude towards the patients. Â This hospital rushes it's internal care and sends the sick or injured home before they are well or prepared. Â My advise, drive to Hoag or down the street to Fountain Valley.

I wished I read the reviews of the ER here before driving my 4 year old daughter here to care for her open wound to the forehead. It is something I regret each time I look at her forehead now four months later with a scar larger than the wound she came in to have closed. We were never given the option to do stitch or dermabond. PA told us the hospital now use dermabond instead of stitches. He proceeds in a very rushed manner to work on my daughters cut. This all happened in the hallway. After he was done my husband asked why he didn't hold the skin together longer to allow glue to dry. He said "this glue dries very quickly." Â (He held to her wound no longer than 5-10 seconds) He applied only one layer. After seeing the way he did it and how little time he held to the wound we had this terrible sinking feeling that the wound did not closed. We asked about expectations of scarring. He said, "hopefully no scar; if there is scarring it would be a thin line."We followed the after care to the T. We kept the area dry and about a month later on thanksgiving the tape finally fell off and I was in tears to see how unsightly and big the scar actually is. Then I started to do research on surgical skin glue (dermabond). Everything became clear to me that the PA did not know what he was doing. Had he applied the glue correctly then the scarring would be insignificant like he had described but he failed to do what he was supposed to do. According to childrensmd.org , "Wounds in areas of high skin tension such as the arm, leg or forehead will require stitches instead of dermabond." Â (My child had a cut to the forehead but was never given the option of having stitches done at all). According to my research doctors must "Hold the edges together for at least 30 seconds before releasing, with at least three layers applied to ensure optimal strength to the wound closure." Â The PA applied one single later and held it for under 10 seconds and he was on his way. To know that my little girl could have avoided this big scar to her face had the PA offered her stitches instead of glue or had he held her skin for a necessary amount of time to allow that glue to dry just breaks my heart. Â He was heartlessly reckless. He was there to close a wound to a little girl's face but he behaved as tho he had to finish closing down a restaurant for the day; quick and without thought. I've addressed this to the hospital management but they were quickly dismissive claiming "care was deemed appropriate"I have gathered the medical records and evidences and will be filing a grievance against the hospital to the state.

I went to the emergency on July 6th because I had gallstones and I just had another gallbladder attack. I was admitted to the hospital and had surgery that same day and was kept over night. I just started getting billed SEPARATELY for everything. Emergency room is 1 bill, the hospital another bill. The ultrasound another bill...the list goes on. When I contacted the Billing department not only was I told that they couldn't merge all the bills into one bill. (Fountain Valley and St Joseph hospital have all merged all the bills into one for my family nembers in the past. They've had the same surgery i did) but they told me POINT BLANK "we give you 11 months to pay your bill" over $3,000 for the hospital ALONE. Not including the other bills that are an additional $2,000. But they also told me I had to pay over $300 a month. Yes, because that sounds so reasonable during a pandemic when people have been furloughed like me and have other bills to pay. Like my rent. No sympathy whatsoever from them. They sent me a form to fill out and I emailed them a long email where I included my bills and rent I pay monthly. They never responded to that email. They have the worse customer service I have ever encountered in a hospital. If you're in the Orange County area, do not go to this hospital. Go to Fountain Valley hospital instead they will accommodate your bill so that you're able to pay what you can even if takes longer. Oh. Also, when i was discharged from the hospital, they were refusing to provide a wheelchair for me. When I insisted on one, the nurse who wheeled me ouvt, kept complaining to the security guard and left me sitting in the sun. The security guard felt bad for me and he moved me to a shade nearby while I waited for my ride home. When I stepped into my car, the nurse then complained "if she can walk, why did she need a wheelchair?" I was humiliated and angry. STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!!!

Always pay with a card! Their standard of procedure is you check in, they check your insurance, if you have a copayment, they collect it, ask you to sit and wait to get called back. Without fail, this is how they operate. My copayment is $10. On a few occasion, I had cash on me and thought, "Oh I'll just pay cash. I've got $10 right here." I either didn't ask for a receipt or take one. About 3 months later, I get a bill for $10 copayment for the visit. It was my fault for not taking a receipt because I can't prove that I paid it. It wasn't until I got a few more bills for the visits where I paid my copayment in cash that it dawned on me what they're doing. Someone is pocketing the money and double billing. Shame on you MemorialCare. Learned my lesson to always pay with a card for the digital trail and proof. Don't let them rob you like they did me. Might be a small amount but it's the principle and dishonesty of their actions.

I was just in the ER there this morning and as soon as they wheeled me in they were so fast getting me back into a room and getting my pain under control. I hate to leave a negative review for any nurses as I have friends in the nursing field and understand what a tough and demanding job it can be.However, the service my mom received when she visited the Emergency Room "Hall" after coming down with food poisoning was appalling and unacceptable. I didn't arrive until after the nurse had already inserted the IV needle in her arm but had noticed droplets of blood on the sheets. My mom was so weak and fatigued from throwing up but she managed to tell me to call the nurse because her arm was hurting so bad. When I tracked down the nurse, she came over and lifted my mom's arm and discovered that the needle was not properly inserted. I asked her if she could try again on the other arm and to please be careful to which the nurse scoffed in reply, "We are always careful". I was really upset but held my tongue as I did not want to cause a situation where the quality of my mom's medical care would be further compromised under the "care" of this nurse. I stayed with my mom to change her bed pans and had to request additional pans from other nurses. The assigned nurse was busy at her computer station inputting information for the majority of the hour or so that my mom was in the Emergency Hall. Each time I would have to "bother" her to request something for my mom. This nurse could have obviously cared less. I feel EXTREMELY SAD to think that anyone's sick parent would have to go to the ER alone and be stuck with a nurse like her. I was so thankful that I was able to be there to help my mom get the care that she so badly needed. I wish the assigned nurse had owned up to her mistake and redeem herself by taking extra care of my mom after that failed IV injection, but that was not the case. She was inattentive and rude. My mom had to stay overnight. I was too disheartened by the quality of service at the Emergency Hall so I stayed overnight with her.Thank you to Katrina the Emergency Technician who brought my mom an extra warm blanket and transferred my mom by stretcher to her overnight room when she was too weak to get up.Wishing everyone good health.

My husband was sent to the Memorial Care Nuclear Medicine office for some Â pre-op testing. Â My husband is 88 years old and in quite good health for his age, so he has had little experience with this type of testing. Â He was apprehensive and nervous. Â We were met by Alfred M., who immediately put both my husband and myself at ease. Â He fully explained what tests were going to be done, how they were going to be done and how long they would take. Â He inserted an IV, asked my husband to put on a gown, administered the first dose and led my husband to a seat to wait for the medicine to take effect. Â Noticing that my husband was cold, he quickly brought him a blanket! Â Soon after that, Viet approached, bringing me a chair and a pillow for my husband's back. Â He began speaking to my husband in a soothing tone, telling him to be comfortable and relax. Â He teased my husband a little bit, telling him that if he thought everything would be OK, it would be. Â Both Alfred and Viet checked on us regularly until it was time for the first test. Â Alfred allowed me to be with my husband for the test, which involved a scary-looking machine that turned out to be no more than something to take photos of his heart. Â He told him how long it would take, that the machine would come close but not touch him, covered him with another blanket and did the test. Â Then he said that I couldn't be present for the next test, which was a chemical stress test, but that as soon as it was over, he would come and get me. Â He came back after the test was done, brought me back to the same room and there were sandwiches and apple juice for us! Â He knew my husband hadn't been allowed to eat anything the night before, so here was a snack! Â After we ate, Viet returned to remove my husband's IV. Â Then he prepared him for the last test, wrapping him tenderly in more blankets and reassuring him. Â As the final test was being done, Viet spent time with me, showing me breathing techniques to help warm the body and relax the spine. Â He is a real philosopher and a very kind gentleman! Â When the test was finished, he helped my husband up and stayed with us while he dressed. Â He escorted us to the door, always giving positive reinforcement. Â I can't say enough about the kindness and goodness these men showed us. Â Everyone in Nuclear Medicine was kind and understanding, but these two gentlemen went out of their way to make a scary experience a good memory. Â They are a credit to their profession. Â I wish I could have hugged them both, because they truly deserve it!
