Eric & Cora (?) were caring & helpful during my check in & Eric was also super nice & careful about getting me out to my car. Overall a good experience. :)

The nurses are very rude. My son couldnt breathe and it took them over 20 min to even check his vitals even knowing that he has asthma and a long medical history. I would only suggest going here if you are unconscience and have no other other choice because you are unable to talk or if you are bleeding to death. The wait to be seen is incredibly long

This review is for the Quest Diagnostics Lab in suite 2100 only. Â This facility is easy to access from the freeway and the parking was easy (albeit there were only a few spots left in the lot, I did see a parking structure as well). I was able to make an appointment the day before for an appointment. Usually going to a Quest for walk in is a straight up nightmare in my experience. i've waited for HOURS with a walk in, so I was skeptical that an appointment would have me seen on time.There were only 2 people ahead of me - I'm not sure if this is the regular light crowd or if it was a slow day.. Their computer systems were down and they were experiencing some light construction. With those set backs, I was seen about 10 minutes after my appointment (I checked in about 10 minutes before the appointment).My phlebotomist, Cindy, was very kind. She asked if I was doing ok about half way through (even though I wasn't showing signs of stress or anything) and as the usual routine goes, told me before the needle went in and came out. It was pretty painless. I think I'll try this location next time I need to get blood work done

Two parts to this review... Billing and Labor and Delivery Labor and Delivery: FIVE STARSI'll keep this short and sweet. My delivery nurse (who had been there for about 30 years) and The baby's Nurse (who treated my son like she would her own. She was so happy and excited for us, being a mom herself it's like she was reliving her own kids' births. I loved that about her.) were the absolute sweetest. All of my other nurses (I feel like I had many- maybe 4 others, were all great too) Nice small intimate setting and quality service. No issues at all with staff. They were all wonderful! Billing: Where to begin..?? Had our first daughter at Hoag and our son here at OC Memorial in FV. Just because it's a smaller hospital than Hoag and it's in Fountain Valley, DON'T BE FOOLED. It will cost you more to have a baby here. I was told over the phone that our labor and delivery bill would be well less than 10k, but it was not. It was 11k. This is for a standard delivery, no issues, one overnight stay. This change did not include my Ob's delivery charge. (Luckily our insurance covered most of my OB care, which was just one charge from pre and post). With Hoag, I was able to negotiate a 15% lower price (if we paid the balance in cash within 24 hours) since after our deductible, we still owed around 5k. That helped us out a lot! Yay Hoag!!!! Awesome customer service. With Orange Coast, after my husband and I with our kids, sat down with a billing specialist, told us they don't lower a bill or do any sort of negotiating, because they are a non for profit hospital. This is because WE HAVE INSURANCE. Now, had we been cash paying, there is a very good chance that we would not have been charged 11k, but in fact only charged a percentage of that amount. The lady told us that the amount would be lower had we paid in cash. I regret even telling them we had insurance. Then I probably could have done some negotiating. Something for you all to keep in mind. So good job, take advantage of the people with insurance, whom on top of their monthly premium, still have to meet their deductible before any benefits kick in. With Hoag, there was a labor and delivery fee, room and board and then my OB delivery charge. That is all. With Orange Coast, every single thing you can possibly imagine was billed and there were some categories that seemed to be repeated, but the billing specialist reassured me that they were all different, separate categories. It was a four page bill. Very overwhelming. The other thing that bothered us was that we received a bill for our baby's hearing test. A standard and universal procedure. We were told that our insurance was in network but the reason we were charged a percentage of the hearing screening (180$) was because the company they used was out of our network. This is their fault, not ours therefore we shouldn't have had to pay a dime. We should not have been told that the hospital was in network if a service provided was not. Overall, the staff was great and I do like that the hospital was smaller than Hoag, but service at Hoag was good too and it cost us way less in the end to have our baby there.

I had 3 total surgeries here. The emergency surgeon Dr. Thang Nguyen saved my life. The nurses and staff were always great and treated me and my family well. I would recommend this hospital to anyone.

I brought my husband into the ER.He was very ill with bronchitis. He had visited a Minute Clinic and the nurse only gave him cough syrup, no antibiotic, even though I repeatedly asked for one to be prescribed for him.3 days later I had to take him to the ER because he was so very sick. He was given superb care. He was tested, admitted to the hospital and given treatment.I feel Dr. Tom in the Emergency room saved my husband's life. His excellent treatment continued after he was admitted to the hospital. Â All of the doctors and nurses provided an outstanding level of care.Thanks to Orange Coast Memorial Medical Center my husband is returning to his good health.

Dr. Vergara is hands down the rudest doctor/pediatrician we ever met. Our son was born at Orange Coast Memorial Hospital and we were unable to check out until seen by Dr. Vergara, the pediatrician who was working at the time. He came in late and had one hand in his pocket the entire time as he attempted to examine our baby boy. He was extremely apathetic and the examination was pointless given his demeanor. How is this guy a pediatrician? It's mind blowing that he has decent reviews. Very unfortunate that our hospital stay concluded with his visit because and we had a good experience with the rest of the staff during our stay. MemorialCare should be embarrassed to have him as a part of their network. He single handedly ruined our experience and we will never be back to receive any medical care from MemorialCare Orange Coast again.

Male nurse Garrett is amazing! He went above and beyond his job to care for my dad. Someone give him a raise, he handles his job professionally and with great kindness. He made an unpleasant thing into a joy. Thanks Garret!

I checked myself out because I couldn't trust their unprofessional doctors. Â Their lack of humanity and compassion shows deeply in the way they treat their patients. Â Or should I say there for lack of. Â Left in the restroom for 20 minutes in a wheelchair.. left alone in my room crying for help . Â If you want to die come here...

Labor and delivery. The one important thing about having a baby is the details of your hospital. OC memorial beats FV hospital. I gave birth at both and wish I had gone to OCM from the beginning. First off, parking. The structure is in back so you park near the child center for easy access. However, going into labor between like...9pm-6am or somthing like that, the doors will be locked and you have to go through the front of the hospital ER. Then they wheel u back to L&D. The delivery rooms are cozy and a bit small. But everything you do is in that room. The nurses are very warm loving ladies. I wanted a bow hat for my girl, so the nurse made me one even though they dont have them. The L&D dept gets their own anesthesiologist so no sharing with the rest of the hospital. Now the biggest concern of all, semi-private rooms. There are only a few private rooms, so most likely youll get a semi-private room. If its busy, they put you in the room with someone who is leaving next day and dont fill the room for the remainder of your stay. I got lucky and had a baby when they werent busy. But i still got a semi-private room. Hubby got a bed at least. The showers were not fun. The nozzle is low like for wheel chairs. I guess they want you sitting when you shower. The food is like any other hospital. They had a vietnamese option which is more like rice instead of mashed potatoes and rice porridge for soup. Regardless, you have so much good food surrounding the hospital. In regards to the recovery nurse, they were ok. They pretty much left us alone. There is quiet time from 2-4pm. If you have guests, they will be kicked out. Mine were not, maybe the nurses use that for their quiet time too lol. I chose to breastfeed and give formula, so they brought me an electric pump with tons of new parts and a case of formula. Baby and me were fully stocked, i came home with enough to last me 2 days. I even got to take the new madela pump parts and collustrum bottles home, just not the actual machine. Overall a great hospital, i would recommend it for having a baby.

I have absolutely nothing negative to say about the staff and doctors that were assigned to my care. Â I was in bad shape and didn't know it and they treated me with the utmostâ dignity and respect. I was blessed with the most knowledgeableâ, supportive, and kind nurses. Â One nurse, in particular, spent time explainâing to me what my challenges might be and to be vigilant about my condition and diet. Â Also, I was treated exceptionally well by aâ technician who assisted in a procedure that was required. Â  I am now on an unexpected medical journey, made easier by the kindness of strangers.

I was rushed to the hospital from a 911 call that was called in from my friends at Beach Point Church in Fountain Valley on the 17th of August.Severe stomach pains and passed out was the issue that night. Â The emergency room Dr. That evening ordered a CT Scan on my belly and was concerned with something he was seeing. The Dr. Called in a surgeon, named Dr. Vannix to look at the scan report and decided to do exploratory surgery, which was a complete success !!!!!!!!!!My stay in the hospital was absolutely a great experience. Â From the Dr.s to Nurses to the people who came in the rooms to take the food orders were wonderful.The food was so good, it tasted like I made it at home.I really want to give a shout out to this Orange Coast Memorial for taking great care of me for the week that I was there.My nurse Gary was the best. Thank youThank you very muchAngela J. krebs

I am writing this review in regard to my experience at Orange Coast Memorial for my gastric bypass surgery performed by Dr. Ali and overnight stay. Originally I was scheduled to have my surgery at Fountain Valley Hospital. After reading the horrid reviews on that hospital I requested for my services to be transferred to Orange Coast Â On January 18, 2017 I had gastric bypass surgery performed on me. This review will be on the entire experience.The valet parking was awesome, what a convince. The admission check in was a breeze and staff was polite. After check in was completed the valet staff called for a gentleman to take us to the surgery department via tram. Once in the surgery department a friendly gentleman checked me in, advised me and my husband of my surgery time and explained to him how to follow the monitor on my progress once called back for pre op. So far so good. Once into the pre op my experience changed. My pre op RN (Wish I could remember her name) was down right rude. Her bed side manner was terrible and she was extremely short with my husband when he came back to wait with me. For me this was a huge deal and I was nervous, the mannerism of this RN did not help with that but instead heightened it. Even my husband said she was rude to him. Of course at that point I was now wondering after all if I made the right decision by switching from Fountain Valley. My surgery was scheduled for 1pm but the surgical team did not come and meet with me until about 3pm. To me this was not really an issue. I understand factors or complications with patient prior to me can effect the surgery time. My issue was having to wait in the pre op with a rude RN. When the surgeon, RN that would be in my surgery room and the anesthesiologist came to let me know it was time for me I was so relieved. Dr Ali is great, personable and patient. He answered all my and my husband's questions. The surgery team was great as well. My experience in the recovery room is fuzzy so I am unable to leave a review. My husband did say however, all the staff were very nice. I was so happy with my room as I got lucky and was assigned to a solo room. The attending staff for my stay in the hospital were nice. They answered all questions and helped with anything I asked for. My experience with my discharge the next day was not favorable. I felt completely rushed. The nurse who discharged me did not really go over my discharge instructions. Of course I was tired and not thinking to straight with the medications and the pain I was experiencing so all the questions I needed answered I did not think of until I went home. In summary, if my experience with the pre op RN and my discharging nurse were better I would definitely give this hospital a 5 star. With these negative experiences I can only rate this hospital at a 3. I am unsure if these reviews really make a difference to management. If they do I would recommend pre op staff be coached on their attitudes. These RN's are the front line and are who patients see before their operation. The experience with the pre op staff can set the whole tone for a patient. Stress and feelings of wondering if you chose the right hospital right before surgery stink.

The Urgent Care is really great. It is clean and ran well the staff is top notch from the intake to the nurse's the Doctors and even the xray tech. Very polite and fast turn around.even the pharmacy is polite and helpful.

Trying to find parking here Â is ridiculous. There's valet and other parking lots but it's mostly full because they share it with the pavilion, women's health center and edinger medical. They need more parking spaces.

Beware of hidden costs. Labwork and x-rays, etc are available on site. However, they may or may not be contracted with your insurance provider. They won't tell you in advance, just write you up for the work like its part of the normal process. You'll go and have the work done, then get a huge bill in the mail once it's too late. Ask about everything. When they tell you they don't know if you're covered or not, decline the work until you find out. You will have to use the same overcautious mentality you would at a used car dealership.

Worst, most frightening experience of my life. I had a tiny non-cancerous cyst which needed removal. My primary physician recommended that I have a cosmetic surgeon perform the procedure, instead of a dermatologist, because this was a facial cyst. Unfortunately, I had the misfortune of seeing Dr. Thuam Nguyen of Fountain Valley at ORANGE COAST MEMORIAL HOSPITAL.Upon his initial examination, Dr. Thuam Nguyen assured me that it was a simple 20-30 minute procedure, using a local pain block. I had cysts removed before and that was the usual protocol. Nguyen then said that I would have to check into the hospital because he lacked an operating room in his office, which was acceptable.Then the real 'fun' started...Nguyen's office and the hospital must have called to re-schedule my surgical dates and times at least 6 times.The morning of my operation, Nguyen's office manager called to say that he had a Â cancellation and asked me to arrive 3 hours earlier than scheduled. She said that he was always punctual, so "please don't be late!". I agreed and checked-in on time.Ended up 'Dr. Punctuality' was three 3 hours late.While I was stuck waiting for hours in pre-op, two Asians, one was a 50-something woman who introduced herself as my anesthesiologist, the other was a young 30-something male (introduced himself as her assistant) and asked me if I wanted a general anesthesia. I said,"absolutely not; Dr. Nguyen already agreed to a local."The self-identified female 'anesthesiologist' laughingly said,"Why you no like Michael Jackson juice?!" (referring to Propofol that killed Michael Jackson and Joan Rivers). The use of Propofol should not be taken lightly and is no laughing matter.FACT: Propofol was developed in Israel for LETHAL INJECTIONS.FACT: The Missouri Supreme Court uses it to execute prisoners condemned to death. Her male 'assistant' kept up the pressure to have me consent to a general anesthetic (more $ for them). Again, I adamantly refused. (Where was my doctor?!)They kept pushing EVEN AFTER I EXPLAINED (AGAIN) THAT I WAS ALREADY ON A DAILY REGIMEN OF PAIN MEDICATION, BETA-BLOCKERS (TO SLOW MY PULSE), and BP PILLS TO DECREASE MY BLOOD PRESSURE. Adding a 'cocktail' of extremely strong sedatives to this mix could have caused permanent brain damage, and at the worst, death. It was becoming more evident that these white-coats were putting me in harm's way for profit. And why was Dr. Nguyen no where to be found to tell these people what he told me: that a topical pain block, like Lidocaine would suffice.It appeared that this last minute hospital bait-and-switch was financially-driven -- for the anesthesiologist and perhaps an extra side-bonus for Nguyen as well. Nearly 3 hours after I had arrived, Dr. Nguyen casually strolled in (with no apology for being late). I was then rolled into the operating room and the next thing I remember is a mask was being shoved onto my face while I shouted "NO!". Â I tried to avoid it by quickly nodding my face sideways. My arms were strapped down on the stretcher so I was unable to defend myself by pushing the mask away. Then I blacked-out.5 hours later, I awoke in a post-op daze, horrified and angry that I had been treated worse then an animal. Because I had so many strong medications already in my system, and then more were added, I became sick. My friend had to move into my home and stay with me for a week because I was virtually bed-ridden. When I was finally able to drive again, about 2 weeks later, I drove to the hospital to pick up my medical records, AND the anesthesiologist's report (which is a separate document, picked-up in another office). The report confirmed that they gave me enough drugs to kill an elephant. It's an absolute miracle that I survived.Thank God, I made it. No one should be abused like that - EVER! I noticed that the majority of patients were non-English speakers, mostly Spanish. My friend witnessed how they were being insensitively mishandled in the waiting room. Perhaps I lived to Yelp to warn people about this incident, or start a patient's advocacy group.PLEASE CALL YOUR INSURANCE COMPANY AND THE STATE ATTORNEY GENERAL TO COMPLAIN IF YOU HAVE EXPERIENCED ABUSE.oag.ca.gov/consumersI filed a formal complaint with the hospital and my insurance company. They said that there was an investigation underway. The result: I received a letter of apology from the hospital. It's all about numbers. If enough people speak up, then the bad guys will be stopped from hurting, perhaps killing more people.The OC Register listed this hospital for Medi-Cal billing abuse. They're still sending me an erroneous bill for an unnecessary EKG (another case of double-billing) since Medi-Cal already paid them. $14,000.00 to remove a tiny cyst!Be careful, stay healthy by eating properly and exercising. Stay out of the ER unless it's absolutely necessary.Most important: if you value your life, stay out of this specific hospital!

This place ridiculous. My son needed to get an EKG to be cleared for the Police Academy. We gave them the Prescription from our Medical doctor. They said that they need a diagnosis? Â He doesn't have any medical condition, he just needs to be evaluated and cleared. I don't understand what the problem is.

I am so grateful that I delivered my child at the Center for Childbirth at Orange Coast Memorial. Â I had originally wanted to give birth at Hoag but after learning that Hoag had a higher caesarean section rate than OCMMC did, I'm glad that my insurance had me deliver here instead.The nurses were warm and compassionate. Â Danielle in L&D is one of the best nurses I have EVER encountered. Her bedside manner is remarkable and she's a huge asset to the OCMMC team. I was working towards a completely natural Bradley Method childbirth and she worked with me every step of the way to make my dream possible. Any time a situation arose that required providing informed consent, she took the time to advise me of all risks and benefits of our decisions along the way. It meant so much that she believed in me and what I was trying to accomplish even if I was one of the most "strong willed" patients they've had. :) Â Geri in Post-Partum was also one of the best nurses I have ever had. Â She was so encouraging and compassionate. Â I felt very connected to her as a patient and she was so sweet to my perfectly healthy newborn son. I feel fortunate that she was looking after us.Lori, the lactation consultant is also fantastic! Â She worked closely with my son and I to ensure we had the best bfing relationship possible. She was so helpful and supportive and I so appreciate her efforts to make sure we had all the resources and tools we needed. Â I had several private appointments with her and she was great. Highly recommend her.These nurses are a huge asset to the OCMMC team and made my experience there so wonderful. Â I was concerned when I found out that I wouldn't be delivering at Hoag Newport, but it turned out being one of the most serendipitous things that ever happened to me. I could not have had a more magical experience there!My only suggestion is to have the newborn photo photographer let the parents know up front that the photos she'd be taking were for photo packages. It seemed a little shady that she made it seem like she'd be taking free photos, then put on a whole sales pitch. It's a little much for new parents facing the expense of a brand new child. Â My hubby felt that her approach was a little bait-and-switch-y, but I love the photos I purchased.

My husband has been admitted twice, Â through E.R. Â I have to say the hospital is run so efficiently. Â The staff was awesome, the staff always made my husband feel he was getting top of the line care. Â His medicine was always on time and everything explained with care and confidence. Â They were great with explaining the care with family. Â I think this hospital should receive an award for being the Â kind of hospital that others should model themselves after. One more thing I found myself lost (after being up all night) Â a nurse who was leaving after a 12 hour shift, Â took the time, and I was going the opposite direction to take me all the way to the exit lobby. Â I didn't ask for help, she just happen to ask how I was.

I recently had the wonderful experience of going to the Emergency Room. Wonderful not because I was ill but because of how I was treated. Â With respect and kindness. Â The staff was wonderful and the doctor I saw was very kind. Â Thank you.

Usually this medical center is awesome, but today I went in to have an ankle sprain evaluated that is causing a huge amount of pain. A physicians assistant shows up that literally looked 12 years old and offered absolutely no help whatsoever. When I asked to see a doctor, I was told "This is the doctor". I am sorry, but I don't even think this is legal. A Physicians assistant is "an assistant" and not a doctor. All I can say is I best not see charges against my insurance for "Doctor services" because I will fight them, legally.

My wife just had a C-section at this hospital. Now that we have been to the maternity ward and ER of both Hoag and Orange Coast I have a frame of reference for comparison...PROS: Spouse (or partner) can sleep in the same room in an actual bed as long as the hospital is not too busy (bed space is limited to 21 beds but the hospital was not that busy when we were here; we missed the full moon by a few days). At Hoag you get an uncomfortable cot to sleep on. The night nurses were great - very attentive and a great bedside manner. There is a bit more of a personal touch whereas at Hoag you were more of an ant among billions of ants. Proximity was a big plus for us as we live only 3/4 mile away and I could shuttle my son back and forth to see mom and the new baby. Hoag was better at educating new parents offering special classes and making birth parents watch a series of videos. Parking is free - Hoag charged $20 for a weekly parking pass or $8 per day. CONS: Only one meal for dad - Â Hoag had at least one meal a day for birth partner. Some of the day nurses were like legacy airline flight attendants - knowledgeable and experienced but a "my way or the highway" mentality, we missed the waterfront view we had at Hoag, the Labor and Delivery rooms were much nicer at Hoag, the common areas are not lavish like a 4-star hotel. We had an experience at the ER at Hoag on a Friday evening (maybe around 7 pm) where we have to wait 3-4 hours to get in. At Orange Coast we went to the ER at 3 am on a Saturday and there was virtually no wait. The doctors and staff were very friendly and helpful.We would definitely come back to this hospital for our next baby (we love Hoag too) but prefer the ER at Orange Coast.

Horrible staff! Maternity building Security and front staff wont even allow any child in the lobby. Demanded my husband to stay outside with a toddler with almost 95degrees heat or leave. Wow! Hospital Lobby is just for adults i guess!

Had a c-section 5/16/14 8:25am All the Nurses & staff were great before delivery & after delivery Mirete, Charley, Dorris and everyone else thnk u for taking care of me and baby. I had a great experience had a room to myself great view thankfully didn't get a roommate I had more than 2visitors at a time nurses were ok with that as they didn't say anything while they went in to check my vitals grateful for there attention made me feel good all the time explaining what was going on while they were doing something to me or baby. Thank you OCMMC nurses and staff for making my stay a great expirience.

Staff is very kind. They are extremely helpful and make you feel at ease. The wait is not long they help you feel comfortable and make things so clear and easy. I have been here a few times and they are always so nice. I highly recommend this place. Doctors make you feel like family.

So let's go back, this hospital definitely did a 180 and worked to rebuild my trust with them. After the previous post I had two very nice women come to ask me about my experience (Lynn and Mary) who both were very attentive. What I liked most is they didn't belittle the ways I was feeling or try to excuse it, they simply accepted it and made efforts to remedy this situation. Thank you ladies! So often the hardest part is simply being heard and believed without someone trying to diminish the validity of how you feel. They then brought me down to the OR, because surprise surprise! I was on the schedule to have my gall bladder out. :) I think they may have hand picked Elizabeth for me to repair the damage of my previous experiences. Elizabeth, without you I wouldn't have made it through! She literally held my hand while I cried and processed through my fears about what was about to happen. She was grace and kindness itself with me and before the doctor even made it in to see me, she had me laughing and calm again. Well played Lynn, Mary and Sue! She was wonderful! Had all my interactions been with Elizabeth or people like her my entire review would have been 100%! However, I won't allow the actions of three to skew the way I feel about everything else. Dr. Murray was amazing, efficient and calm, as was the rest of my team. As someone who was alone and scared, thank you! I'm now in recovery with both Cathy and Joselito who have been nothing but attentive and accommodating. What a way to turn an experience around. Thank you very much! And thank you Lynn, Mary, Sue and Beth got actually listening and making this experience not only no longer a negative but into a positive. I appreciate all the hard work. :) thank you again!

Have an emergency? Â Don't go here! Â Go to Hoag if you can. My sister had to go to the ER because of a surgery she had there and the incision from the surgery was infected. Â She got to the ER around 2pm and they sent her outside in the cold - want to know how long it took for her to get a bed? She finally got a bed at 9PM! Â My sister was sitting there with blood oozing out with her shirt drenched in blood - crying in tons of pain. Â After hours of waiting in the tent, they brought her into a hallway in the hospital to wait for a bed to be available. Â They lifted her shirt and was looking at her wounds in front of everyone passing by in the hallway which was really embarrassing for my sister. Â They sat her outside of the break room for the staff and while waiting, she and my mom had to listen to male nurses/doctors talk about other women employees in the break room in a crude and disgusting way. Â The things they were saying were so unprofessional and rude. Â Anyways, my sister sat in that hallway for the longest time until they finally told her she needed to be admitted. Â They had a room ready for her for over an hour but workers kept saying "I'll find someone to take you up to your room." And then they would walk away and not come back. Â So, after that nightmare, my sister was waiting for her doctor who performed the surgery to check on her - but the PA said he would be in first thing in the morning to see her. Â Guess what? Â We waited at the hospital alllllll day and finally they said that no one even contacted the doctor because they forgot! Â So they finally came back in to tell us that the doctor wouldn't be in for the rest of the week. Â Great! Â What a complete joke. Â If you can, avoid this ER!

My son was seen in the ER on 9/21-22. He had surgical emergency. Â He was seen around 2115 and in surgery about 2.5 hours later. After having an ultrasound, blood work and having everyone get called in from home. I have worked in ERs for many years and I was impressed. I now work in the home health field, and when my husband asked where to go I said orange coast, Â why -- because I don't hear anything bad about them. In my field, Â that is a GOOD thing. Thanks to all the staff on that night!

It was a LOT cleaner when it first opened. Â  Rooms seem a bit confined. Â There is a lot of room, Â however, Â for family And guests in the lobbies and patio areas... beautiful building and architecture!

The tale of two hospitals .Base off of a mile to two mile difference in the city of Fountain Valley lies Orange Coast Hospital and Fountain Valley Hospital.One can heal you Â while Â the other could potentially kill you with their crusty doctors , dirty environment and incompetent staff.How many hospitals have I been to in the past year? 5 by now and by far this is my favorite hospital. I like the care received post surgery. I can't comment too much on the doctors since this was Â one of the hospital my grandmother's general doctor works for so Â we came here to schedule her surgery.I had already talked to her surgeon multiple times and was familiar with his educational background so I wasn't afraid about having a bad doctor. My grandma has been her twice , once in ICU and telemetry on the 3rd floor Â towards the side that tends to Â cardiac patients.On the cardiac side it's a 4:1 patient to RN which is always a plus. A lot of the hospitals in the area have huge patients to RN ratios and it's just not feasible to give patients the care they deserve.ICU:I can't say this is my favorite ICU, the rooms are very dark and Â not centered around the nurses' station. In terms of attention, I felt that the nurses here just showed up sporadically , they weren't as attentive as the ones around garden grove and UCI medical. I guess I just expected them to be more personable but they did their job so that's all that matters.Telemetry:I total love the care! Granted I had a nurse that was a bit creepy but overall the other nurses where so attentive and quick in response to my grandmother's needs. The CNA kept her clean and that's a big deal. In hospital people have greasy hair or bad breath because they aren't well cared for.Pre-op room:Jennifer in the pre-op room is feisty but I like her no bullshit attitude.Waiting area for surgery updates:Now the last time my grandmother had surgery was at UCI , and at UCI there was a waiting room that gave updates to the surgery progress. You can look at a screen with a patient's code number to know what's going on with your love ones. Using that Â experience as a bench mark OCMMC really lacks in that respect. Your essentially just sitting outside for the longest time not knowing whats happening until the doctor comes out. My family was waiting for 2 hours after my grandma was out of surgery until I ask the front receptionist when we are able to see her.Just not as efficient as I would like.Bottom Line:Orange Coast memorial is a great hospital in my opinion given the experiences I had here:the hospital is Â clean,the nursing staff aren't idiots , the hospital is applying for magnet. Granted, I don't think all the doctors here are great. I have seen the asshole who was my grandmother's doctor when she was at Fountain Valley hospital actually roaming the halls. Apparently that dick wad works here , probably scamming people off Family Choice HMO ( BTW WHICH IS AN HMO NO ONE SHOULD HAVE PERIOD). If I could kick the shit out of him and not face legal charges I would.

If I can give them zero stars I absolutely would. This hospital employs the laziest nurses I've ever seen and I've seen my share of hospitals throughout my life unfortunately. They are rude and lazy to your face and behind the curtains. So F*****g unprofessional. I can't believe the things I heard them saying..speaking out loud about such unprofessional things. Example: in the emergency room, where I can guarantee not a single person would Preferably be there rather than in their warm beds, who are in a lot of pain and scared, the nurses, trainees and front desk are LOUDLY speaking about zodiac signs (I hadn't been checked on in over 45 min) and birthdays and cackling about their boyfriends. 2nd example: during discharge, after a nurse closed the curtain started speaking loudly about how unfair this is and how tired they are and how "it never ends". I understand it's a hard job, but I can guarantee none of these people wanna be here willingly nor did anybody ask you to take this job. Â 3rd example is that after 4 days of being in the hospital, not a single documentation of my entire stay as of medications or anything has been recorded nor communicated to any nurse. THIS IS HOW PEOPLE END UP IN COMAS OR DEAD. 4th example: I caught an INFECTION due to their laziness and carelessness. Many more examples but I won't go on any further. STAY AWAY FROM HERE

Customer service is below mediocre.Tried to call Amber and Jennel for Â several weeks and still no success, left several voice messages and no one returned my call.They practice exams without a permission and you find a surprise Bill under your door.I will certainly escalate this to their corporate office.
Such caring ladies work here!!! This review is for the wig bank . The ladies are angels and took the best of care with my girlfriend. Thank you for taking the one on one time with her .

We had a billings problem with them. My Insuranse company was willing to pay but the hospital kept billing them wrong. When I called, they lied about the doctor giving them wrong information. Billing people just don't care enough to pick up a phone to call the insurance company to clear the mess.

I took my mom here this morning for a stress test per her Cardiologist order. Â She was so scared and nervous going there, which is understandable for someone her age. Â The process took about 3 hours in the Nuclear Department, that was where we met this wonderful technician Viet Pham. Â He first welcomed us with a big smile, explained all the procedures before he started, then patiently answering all of my mom questions and concerns. Â When he saw how nervous my mom was, he wanted to make sure my mom was at ease by making her laugh, told her not to worry and stayed by her side the entire time. Â Most of all, he made my mom feel safe throughout the process. Â He even went out of his way to bring my mom lunch and gave her a blanket when she was cold, waiting in the waiting room. Â What a service and a true gentleman! Â I can tell he is very sincere, he loves his job and loves helping people. Â This hospital is very lucky to have him on staff. Â As a business owner and a husband in medical field. Â I acknowledge and appreciate this kind of service, where customers / patients come first.

Michelle Edwards-King is the BEST!!! She is very informative and listens to all your questions. I was extremely nervous but after speaking with her she eased my mind. I had such a good time laughing and talking to her about everything. She was punctual and had everything scheduled to the T. She is such a great person and I really appreciate her taking the time to make sure I had everything needed to be successful I can't say THANK YOU enough. You are AWESOME!!!! ORANGE COAST IS SO LUCKY TO HAVE YOU. THANK YOU SO MUCH :)

I am writing to express my deep gratitude for all that the ICU doctors, nurses and assistants at OC Memorial Care have done for my mother. My mom was admitted to the hospital due to respiratory failure caused by a rare drug-induced autoimmune disease. The team in ICU worked incessantly to bring my mom back to life, and for that, my family and I are forever in debt of their kindness. Â Unfortunately, she passed away this morning at another hospital. Nevertheless, we are forever grateful to all the wonderful staff--Dr. Asciuto, Dr. Dinh, Dr. Espeleta, Dr. Singh, Dr. Jacoub, Dr. Nguyen ChiDao, Dr. Hsu, Dr. Ananth, Dr. Voung Nguyen, Dr. Dang, Dr. Burke, Dr. Sungkapalee, and Dr. Rodnei. The nursing staff includes Boonpit, Todd R., Harry H., Mika, Brenda, Lourdes, Lindsay T., Lawrence, Thao H., Hesna T., Cinda., Chad P., Elizabeth., Kerry and everyone else who's name we have missed.

If you asking me to go back to the hospital because there is no more hospital and you will die I prefer to die Â  Â very very unprofessional attitude from the RN's and seems the management is poor for training

We had a recent delivery here and the staff on the L&D and Mother Baby were fantastic! All the L&D nurses were amazing. They were all very patient, caring, and had really nice gentle touch. I cannot recall all their names because quite a few came to take care of me for a length of time. Marcel, Terri, Baraba, Lisa, Mary Ann were all great, even though they were very busy because of the high census that day. I couldn't have asked to deliver at a better staffed facility. After the delivery Karen and Yoli took good care of me and the baby as well. There is a lactation nurse who comes to visit, even without asking! The dietary staff were excellent, and gave extra oatmeal when I requested it, for fearing of jammed plumbing (aka constipation). Kudos to y'all!

This review is for Lori, the lactation consultant, Ginger in labor and delivery, and Char in post partum. These nurses are amazing and the care they provide is of the highest quality. They care for their patients and go above and beyond. I feel so fortunate to have had my birth experience here under their care. You can tell it is not just a job for them and truly care and have compassion for their patients. I cannot say enough good things about these women named. I'd like to nominate them for a daisy award but do not see the information online.Unfortunately, our NICU experience was the exact opposite. One nurse in particular who has a bad reputation among the staff soured our experience here. I do not understand why she is still working here. I agree with other reviewers that this center is not pro breastfeeding and pro skin to skin, despite their claims. A vast amount of research exists that reports skin to skin and breastfeeding are life changing and life producing for babies in the NICU. However, this is not the atmosphere created in the NICU. New mothers are vulnerable and this mistreatment could lead to post partum depression. Parents are viewed as a nuisance. I hope your family does not have the unfortunate experience of having to have your baby in the NICU. If so, remain adamant about being with your baby, I wish I would have continued to do so. This nurse should be terminated for the unethical treatment she provides. I hope management views this and action is taken to remove this incompetent nurse. I will wait on a response and take action accordingly.

My father was treated poorly as a patient. He generously donated to this hospital. Â They not only charged all of his Medicare part A,B,C,D,F Â which cost a house in California but we received massive billings from many Dr's in the hospital after his passing. Â They left him to pass with inhumanly without treatment nor told the family ( wife ) the cause of symptom. Â I now view Dr's with lack of compassion but just money hungry. Â They never gave information about his condition to his wife ( my mom ) but yet my mom got the bills. I will change my ratings for this because someone was concerned and did reached out to my mother to sort everything out. Â I thank you for being concern as a healthcare.

If you want to be treated with respect, do not give birth at the child birth center here. at first I thought it was great, until it was time to delivery. My water broke very early in the morning, and after them pissing around for 4 hours and not checking me, they finally listened to me that I knew this was it. Being 19 they didn't respect me. The whole time they were telling me I needed an epidural because I didn't know what I was doing, I had already gone natural and was doing just great. I started getting a fever and the baby was in distress, so they FINALLY decided to check me and finish breaking my bag of waters. The doctor saw that there was meconium in the fluid and said nothing until very much later. More time went on and I got sicker and sicker to where I was blacking out, I do not remember the last hour of my labor, but I was given an epidural, and rushed for an emergency C section because they let me go too long, and it caused an infection for both the baby and I.In the operating room, the anesthesiologist asked to wait for her to use the restroom, which they did.. But as she came back and they were asking me if I could feel them poking me, I very clearly said yes because I could feel every Poke They said, sorry but we have to get started. Â  I felt them cutting me, the burning hurt but I couldn't move so I screamed and yelled, my boyfriend told them to stop that I can feel it and they told him to shut up that I was lying! Once the baby was out they put me completely under because I began losing too much blood. When I woke up in recovery I found out my baby had to be admitted to the NICU because he had an infection and needed a course of antibiotics. The woman pediatrician was a joke, she kept promising my baby could come home and then would extend it longer. He was born with a 102 fever because THEY didn't move things along sooner, and didn't mention til AFTER that they already knew he had gone to the bathroom inside.. To top it off, the NICU nurses, NEVER told me if they were doing any procedures on my baby. They moved his IV 4 times and I was never told about it until after they already did it. Blood draw, hearing test, shots, I wasn't told about until after they were already don't and my baby was upset. I could not wait to leave that place and never have to go back. I tell family and friends to stay far far away.

This review is for the post partum ward. My experience with labor and delivery was absolutely phenomenal and not a single thing could have been better. However, once I got to post partum everything was different. OCM says they're a breastfeeding- supportive hospital but drastically failed to be supportive when I gave birth there in June. I was fed a ton of misinformation claiming I needed formula when I didn't and was never informed of things I should have been in order to prevent issues with breastfeeding later. Formula was heavily pushed when it did not need to be. A pump was never offered to me, even when my daughter was taken to the nursery for jaundice. I was told she would be brough to me for feedings when she was hungry and I had to call every single time and usually the nurses fought me on it saying she didn't need to eat and they already fed her even though they weren't supposed to. On top of failing in such an important area for me, the nursing staff was very inattentive in post partum. My pain meds, after an emergency c section, were consistently late. I was told I needed to call for help every time I needed to use the bathroom and it would sometimes take close to an hour to get a nurse in the room when I had to pee.I gave them two stars because the hospital was very clean and my husband was able to stay with me some of the time because they had an empty bed. This is not always the case though, so don't count on that.If you know what you are doing as far as breastfeeding goes and you have a routine birth, your experience should be okish here, but as a first time mom with a c section birth, they really failed me and my daughter.

We just delivered our 4th child here. I delivered my previous 3 Children at Hoag Newport Beach. I LOVED it here. If I would have had my first child here, I'm sure I would have had them all here. The labor and delivery nurses are all so wonderful (Ginger, Joanne, Jenny, Lori, Dawn, Veronica, Sarah, Robin) they made me feel very comfortable, answered all my questions and made the entire process seem like a breeze. I named that many nurses because I came in at shift change so we had several nurses helping with our labor. The anesthesiologist (Dr. Saman and Dr. Nguyen) were heaven sent!!! I was able to rest for about 2 hours before pushing this wonderful blessing out and it was almost painless. Actually, it was painless after Dr. Nguyen hooked it up! Then my OB Dr. Tracy came in and worked her magic! By far the best OB ever! She's been my OB since my first baby and has always been amazing throughout my pregnancy and delivery. Post partum nurses have been amazing as well (Beth, Veronica) always doing the most to make mommy, daddy and baby feel most comfortable and relaxed. The entire experience was wonderful and amazing. I would suggest this place for labor and delivery to all my friends and family. Thank you OCM labor and delivery team for making this labor and delivery experience so easy and comfortable.

I don't know what it is about this ER staff, but they are the nicest and most caring group of physicians, Â nurses and PA's. Â I have been there three times this year and today's visit was no different. Â The gal (forgot her name) Triage Nurse who checked me in was the kindest, warmest person. And she came back later to my room to check on me. I am so sad I can't remember her name but Mary sounds familiar. I apologize was very sick. My PA, Megan was on top of my treatment and very attentive. And what can I say about my nurse Elena. Â All professional and kind. Â I am feeling lousy today but wanted to stop everything and write a review. Â  Thank you to everyone.

There are good things about this hospital and not so good. Â It's a beautiful campus (a little confusing though to find the right building).Surgery went very well - thank God. Â Waiting room staff were great and went out of their way. Waited about two hours to be called and allowed to go to recovery. Was told one hour.Had a hard time communicating with most Asian nurses. I thought speaking good English was a requirement. Â :(Had to go get a nurse because the roommate's IV was beeping for a while and nobody came to check it. Â Don't they get notified at their stations?Had to flag the nurse for a bedpan. Took another 15 minutes and 3 requests at their station for someone to come and remove it. Â Sad! Â What if I wouldn't have been there?Liquid diet comes - Unbelievable! Besides the tea, chicken broth (God only know what was in there), 4 type of juices from concentrate, frozen bar - I think it was Blue Bunny. Â Am not exact on the brand but I remember the ingredients: water, sugar, corn syrup, high fructose corn syrup, junk flavoring... and Red 40, Yell0ow6, Blue 1, yellow 5. REALLY! NOWADAYS AND IN THE HOSPITAL. WHERE DID THE NUTRITIONIST GET THEIR NUTRITION DEGREE? Â And let's not get into how much they charge. Â Disappointing to say the least!

Courteous and professional staff takes time to explain things and to answer patient's questions. Â Very friendly and positive atmosphere promotes faster healing!Large visitor parking off Talbert street with prompt shuttle service.Suggestion to better identify hospital entrance for visitors

Words cannot give justice to how I truly feel about Dr. Reddy and her practice. I have the utmost respect for her and I owe her a debt of gratitude for the care she gave to me. I truly had my options in choosing who I wanted to direct my care and the first person that came to mind was Dr. Reddy as I have witnessed first hand her compassion and competence. My life literally flashed before my eyes when I was found to have an abnormality on one of tests. Feelings of shock, fear, confusion, and defeat took over me when I received the news. Immediately I turned to Dr. Reddy and she very calmly, efficiently, and systematically, pulled out all the stops to ensure that I received what I perceived as "above and beyond the call of duty" care. During my times of fear and anxiety she reassured me and helped me remain calm and focused. She wouldn't just listen to me, but she heard what I was saying and was sympathetic. She was my biggest advocate and supporter. When I was about to make a hasty Â decision on treatment, not listening to her recommendations against it, she did not relent but remained persistent, using various approaches, to give me clarity and it worked. I did not go through with that treatment which would not have been the best choice for me. Thereafter, I gave her complete control and she did not let me down. At the end of it, her recommendation was the best recommendation. Everything turned out as I prayed it would. It would have been different had I done my own thing. She remained professional and caring. She never demeaned me or made me feel that I was not qualified to decide on my medical care; rather, she spoke to me in a manner I could understand so I could be more informed. These are qualities that are hardly ever seen this day in age. These days, patients do not get random follow up calls from their doctor to check on them to see they're doing. Physicians don't sense your fear and then invite you into their office to help to relax you and tell you it's going to be okay. But Dr. Reddy does. She treats her patients as they are members of her family. She genuinely cares. She will fight for you. She will stand up for you. She will make sure that you get the best care that can be given because you are her patient and she expects nothing less for her patients. Thank you again, Dr. Reddy, for saving my sanity, and my life.As a added bonus, her office is located in the new pavilion building which makes getting radiology and lab tests done easy at Orange Coast Memorial. The radiology and laboratory staff are so friendly, welcoming, and calming. They work hard to make your visit as pleasant as and quick as possible.

This rating is for their Imaging and Radiology department. I've had two ultrasounds done here. Both of my experiences were great from beginning to end. It was an easy process to call and schedule an appointment. The reception and registration staff are wonderful. They are friendly and efficient. The back office staff is professional and have a wonderful bedside manner. The exam rooms are quiet and clean. Â I dread having to take time out of my busy day to have any medical testing done. Luckily the staff in the Imaging and Radiology department make it a pleasant experience!

I was a patient at Orange Coast Memorial Ctr (Fountain Valley) Sept. 26-28 2016 (I had a full knee replacement). I have to say not only were my doctor's very considerate so were all the nurses & entire team that cared for me during my stay. Any time they came in during the night they didn't flip on all the lights & make a ton of noise to wake you up, they were very quiet, they only turned on 1 light that was closer to the door, if you were asleep..they would quietly knock on the door or on the cabinet until you woke up. They never startled you, it was a gentle awaking. Now let me compliment my team.....First: DIANE GARIOT, nothing short of amazing & surprising. If you needed anything she was there before you could hit the call button, it was like she knew me for years & my habits. She was very kind & pleasant to chat with and never in a rush. Second: KATIE HENDRICKSON, what a ball of energy! She came bouncing into the room & I totally felt her energy. She was always kind, smiling or laughing all day long (even though she was tired & she was only half way thru her day). I loved being in her presence due to her energy, it made me feel like I could jump up & RUN down the halls with my walker.Third: HALEY ERBES, she was so kind, polite & always there at a moment's notice. I enjoyed talking with her & listening to some of her life experiences. It seemed like I didn't get enough time with Haley or maybe I didn't need her as much but when I did....she was there immediately.Fourth: INES PAUL, she was so quiet. I only got 1 night with her & she was very soft spoken, very quiet & gentle. When she would scold me for not waiting til she got in the room to help me up out of bed she would do it in such a gentle way. She would always compliment you before she scolded you for "not waiting for her". I never had to ask her to refill my water or get new ice bags for my knee...she was there with everything I needed before I could ask. Last but not least JOHN PAUL, he was my first encounter when I got to my room. He made me feel like we had known each other for years, he was comfortable to be around, he was funny & made my stay enjoyable. When I wasn't feeling well he knew how to cheer me up with a simple smile or a short joke (I've always said; "laughter is the best medicine"). My first night after surgery was hard, my blood pressure dropped & my leg went into spasms. John was always there with my med's on time, never late & always polite. He would stand in the doorway & make for sure I was ok since my spasms were pretty bad & my blood pressure dropped too low. He was in touch with the dr & when I was awake he'd explain what the dr had said. THANK YOU to my team of Nurses for taking such great care of me during my stay. Thank you for your support & THANK YOU FOR CARING FOR THE SICK. It takes someone special to care for the sick & elderly....I hope you all know how very special you are.Melanie Johnson

Can not say enough good things about the ER staff! Have both of my parents outstanding care as did the staff in ICU and the floor. When my mom was critically ill the nurses took the time to educate me on what was happening and if my mom passed kindly prepared me that often the other spouse died soon after. When my dad was in ICU they let me sleep during shift change, normally a no-no. I had been sitting next to the bed holding my dad's hand & I put my head on the bed and was out cold! When I woke up the nurse told me they realized how tired I was and was sleeping so soundly they felt I wouldn't hear a thing and I needed the rest. The hospital staff did a fantastic job of caring for both of my parents and educating me

My wife is 24 weeks pregnant and recently woke up with chest pain and palpitations. We took her to Orange Coast Memorial ER and were met outside by the triage nurse, Jeff, who escorted us straight into the triage room. After taking her vitals, we found her heart rate was over 200 beats per minute. He then escorted us straight back to a room where we were immediately met by Doctor Yee, and our primary nurse, Rachel. The OB department was notified and nurse Robin was sent down to monitor the baby while the rest of the awesome team took care of my wife. Everyone was so caring and kind throughout the entire experience. They gave my wife a medication that would briefly "reset" her heart. Before giving the medicine, Dr Yee, Jeff, and Rachel all explained thoroughly what was about to happen and exactly how she was going to feel. The medication worked like a charm and my wife's heart rate lowered to an normal rate. After the medicine, Rachel stayed with us to monitor my wife while Robin monitored the baby. Everything worked out great, and we were in and out in about 2 hours (mostly because they needed to monitor her after the medicine). I have no complaints about our experience at OCM and would definitely recommend them to anyone.

My dad went in to do some tests in the Cardiovascular dept. Viet Pham was the technician who was doing the test for my dad back in Jan. Viet was very patient, professional and accommodating to both my dad and my mom who went w/ my dad that morning. Viet made sure both my dad and mom were comfortable, and even offered to get breakfast for mom in the cafeteria while she waited during the test procedure. Unfortunately I wasn't able to go w/ my parents, but knowing professionals like Viet are here makes me want to schedule future test and visits to OC Memorial. I can see why OC Memorial often get awarded like Kaiser Permanente.
Excellent care by all on staff: doctors, nurses and attendants. The attention and quality of care was exceptional The food was very good too.

How is it legal for these people to operate in business? I try never to go to the hospital, but I was in a pinch and decided I probably should get a hole inside my lip stitched up. Upon arrival, they quickly had me fill a couple of papers out, put a bracelet on my wrist and rushed me into the emergency room. I sat there for about 20 minutes, then a girl came by and said, your health insurance didn't work. So now I had a real issue. I asked her how much the treatment would cost if this was something I was going to have to pay myself. She said, well I can't tell you that, we don't know how much things cost. I told her I'll just leave then. She then went on to say, well no matter what you're gonna pay something because you're in here. This is without having received any treatment at all, just for them admitting me, which they should have checked my insurance before they did so. She said you may as well sign these papers and just take the treatment, you can work out the payment later. That being said, I figured ok, it can't be that much, all I need is a couple of stitches in my lip. BOY WAS I WRONG. So after signing the papers, a PA comes to see me and looks at my lip, she says she can't really do much because it's not that fresh, as I waited over night because I really didn't want to go to the hospital for obvious reasons. She sent a nurse over to clean out my lip, which he didn't do, he had me just do it myself. Then someone came by and gave me a tetanus shot. The PA decided she better give me at least 1 lose stitch, I'm guessing most likely so they could charge me more. So she gives me one lose stitch which didn't really do much and gives me a prescription and sends me on my way. Once I received the BILLS, and not just one BILL, but 2, one from the Hospital and one from the actual PA. They totaled $2500 for 1 lose stitch and a tetanus shot. Yes, $2500, I couldn't even believe that was real, but yes it is. So now due to my health insurance being messed up, because Health Net is the worst health insurance ever created, I'm stuck with this bill. The problem isn't everyone needs health insurance in this country, the problem is, health care is the most ridiculous costing thing in this country. I'm not sure how it's legal, but it is, and we all shouldn't stand for it. It's disgusting that places like this can get away with it.To all the people working here, you're not really helping people, you're just robbing them with a good conscious because maybe you helped them out a bit.

I entered pre op at noon for my 2pm surgery. No one bothered to check on me till 5pm when the surgical rn came in to get me ready for surgery. He finally turned on the iv which had been turned off for the past 4 hours. I also overheard another patient, who had been waiting for hours in pre op, only to have their surgery canceled due to lab results that were only reviewed that day. If you go hear for any kind of procedures make sure you ask questions about everything and have a person with you to make sure you are taken care of. The staff here will not care about you and are more concerned about going home on time.

My first visit was for 3 different pre-op procedures in two separate buildings. The next day I had another procedure and outpatient surgery, again in two separate buildings. Â Everyone in all departments did an excellent job of communicating to the other buildings and departments. Â Registration was organized, quick and easy. Â  I didn't have any waiting for anything. Every single person I encountered was friendly, helpful, cheerful and efficient. Â They really put me at ease and I felt very well taken care of every step of the way.

We went there on Monday August 15, 2016. Everyone we encountered treated us kindly and were easy to communicate with. They cared about their jobs and the patients. We saw the same treatment with the other patients around us too. We had Dr. Tran and Steven as our nurse who both did an excellent job as well.
Elite 2021

Dr Thang Nguyen sent me to the ER. Wait time was minimal. Literally 5 minutes. My nurse was bad. Iv line was not flushed. No pain meds or anti nausea given even though it was ordered. Christine Bernier is an amazing PA-C. She was very attentive and bubbly. I was admitted. Er nurse started a levaquin bag and left. It started infiltrating and kept calling/paging a nurse. No response so as an RN i stopped the pump. I had to wait til i was on the floor for pain control. My night nurse and aide were great and made up for the lack of caring in the er. I would come back since Dr Thang Nguyen is a great surgeon and i am glad i got the attention i did not recieve at saddleback

I am writing my review as a "visitor" even though I wasn't "visiting" and was there to drop off some clean undies for a neighbor who ended up being admitted. Like I mentioned, my neighbor was admitted and I was asked from a relative to deliver some clean undies in a clear ziplock bag to the front desk in hopes a nurse would be able to deliver them to him.....boy was I wrong!!!!!When I entered the hospital, there were 3 men at the reception desk area involved in their own conversation. I was not asked if I needed assistance or if I had a question, instead I was glared at for interrupting them and apparently I was supposed to know that being stared at means the equivalent of "can I help you". I mentioned I wasn't visiting and there to drop off a care package for a patient who had been admitted. I was sent to "Joe" I believe who is the security next to the reception desk. Joe starting filling out a paper wrist visiting band and I said I wasn't visiting and there to just drop off a package. He gave me the rudest look and nastiest response of " this ain't a courier service!" and sent me back to the boys at the counter who again said no we don't take anything to anyone. Finally one of the men said he would take it and my husband slipped him a $5. He ran after us in the parking lot and said he couldn't take the money as this was his job. I asked him what happened and why the drama and disrespect to me inside. He stated that due to liability they cant take anything but because he could clearly see it was only underwear he took it. I told him that was all that needed to be stated to begin with inside, not the unprofessional smart ass remark I received. I am appalled and disgusted by the lack of sensitivity the front desk/security has with this hospital. For being such a sensitive nature facility (ie, a hospital!) the coldness and lack of any desire to even be there was non existent. Care, concern, and values should be top priority when dealing with visitors and patients and all I received was numb. I will be in contact with Human Resources to express my concern on all departments involved. I will never willingly be treated at this hospital nor will I ever recommend it.

The staff here is truly remarkable. During my four day stay I was treated each day by someone even nicer and more knowledgeable than the last and they we're already WELL above average on day one! From the ER to the radiology lab to the blood work team and especially the medical wing I was consistently impressed. I can be squeamish at times and they were more than accommodating. The night staff was WONDERFULLY caring and let me sleep as much as possible. The cleaning staff and maintenance were unobtrusive and kind. The food was really quite decent and food staff made me feel appreciated and comfy with many choices and a pleasant demeanor.When I needed some lightheartedness to calm my nerves they all of them were kind and jovial and when it was time to talk serious stuff they were confident and understanding and very good at listening.I had contact with almost two dozen doctors, nurses, assistants and techs and I would give every one of them 5 stars based on their time with me.I had a lot of choices and I diligently picked Memorial based on family and friend recommendations and I believe I couldn't have made a better choice.Thank you Drs Harris and Hanna, nurses Sheri and Aris and Eme, and all the ER crew including Frank and all in radiology, everyone whose name I missed and especially my intake person who continued to ask about my progress. THATS professionalism!

So upset that I even need to give them one star. The nurses here are by far the worst I have ever seen. Mind you, I understand that being a nurse isn't exactly an easy job, in fact it's very demanding. So I'm not just going to rant and rave about petty things. My mother has been to this hospital twice within the past month. I have to work so when I leave she relies on the nurses to help her. Instead they unplug her nurse call button and place it out of her reach. Then my mother is forced to sit in her soiled clothing for over 45min while my aunt is on the phone with her waiting the whole time. Then there was a new nurse that came in while I was here and when asked about my mother's insulin, she had no clue that my mother even had diabetes. Um hello??? Do you even read your charts??? Had I not mentioned it to her, I highly doubt my mother would have even been given her insulin. I'm sorry but before you come into a patients room... Please have enough decency to want to learn what is going on with the patient so you can better provide assistance.

Wish this was near my house! Had surgery here & stayed for 5 days. Surgical floor was the best!! Â Nurses very polite & caring, housekeeping staff friendly & efficient. Â Food was just okay, but the treatment I received from the entire staff surpasses the 5 stars. Â Best hepatobiliary surgeon ever = Dr. Sean Cao!!

I've never stayed over night, but have had a few tests and outpatient surgeries done here. These experiences have been totally positive. Clean, friendly, and professional care. Very convenient location for me, also.I had to take my daughter to the ER once a couple of years ago....was unhappy with that experience. I actually wrote a letter, and was very quickly contacted. I could tell they cared. My daughter received a quilt from the hospital, hoping our experience would be better if we needed to return. Â Our next trip to the ER...when my spouse was injured - ended up being terrific. Â It's such a small hospital, and I love the new building. A good place with caring staff.

To be fair and highlight the positives and negatives with the hospital I have broken my review down into sections so that they may improve in areas that are unsatisfactory.Staff: Very friendly and nice. Upon arrival (we had admission papers) we did not have to wait long to be admitted and get a room. Staff helped my dad get to his room and was friendly. Nurses were quick to arrive and make sure my dad was comfortable. Â Only problem was that RN say a potential bio hazard in the room but ignored it. 2/4 YelpsHousekeeping and upkeep: Extremely Â disappointed. Thier were several problems with the hospital room we got. Major: Broken razor blade left atop hand sanitizing canister. ( Using the and sanitizer I found it loosely attached so I but my hand atop it to stabilize it and I nearly sliced my hand open so Â I was really offended by this. Their is no telling where the razor blade has been. Granted it could have been used for supplies but I could have been used on a patient with some sort of infection also. Â  Soiled Phone: Trying to make my dad more comfortable I wanted to find the phone in the room so that he could use it if need be. Upon discovering it I was shocked. Atop the phone their is a substance that appears to be blood! God forbid someone uses it a any microbes on it is transferred to to a ill patient. Â  Mattress is soiled: Â  MinorPhone jack out of service. Summary. I truly enjoyed the staff they were knowledgeable, altruistic, and nice. But this does not make up for poor housekeeping. With nosocomial infections and MRSA such a threat to patient health I really hoped that a hospital would be more responsible with house keeping. I am really disappointed with the state of our room. The hospital not only provided a possible entry point Â for microbes to enter (i.e. razor blade), but also allowed the room to be occupied by without a through cleaning creating a threat to public health.

I am so happy with Dr. Thang Nguyen! He did a very complicated surgery on my husband and has helped us though this every step of the way. He is kind, compassionate and has wonderful bedside manner. He always keeps us informed as to what is going on and I seriously do not think I could have made it through this time without him. Please Dr. Nguyen keep doing what you are doing because your kindness really makes a difference. Thank you!!

I am not sure who to contact about my complaint about a receptionist, but it is for the Memorial Care Imaging Center with the phone number of 714-378-7572. I wound up scheduling with Newhope Imaging because I called Memorial Care Imaging and the receptionist was very rude. She accused me of not reading her the MRI description as my doctor wrote. My doctor didn't write a lengthy description and I told her exactly what it said 3 times because she kept asking. The receptionist raised her voice at me and accused me of not reading what the doctor wrote. She also gave me a lot of hassle about how my mri order does not have a box selection for contract or without contrast. I have seen mri orders before and my other doctors gave me ones with a box checked. There was no option to check a box for contrast on this order. I told her that my doctor can fax her. She was being rude and said that it sounds like I am just telling her what I think and not what the paper says. This call took place on Monday, August 31st at 2:44 PM. I called Newhope Imaging after and they were very nice and are verifying my insurance and how much my copay will be first and they are calling my doctor. It seems like the lady from Memorial Care Imaging just didn't want to do any extra work like get a fax from my doctor. She didn't want to do her job. I even said I could get my doctor to fax it to them so she wouldn't have to call.

Moms, moms. Yes yes yes. In the middle of the night when you're exhausted and you have to take your kid somewhere, this is the place. I was in within 10 minutes. Granted it was two in the morning but still it was great. They gave my kid a teddy bear. She was seen within 10 minutes. People kept coming by to check on her. Everybody was very nice. Oh and The male nurse practitioner, very hot! Just in case you want some eye candy while you're exhausted.

Because one of the nurses and pa were so great, i gave 2 stars. Â Other nurses and front end staff were sucky sucky.....very rude and not helpful. Â Took me to individually ask 3-4 people for a blanket for my mom since she was cold in the er. Â Did not make us feel comfortable and barely checked up on us.

The billing people are the worst; they treat you like you're a piece of trash on the floor! Â I'm dealing with 5 different hospital 4 who are very nice and respectful. Â OC Memorial billing service needs to take lessons from a good billing service on how to treat people!!!! Â If I could have given less then one star I would have.

Great and fast when you need them. Took my daughter here the other night and we were in and out like an urgent care. The er staff was friendly and I felt like we were given enough time with the Doctor

All around I feel as if this hospital doesn't have a clue what they're doing. All the schedulers mess up daily on booking appointments and surgery dates. They rescheduled 2 of my boyfriends surgeries due to their mess ups. And his doctor who is suppose to be a "specialist" has no clue on how to handle both of the surgeries. Basically made a bad call on the first surgery, which is why he needs the second surgery. Honestly feel like my boyfriend isn't in the best care here.

Hard for a lay person to grade the technical ability of a medical provider. Most of the time, you just go by the result. In this case, I walked into the ER with a kidney stone problem. If you hadn't experienced this before, the pain can be excruciating. The need for relief is immediate. At five in the morning, following a Saturday night, I was lucky that the ER was relatively empty. They put me on a bed right away and I was immediately attended to by a slew of nurses and doctors. They tried different pain medications before nailing it to give me complete relief. In the meantime, they kept me warm, hydrated, and contacted my urologist. Anticipating a surgical procedure the next day, they added antibiotics to the IV and got me in for an x-ray and mri scan. The 'stone' was located and measured. By the time I was admitted to a semi private room, the ER was full. I spent the next 2 nights Â there while they controlled the pain until they were able to break up the stone via lipotropsy (the shockwave). There were no glitches and I was discharged pain-free on Tuesday. The hospital routine is always the same. You lay there in bed, either in pain or bored to death. Seems like they are waking you up every hour to take blood, your vitals, your meds. Your roommate, if you have one, seems like the person who either yells, complains or snores a lot. (Then again, Â maybe i was THAT GUY.). You try going to the restroom and it's no easy trick hauling your IV pole around with you. Â BUT The one Â thing that stands out this time? THE STAFF. Â No matter what else they had to do, they were without fail patient, helpful and good natured. Not unnecessarily cheerful but extraordinarily professional in the way they did their jobs and doing so as they were being Â besieged by their beepers. Of course that's Â part of their job, it's what they get paid to do but what other job involves 12-hour shifts (during the "graveyard"), with a ward of unhappy/ailing customers, who are given your cell no and the permission to call you with any concern that comes to mind ("my IV is beeping", "can you get me sugar-free vanilla ice cream", "can I have a warm blanket", "can you empty my urinal container"). And those were just some of mine. Â Ok. So that's part of their job, along with the digital paperwork that they have to keep logging and lord only knows what else. I suspect that dealing with the patients is not always the most time consuming part but the most draining. To field multiple requests Â at the same time from different patients at different locations with the patient expectation that their particular request is the most important is a losing scenario. You can never meet that expectation. I expect that they often face criticisms for being too slow or the inevitable "2d beep" and "where are you?" call. OCMH seems to have 2 nurses and then other staff that just pitches in and helps at all times. I was very satisfied with their efforts and results. My needs were always met within a reasonable time. Don't know why someone like me (who is usually pretty clueless) noticed what I did this time but it was something that stood out from how they handled themselves. Â They earned my thanks.

I have been a patient here for quite some time in the past, and now many of my family members also have. When I was in the hospital for 2 weeks, it was not a terrible experience as with some other hospitals I've had to go to. All the staff were friendly, and seemed to truly care and want to help. No one likes going to the hospital, but if needed this is not a bad place to be.

My experience so far for this hospital has been very good. The facility is nice and so are the people here( generally) from Nice receptionists to extremely able staff and doctors. the only caveat is the difficulty in finding the location of different doctors here. Since this place seems to be constantly under construction. I had a pleasant experience here. I can say these good remarks about very few hospitals in the area. Mostly the hospitals are money making machines and so are the doctors but this place does not seem to be one of those kind. I am happy that my doctor referred me to this place and I was able to get in and out on time quickly. I agree with some of the other comments on here the nurses here are very well maintained and extremely friendly. A huge plus for any hospital:)

Everyone is pleasant and kind here. They all seem happy and helpful as well so it makes it easier to come. From the manager to the front desk people, the nurses, lab people and of course my doctor--Dr. Damoui. I couldn't be happier that I made the switch from Health Care Partners to Orange Coast Memorial. And I'm glad my doctor made the switch herself. Kudos to the OCM management team, doctors, nurses and staff.

This review is for the Center for Childbirth at OCMMC. I am writing this review as my newborn and I recover from our c-section, I wish I could give this amazing place more than five stars because it deserves ten. I am so glad my husband and I listened to my OB and decided to give this hospital a chance, we knew this place was special after the initial tour. Everyone at the Center for Childbirth was very welcoming, well educated, forthcoming with information and made us feel comfortable. We knew when we left that we had found the place our baby boy would be born. One of the biggest deciding factors for us is the size of this hospital, it is a lot smaller than others and it makes for more personalized care and attention.
